Motion Finco S.à r.l., a société à responsabilité limitée incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg, having its registered office at 2-4, rue Eugène Ruppert, L-2453 Luxembourg and registered
with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register (Registre de commerce et des sociétés, Luxembourg) under number B234977 (the “Issuer”), is offering €650 million in aggregate principal
amount of its senior secured notes due 2030 (the “Notes”). The proceeds of the Offering (as defined herein) will be used, together with cash on balance sheet: (i) to redeem the Issuer’s €500
million Senior Secured Notes due 2025 (the “2025 Notes”), including paying the redemption premium thereon and accrued and unpaid interest to the date of the redemption (the “Refinancing”
and together with the Offering, the “Transactions”), (ii) maintain cash on balance sheet to repay, redeem, repurchase (including from the open-market) or address maturities of, our other secured
indebtedness, and (iii) to pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions.

The Notes will bear interest at a rate of per cent. per annum. Interest on the Notes will be payable semi-annually in arrears on each and, beginning on . The Notes will
mature on, 2030; provided that if any Existing Senior Notes (as defined below) remain outstanding on 15 August 2027, the Notes will mature on 15 August 2027.

We will be entitled at our option to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at any time prior to at a redemption price equal to 100 per cent. of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed,
plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts (as defined herein), if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption, plus the applicable “make whole” premium as set forth in this
preliminary offering memorandum (the “Offering Memorandum”). At any time prior to, up to 40 per cent. of the aggregate principal amount of Notes may be redeemed with the net
proceeds of one or more specified equity offerings at a redemption price equal to per cent., plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of
redemption, _provided that at least 50 per cent. of the aggregate principal amount (including any additional Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption (unless all Notes are redeemed_
substantially concurrently). The Notes may be redeemed at any time on or after at the redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum.

Upon the occurrence of certain defined events constituting a change of control, each holder of Notes may require the Issuer to repurchase all or a portion of its Notes at a price equal to per
cent. of their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a specified consolidated
net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may elect to redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes at
a price equal to per cent. of the principal amount thereof (including accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any). In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for
the Notes, if holders of not less than 90 per cent. in aggregate principal amount of the outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or
any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right
to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of the Notes. See “Description of Notes—
_Optional Redemption.”_

The Notes will be general obligations of the Issuer. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis by Motion Acquisition Limited (“MAL” or the “Parent Guarantor” and
such guarantee, the “Parent Guarantee”) and, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein), by each subsidiary of MAL that guarantees the obligations under the Senior Facilities,
the Existing 2026 Notes and the Existing Senior Notes (each as defined herein) (collectively, the “Subsidiary Guarantors” and together with the Parent Guarantor, the “Guarantors” and such
guarantees, the “Subsidiary Guarantees” and together with the Parent Guarantee, the “Guarantees”).

Within 30 days from the Issue Date, the Notes and the Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by the Senior Security (as defined herein) that also secures the Existing 2026 Notes,
the Senior Facilities, and certain hedging obligations on a first priority basis. The Notes and Guarantees will be further secured on a first priority basis by the Shared Collateral (as defined herein)
that also secures the Existing 2026 Notes, the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations on a first priority basis and the Existing Senior Notes on a second priority basis. The validity and
enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations
_and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security.” The security interests in favour of the Notes and the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances._
The Notes will be structurally subordinated to all existing and future obligations of the Subsidiaries of the Parent Guarantor that do not guarantee the Notes and effectively subordinated to any
obligations that are secured by property and assets that do not constitute Collateral for the Notes to the extent of the value of such property or assets.

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered,
sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in the EEA. For these purposes, a retail investor
means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of
MiFID II; (ii) a customer within the meaning of the Insurance Distribution Directive, where that
customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II;
or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in the Prospectus Regulation. Consequently no key
information document required by the PRIIPs Regulation for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise
making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling
the Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under
the PRIIPs Regulation. This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of
Notes in any Member State of the EEA will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Prospectus
Regulation from the requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of the Notes. This Offering
Memorandum is not a prospectus for the purposes of the Prospectus Regulation.

**PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL INFORMATION**

**Presentation of Financial Information**

The Issuer was incorporated on 31 May 2019, for purposes of facilitating the Acquisition and
performing certain activities related thereto. The Issuer has no material assets, other than derivative
assets to hedge certain interest rate exposures arising from debt issued by the Issuer, equity interests in,
and/or intercompany balances with, other subsidiaries or affiliates of the Group. The Issuer has no
revenue generating activities of its own and no business operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related
_to the Notes and Our Structure—The Issuer and certain Guarantors are dependent upon cash flow from_
_their respective subsidiaries to meet their obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.”_

We have included in this Offering Memorandum the consolidated financial statements of JVco, which
is the indirect parent of MAL and the Issuer, as well as the level at which we report our consolidated
financial condition and results of operations on an ongoing basis. No separate financial statements of
MAL or the Issuer have been included in this Offering Memorandum.

The financial results of JVco and MAL are not directly comparable. In particular, certain line items
contained in the consolidated income statement and balance sheet included in the audited consolidated
financial statements of JVco and its subsidiaries as of and for the 53 weeks ended 31 December 2022
are not comparable to the corresponding line items contained in MAL’s financial statements for the
same period, as these are impacted by intra-group back-to-back loan arrangements.

Accordingly, unless otherwise stated, all references to “we,” “us,” “our,” “Group” or the “Merlin” in
respect of historical financial information in this Offering Memorandum are to JVco and its subsidiaries
on a consolidated basis.

The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical
accounting estimates. These standards also require management to exercise its judgment in the process
of applying accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or
areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to the consolidated financial statements, are
disclosed in the financial statements.

The extracted consolidated financial information in this Offering Memorandum is presented in pounds
sterling rounded to the nearest million. Therefore, discrepancies between total figures and the sums of
the amounts listed may occur due to such rounding.

In making an investment decision, investors must rely upon their own examination of our business, the
terms of the offering and the financial information.

**Historical Financial Statements**

Unless otherwise indicated, the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is
extracted from the historical consolidated financial information of JVco and its subsidiaries. This
Offering Memorandum presents:

- the unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of JVco and its subsidiaries as of
and for the 13 weeks ended 1 April 2023, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS;

- the unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of JVco and its subsidiaries as of
and for the 13 weeks ended 26 March 2022, which have been prepared in accordance with
IFRS;

- the audited consolidated financial statements of JVco and its subsidiaries as of and for the 53
weeks ended 31 December 2022, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and
audited by our independent auditors, Ernst & Young LLP; and


-----

- the audited consolidated financial statements of JVco and its subsidiaries as of and for the 52
weeks ended 25 December 2021, which have been prepared in accordance with IFRS and
audited by our independent auditors, Ernst & Young LLP, and which include comparative
financial information for the 52 weeks ended 26 December 2020.

For the purposes of this Offering Memorandum, we refer to the 52 weeks ended 26 December 2020 as
the “2020 financial year,” the 52 weeks ended 25 December 2021 as the “2021 financial year” and the
53 weeks ended 31 December 2022 as the “2022 financial year.” We prepare our annual financial
statements on the basis of a 52-week or 53-week financial period. Each of the 2020 financial year and
the 2021 financial year was a 52-week financial period. However, the 2022 financial year was a 53week financial period. Consequently, unless otherwise indicated, our results for the 2022 financial year
include an additional week of trading, which affects the comparability of our results of operations
between periods.

We refer to the 13 weeks ended 26 March 2022 as “Q1 2022” and the 13 weeks ended 1 April 2023 as
“Q1 2023.”

**_Restated Financial Statements_**

_Change in accounting policy relating to software-as-a-service (SaaS) arrangements_

In April 2021, the International Financial Reporting Interpretations Committee (“IFRIC”) issued an
agenda decision in relation to the accounting treatment for configuration and customisation costs in
cloud computing arrangements. This decision clarified that in order for an intangible asset to be
capitalised in relation to configuration and customisation costs in a software-as-a-service (“SaaS”)
arrangement, it is necessary for there to be control of the underlying software asset or for there to be a
separate intangible asset which meets the definition in IAS 38 ‘Intangible assets’.

Since 2019, we have undertaken numerous technology-based projects that utilise SaaS arrangements.
We updated our accounting policy in the financial statements to align with the clarified guidance within
the IFRIC agenda decision. As a result, we have expensed all costs previously capitalised associated
with both the configuration and customisation of these SaaS arrangements. Accordingly, we restated
our consolidated statements of financial position for the 2020 financial year in accordance with IAS 8
‘Accounting policies, changes in accounting estimates and errors’.

The nature and impact of these amendments are explained in note 1.1 of the audited consolidated
financial statements for the 2021 financial year.

_Correction of errors_

We restated our audited consolidated financial statements for the 2020 financial year to reflect the
correction of certain errors that were identified during 2021. The amendments relate to the currency
used for valuation of certain brands at acquisition of MEL by MAL and adjustments due to identification
of certain deferred tax assets. The nature and impact of these amendments are explained in note 1.1 of
the audited consolidated financial statements for the 2021 financial year. These restatements have not
impacted previously reported underlying revenue or underlying EBITDA. This Offering Memorandum
reflects the restated amounts for the 2020 financial year.

This Offering Memorandum includes unaudited _pro forma financial information, presented on an as_

**Non-IFRS Financial Information**

Certain financial measures and ratios related thereto in this Offering Memorandum, including EBITDA,
Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16), Segment EBITDA, operating free cash flow,
operating free cash flow conversion, Existing Estate capital expenditure, New Business Development
capital expenditure, revenue per capita and admissions revenue per capita (the “Non-IFRS Metrics”),
are not specifically defined under IFRS. These measures are presented in this Offering Memorandum
because they are measures our management uses to assess operating performance, and we believe that
they and similar measures are widely used in our industry as a means of evaluating a company’s
operating performance and financing structure, and because we believe they present helpful
comparisons of financial performance between periods by excluding the distorting effect of certain nonrecurring items. These measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other
companies and are not measurements under IFRS or other generally accepted accounting principles.

Our Non-IFRS Metrics have limitations as analytical tools, and you should not consider them in
isolation, or as a substitute for analysis of our results or any performance measures under IFRS as set
forth in our financial statements. Some of these limitations are:

- they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital commitments or
contractual commitments;

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;


-----

- they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or
principal payments on our debt;

- they do not reflect any cash income taxes that we may be required to pay;

- they are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in our
consolidated income statement;

- they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters we consider
not to be indicative of our ongoing operations;

- assets are depreciated or amortised over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be
replaced in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such
replacements; and

- other companies in our industry may calculate these measures differently than we do, limiting
their usefulness as comparative measures.

Because of these limitations, Non-IFRS Metrics should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute
for performance measures calculated in accordance with IFRS. You should compensate for these
limitations by relying primarily on our IFRS results and using these Non-IFRS Metrics only as
supplements to evaluate our performance. Please see “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated
_Financial and Other Data,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and_
_Results of Operations” and our historical consolidated financial statements and the related notes_
included elsewhere.

For a description of how our Non-IFRS Metrics are calculated from our consolidated profit/(loss) for
the year and a reconciliation of our Non-IFRS Metrics to our consolidated profit/(loss) for the year,
please see “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated Financial and Other Data.”

**_Existing Estate capital expenditure and New Business Development capital expenditure_**

Existing Estate capital expenditure, as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents capital
expenditure on our Existing Estate, which typically includes (i) adding new rides or displays and
enhancements to Attractions, (ii) replacing old features with new, more up to date ones and (iii) general
maintenance and refurbishment of existing Attractions (including ensuring health and safety standards
are met or exceeded)

New Business Development capital expenditure, as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents
capital expenditure on the development of new or upcoming Midway Attractions, LEGOLAND Parks,
Resort Theme Parks, accommodation at existing sites and “second gates.”

**_EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16), Segment EBITDA and Segment_**
**_Adjusted EBITDA_**

EBITDA, as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents profit before finance income and costs,
taxation, depreciation, amortisation and impairment and is calculated after taking account of profit after
tax of joint ventures.

Adjusted EBITDA, as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents profit before finance income and
costs, taxation, depreciation, amortisation and impairment, share-based payments, exceptional items
and is after taking account of attributable profit after tax of joint controlled entities.

Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16), as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents Adjusted EBITDA
_less adjustments made to exclude the impact of the application of IFRS 16 to Adjusted EBITDA._


-----

EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) presented in this Offering
Memorandum do not reflect any weighted foreign exchange rate adjustments.

Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) may not be directly comparable with other
similarly titled measures or profit measures used by other companies.

Segment EBITDA, as used in this Offering Memorandum for the 2020 financial year, the 2021 financial
year and the 2022 finanical year, represents segment profit before exceptional items, finance income
and costs, taxation, depreciation, amortisation and impairment, and is after taking account of profit after
tax of joint ventures. Segment Adjusted EBITDA, as used in this Offering Memorandum for the Q1
2022 and Q1 2023 periods, represents segment profit before exceptional items, share-based payments,
finance income and costs, taxation, depreciation, amortisation and impairment, and is after taking
account of profit after tax of joint ventures. Certain costs are not allocated to individual operating groups
and are therefore not included within Segment EBITDA and Segment Adjusted EBITDA. Our segments
are the Midway Attractions, LEGOLAND Parks and Resort Theme Parks (together, the “Attractions”).

**_Operating Free Cash Flow, Unlevered free cash flow and Operating free cash flow Conversion_**

Operating free cash flow, as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents EBITDA less Existing
Estate capital expenditure. Operating free cash flow conversion, as used in this Offering Memorandum,
represents EBITDA less Existing Estate capital expenditure as a percentage of EBITDA.

Unlevered free cash flow, as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents operating free cash flow
less working capital and other movements less adjustments made to exclude the impact of the
application of IFRS 16 to EBITDA.

Operating free cash flow and operating free cash flow conversion are unaudited and are presented to
enhance a prospective investor’s understanding of our cash generation and provide prospective
investors with a useful supplemental measure for comparing our liquidity in respect of our operations
from period to period without the distortions of exceptional growth capital expenditure and other nonoperating items. Our management uses operating free cash flow as a key performance indicator of our
business and as an indicator of our ability to make strategic investments, repay our debt and meet other
payment obligations.

**_Revenue Per Capita and Admissions Revenue Per Capita_**

Revenue per capita, as used in this Offering Memorandum, is calculated by dividing total visitor revenue
by the number of visitors, excluding visitors to Attractions operated under management contracts
(which includes LEGOLAND Malaysia and LEGOLAND Dubai and THIS IS HOLLAND) and as part
of joint ventures (which include, for example, LEGOLAND Dubai Hotel). Visitor revenue includes
both revenue generated from admissions fees, including spend on fast track passes, and commercial
spend, including spend on food and beverages, retail purchases and souvenir photography. Revenue
generated from our hotel operations, private functions and sponsorships, as well as revenue generated
at Attractions operated under management contracts, including LEGOLAND Malaysia, LEGOLAND
Dubai, THIS IS HOLLAND, and under joint ventures, is not included in visitor revenue or revenue per
capita.

Revenue per capita data is unaudited and is presented to provide prospective investors with a
supplemental measure to evaluate our financial performance, enhancing comparison of results from
period to period and by operating group or Attraction by highlighting the visitor revenues achieved per
visitor, as opposed to aggregate visitor revenues which depend largely upon visitor numbers. Our
management uses revenue per capita as an indicator of profitability and yield and uses revenue per
capita to evaluate the performance of operating groups and Attractions from period to period.

**Overview**

We are a global leader in branded, location-based family entertainment. As of 1 April 2023, we operated
141 Attractions, 24 hotels and 6 holiday villages in 24 countries across four continents, and in the 53
weeks ended 31 December 2022, we welcomed approximately 56 million visitors to our Attractions.
We were the second largest theme park operator globally by number of visitors in 2019, according to
TEA/AECOM. We also own eight of Europe’s largest 20 theme parks by number of visitors as of 2021.
We believe we are a market leader in the United Kingdom, Northern Germany and Italy, based on total
visitor numbers in 2021 to Europe’s top 20 theme parks, with an already significant and growing
presence in the United States and the Asia Pacific region. We believe we own and/or operate a unique
portfolio of chainable iconic assets and brands, possessing strong heritage within their original markets,
as well as being globally scalable and supported by our extensive technical and creative expertise.

Our vision is to establish ourselves as the global leader in location-based entertainment. To this end, we
consider our main purpose to deliver memorable experiences to all our visitors, while maintaining a
strategy aimed at creating a high growth, high return, family entertainment business, naturally balanced
against the pressures of the macroeconomic environment in which we operate. We possess a unique
portfolio of family entertainment brands and iconic assets, which are highly diversified across
geography, attraction type, brand and customer demographic and well balanced between indoor and
outdoor Attractions and international and domestic visitation (with international and domestic visitation
measured relative to the relevant Attraction). We believe our footprint across 24 countries provides us
with a favourable platform to benefit from global growth in spending on travel and tourism, which
according to the WTTC, is forecast to increase by a CAGR of 5.1 per cent. per annum between 2023
and 2033 (from $9.5 trillion to $15.5 trillion), by allowing us to attract both international tourists and
domestic visitors, and providing us with a buffer in the event of macroeconomic and currency risks.
Our operating groups offer our visitors diverse entertainment options, including both indoor Attractions
within city centres as well as outdoor theme parks offering multi day visits. In the 53 weeks ended 1
April 2023, 45 per cent. of our revenue was derived from our LEGOLAND Parks and 22 per cent. of
our revenue was derived from our Resort Theme Parks operations, which are primarily organised around
outdoor activities, and 33 per cent. of our revenue was derived from our Midway Attractions operating
group, which is primarily organised around indoor activities, providing a natural hedge against weather
disruptions.

We have established a diverse portfolio of nationally and internationally recognised premium brands
focused on delivering memorable experiences to millions of visitors around the world. We generated
revenue of £2,084 million, Adjusted EBITDA of £717 million, Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) of
£601 million and profit before tax of £126 million in the 53 weeks ended 1 April 2023.

Our three Operating Groups are supported by internal teams including our in-house innovation and
product delivery group, Merlin Magic Making (“MMM”), which includes teams across Europe, North


-----

America and the Asia Pacific region. MMM is responsible for driving innovation across our group.
These teams capture a combination of skills, including research, creative, production and project
management. We also maintain specific resources within our Operating Groups which are dedicated to
researching future opportunities, searching out locations for potential new attractions and negotiating
with local landlords, developers and civic bodies, while also managing a wide range of construction
projects including individual rides and attractions to improve our Existing Estate and leverage organic
growth opportunities.

Moreover, MMM creates compelling propositions and develops new concepts into commercially viable
attractions. Our in-house production capabilities include bespoke content such as wax figures, attraction
theming and LEGO model production, thereby creating efficiencies and reducing costs. MMM is central
to our major projects. In 2022, these projects included MMM’s work to develop LEGOLAND Korea
and the LEGOLAND Korea hotel, the Peppa Pig Theme Park Florida, a Second Gate attraction (which
are visitor attractions at an existing resort with a separate entrance and for which additional admission
fees are charged), adjacent to LEGOLAND Florida Resort, LEGO Discovery Center, Brussels and
Peppa Pig World of Play in Leideschendam, Netherlands, all of which opened in 2022.

As part of the ongoing development of our footprint, we also manage construction projects including
for individual rides and attractions in our Existing Estate, new Midway attractions across the globe and
also engage in the development of full-scale LEGOLAND resorts, the latter through a range of
ownership models which we deploy when pursuing new locations. Capital expenditure for our
LEGOLAND projects which are under a management contract model, are generally not incurred by us
directly, but rather by our local partners. For example, the capital expenditure related to our
LEGOLAND Shenzhen and LEGOLAND Sichuan resorts are incurred by our local partners, while the
capital expenditure related to the LEGOLAND Shanghai resort is incurred by a joint venture in which
we are a minority investor. We also leverage our extensive experience to provide an opportunity for
investors to develop location-based entertainment offerings, and to take on the operation of other
parties’ attractions under management contracts.

We believe that our Attractions continue to broaden our appeal in different markets and geographies,
and reflect the increasing volume and strength of our relationships with third-party intellectual property
holders who seek to leverage their content through location-based entertainment. In 2021, we opened
four LEGOLAND Discovery Centres, which comprised two locations in the USA (San Francisco Bay
Area, and New Jersey), one location in the Netherlands and one in Hong Kong. Moreover, we further
strengthened our USA footprint by opening two SEA LIFE Centres in San Antonio and New Jersey,
along with a Peppa Pig World of Play attraction in Chicago. Over the same period, we also opened a
Madame Tussauds attraction in Dubai (UAE). In 2022, we completed the acquisition of the COEX
Aquarium in Seoul, South Korea, and have taken over the operations of the Cadbury World Attraction
in the UK. Over the same period, we also opened one additional indoor Peppa Pig World of Play
attraction in Leidschendam, one standalone Peppa Pig theme park close to LEGOLAND Florida Resort,
a LEGO Discovery Centre in Brussels (Belgium) and have taken over the management contract of
Amsterdam’s THIS IS HOLLAND flying theatre experience.

Our strategy and performance is underpinned by our commitment to operational excellence and is
driven by an integrated approach to quality management, capital investment, marketing and pricing,
together with a focus on health and safety. We believe that our rebound from COVID-19, highlighted
by strong financial returns in 2022, is also the result of our efficient and strategic deployment of capital
expenditure across the Existing Estate and new Attractions.

We have demonstrated the strength of our diversified business model through our historical financial
track record. The drivers of this performance are:

- investment in our Existing Estate to grow demand, improve customer satisfaction, and where
applicable, to increase capacity. Increasingly, these investments are made in partnership with
leading intellectual property owners to provide immersive, themed experiences for our visitors


-----

(such as “Jumanji — The Adventure” which opened at Gardaland in 2022 and “World of
_Jumanji” which recently opened at Chessington World of Adventures, both part of our multi-_
territory exclusivity agreement with Sony Pictures Entertainment);

- developing new LEGOLAND Parks, including the opening of LEGOLAND New York in 2021
(which included a 250-room hotel), LEGOLAND Korea in 2022 (which included a 154-room
hotel), the targeted opening of LEGOLAND Sichuan resort, LEGOLAND Shanghai resort and
LEGOLAND Shenzhen resort in China, each of which are expected to be during or after 2025,
and potentially other new LEGOLAND Parks in the rest of the world, subject to targeted return
on investment criteria;

- open new Midway Attractions as part of our chainable global brands to drive our organic
revenue growth, with a focus on developing “cluster” locations (where multiple Attractions are
situated in one city or region to capitalise on cross-selling, including through our multi
attraction pass opportunities) and new sites outside of Europe, including in emerging markets.
For example, in 2022, we opened a Peppa Pig World of Play Attraction in Leidschendam (the
Netherlands), a LEGO Discovery Centre in Brussels (Belgium) and have taken over the
management contract for Amsterdam’s THIS IS HOLLAND flying theatre experience, thereby
expanding our local clusters of attractions. We are also expecting to open a LEGO Discovery
Center in Springfield, Washington D.C. in 2023;

- transforming our Theme Parks into destination resorts by deploying a broad range of themed
accommodation and new Attractions, with the aim to improve our customer satisfaction and
drive multi day visitation. For example, in 2021 we opened a LEGOLAND Water Park at our
Gardaland Resort and in 2022 we launched our first standalone Peppa Pig theme park, close to
our LEGOLAND Florida premises. In addition, we are expecting to open the UK’s first LEGO
themed holiday village at LEGOLAND Windsor Resort in 2024, featuring 150 lodges and one
on-site restaurant, complemented by a family entertainment hub;

- acquisitions and new-format opportunities to enhance our portfolio and enable us to grow into
new geographies. For example, in 2022 we completed the acquisition of the COEX Aquarium
in Seoul, South Korea, and have taken over the operations of the Cadbury World Attraction in
the UK. In addition, we also routinely develop new formats of attractions. Currently, our focus
is on Peppa Pig branded attractions aimed at pre-school children. To date, we have opened five
pilot indoor Peppa Pig World of Play attractions (including the one in Leidschendam in 2022),
and one standalone Peppa Pig theme park close to LEGOLAND Florida Resort. We are
planning to open a second Peppa Pig theme park in the Dallas-Fort Worth area in 2024.

**Our Competitive Strengths**

**_Unique Portfolio of Strong Brands and Iconic Assets_**

We own and/or operate a unique global portfolio of brands and iconic assets which we believe are
widely recognised by consumers from a wide range of demographic groups, enabling us to differentiate
our attractions from unbranded operators. Our portfolio of assets and brands is highly diversified across
geography, attraction type, brand and customer demographic and well balanced between indoor and
outdoor attractions and international and domestic visitation. Our well diversified portfolio makes us
well-positioned to meet both short-break and intra-day customer demands. We also partner with thirdparty intellectual property owners to create new brands which complement the portfolio and broaden
our appeal across all key target demographics.

Our Midway Attractions portfolio includes chainable brands such as SEA LIFE, Madame Tussauds and
lastminute.com London Eye, while our Resort Theme Parks attractions such as Gardaland Resort and
Alton Towers Resort, are standalone national brands in their respective markets. In addition, our
LEGOLAND Parks benefit from a mutually synergistic relationship with the LEGO Group, one of the
world’s leading toys’ brands associated with fun and learning through play, that recently celebrated its


-----

90[th] anniversary. The LEGO Group operates in over 100 countries with a global footprint of over 900
stores, based on publicly available information. Our portfolio is focused on delivering high quality
family entertainment, with the LEGOLAND Parks and LEGO/LEGOLAND Discovery Centres in
particular placing an emphasis on “playful learning.” We believe the strength and breadth of our iconic
brand portfolio enable us to offer compelling entertainment propositions through a wide variety of
activities and visitor experiences across a broad range of geographies. This allows us to attract a wide
range of target demographic groups, ranging from families with young children, teenagers, young adults
to older adults. We also believe that the size and diversity of our portfolio provides us with a degree of
resilience against short-term trading shocks which may impact a particular geography, brand or
demographic.

_Midway Attractions_

Our Midway Attractions benefit from high quality, chainable brands with broad international appeal
and recognition, which are distributed across geographies, markets and target demographics, creating a
diversified portfolio. As of 1 April 2023, we operate 25 Midway Attractions in the United Kingdom, 31
Midway Attractions in Continental Europe, 34 Midway Attractions in the Americas and 35 Midway
Attractions in the Asia Pacific region. Our 125 Midway Attractions (including Second Gate Attractions)
were distributed across four continents and included:

- Madame Tussauds, the world’s premier wax figures exhibition for over 200 years, where
visitors are encouraged to interact with historical and celebrity figures in both more mature and
emerging markets, comprising 22 Attractions in 12 countries;

- The Eye brand and observation Attractions with iconic, and internationally recognised
landmarks such as the lastminute.com London Eye and the Sydney Tower Eye;

- SEA LIFE, the world’s largest aquarium brand, comprising 47 Attractions in 19 countries, with
a strong name recognition and a track record of providing high quality and informative family
entertainment for over 40 years and campaigning actively on a variety of conservation issues
prioritised around breeding, rescue and protection of the marine environment;

- The Dungeons, comprising ten attractions in four countries with a strong reputation amongst
the teen and young adult market for a unique mix of dark, historical horror and irreverent
humour, delivered through set piece shows performed by live actors, rides and themed sets;

- LEGO/LEGOLAND Discovery Centres, an extension of the LEGOLAND brand to the Midway
Attractions format, offering the same values of interactivity and family fun in a smaller, more
accessible format, comprising 28 Attractions in ten countries, including the LEGO Discovery
Centre opened in Brussels in 2022; and

- Five Peppa Pig World of Play Attractions, comprising a range of attractions aimed at pre-school
children and based on the Peppa Pig brand, featuring family inclusive activities in an immersive
play environment and one Peppa Pig theme park, which features multiple rides, interactive
attractions, themes play-scapes and shows, all based on the Peppa Pig brand.

In addition, we routinely enhance our Midway Attractions portfolio by adding new Attractions. For
example, in 2022, we opened a Peppa Pig World of Play Attraction in Leidschendam (the Netherlands),
a LEGO Discovery Centre in Brussels (Belgium) and have taken over the management contract of
Amsterdam’s THIS IS HOLLAND flying theatre experience, thereby expanding our local clusters of
attractions. Lastly, we are expecting to open a LEGO Discovery Center in Springfield, Washington DC
in 2023. In 2022 we also completed the acquisition of the COEX Aquarium in Seoul, South Korea,
thereby adding a further significant attraction to the SEA LIFE portfolio, and have taken over the
operations of Cadbury World in the UK, which allowed us to strengthen our relationship with the UK’s
largest chocolate brand.


-----

Other Midway Attractions include two Treetop Walk experiences in Victoria and New South Wales,
Australia, one WILD LIFE Australian animal adventure Attractions in Sydney, “DreamWorks Tours’
_Shrek’s Adventure!”_ Midway Attraction in London, “Bear Grylls Adventure” Midway Attraction in
Birmingham and two “Little BIG City” Midway Attractions in Berlin and Beijing.

Our scale and portfolio of strong brands has allowed us to leverage a number of strategic synergies. We
have developed “clusters” of Midway Attractions in Amsterdam, Arizona, Bangkok, Beijing, Berlin,
Birmingham, Blackpool, Chicago, Dallas, Hong Kong Istanbul, Kansas City, London, Manchester,
Melbourne, Michigan, New Jersey, Oberhausen, Orlando, San Antonio, Scheveningen, Shanghai,
Shenyang, Sydney and Tokyo, where multiple Attractions are situated in one city or region to capitalise
on strong cross promotional and operational synergies, including multi attraction tickets to drive crossselling.

_LEGOLAND Resorts and Parks_

The LEGO brand is globally recognised and is associated with fun and learning through play. We hold
the global, exclusive license to own and operate LEGOLAND Parks until at least 2075. We own and/or
operate ten LEGOLAND Parks in eight countries. The parks are located in Denmark, Germany,
Malaysia, the United Kingdom, Dubai, California, Florida, New York, South Korea and Japan, all of
which build on the strength of the LEGO brand and are themed and interactive parks, which are
designed to appeal to families (particularly with children aged two to twelve years) looking for a fun
and engaging day out.

We have significantly expanded our LEGOLAND offering in recent years with the opening of
LEGOLAND New York in 2021 and LEGOLAND Korea in 2022. We operate the parks in Malaysia
and Dubai under management contracts. LEGOLAND Japan is “leased and operated,” meaning a thirdparty partner (a subsidiary of KIRKBI) funded the acquisition of the park site, the development of the
infrastructure and the basic construction while we funded and built the rides, provided the necessary
theming and built the on-site SEA LIFE Centre second gate and the on-site accommodation. We lease
the site on a long-term basis and operate the park.

In addition, we are also developing three LEGOLAND Parks in China in cooperation with local
partners. Each of LEGOLAND Sichuan resort, LEGOLAND Shanghai resort and LEGOLAND
Shenzhen resort is expected to open during or after 2025. All three will be operated under a management
contract model.

All of our open LEGOLAND Parks have themed on site hotels ranging from 61 to 263 rooms. During
the 2022 financial year, we opened a 250-room hotel at LEGOLAND Dubai, in partnership with the
park’s owners, and a 154-room hotel at LEGOLAND Korea. In addition, during the 2021 financial year
we opened a 250-room hotel at LEGOLAND New York and in the 2020 financial year we opened a
150 room LEGOLAND Florida Pirate Island hotel. Adding on site, themed accommodation has
historically improved guest satisfaction, increased the catchment area for our parks, increased the level
of pre booked revenue and improved cross-selling opportunities. We routinely consider potential plans
for adding additional accommodation at our LEGOLAND parks in future years. For example, we are
developing and plan to open in May 2024 a LEGOLAND Woodland Village, the UK’s first LEGO
themed holiday village, at LEGOLAND Windsor Resort. LEGOLAND Woodland Village will feature
150 lodges, an on-site restaurant, and a family entertainment hub. We believe these hotels and villages
provide an integral contribution to the overall customer experience and help drive increases in multi
day ticket sales.

We also have four Second Gate attractions close to our LEGOLAND Parks, including SEA Life
attractions alongside each of LEGOLAND California, Japan and Malaysia and a Peppa Pig Theme Park
close to LEGOLAND Florida.


-----

_Resort Theme Parks_

Each of our six Resort Theme Parks is a standalone national brand in their respective markets, aimed at
families, teenagers and young adults, with themed accommodation at all locations. For example,
THORPE PARK Resort focuses especially on the teen and young adult markets whereas Chessington
World of Adventures Resort is orientated more towards families. Each of our Resort Theme Parks,
certain of which are among the leading theme parks in the UK, Italy and Northern Germany, enjoys
high brand and customer awareness in its local market. We also have three Second Gate attractions near
our Resort Theme Parks, including Dungeons Warwick Castle, Dungeons Alton Towers and SEA LIFE
Gardaland.

We believe that each of our Resort Theme Parks offers a compelling, coherent proposition and strong
theming, with few or no local competitors that can offer the same quality or scale of visitor experience.
We aim to implement effective marketing and promotions to ensure that each brand is the strongest in
its relevant market. Our Resort Theme Parks are recognised as destination resorts, attracting short break
visits from national and, in certain cases, international visitors, supported by short break marketing
campaigns. Each of our Resort Theme Parks has one or more hotels or holiday villages.

Each of our Resort Theme Parks is strongly positioned in its national/regional market, often representing
the pre-eminent visitor attraction in its respective region and benefiting from being situated in a
prominent location with good transport links to areas of substantial populations. In particular, we
believe we have a market leading position in the United Kingdom, as we own the top four UK theme
parks (by number of visitors in 2021) according to the TEA/AECOM Report for 2021: LEGOLAND
Windsor (part of our LEGOLAND Parks operating group), Alton Towers Resort, THORPE PARK
Resort and Chessington World of Adventures Resort (all part of our Resort Theme Parks). We also
believe we hold leading market positions in Italy and Northern Germany, in each case by number of
visitors to Europe’s top 20 theme parks in 2021.

The scale of our Resort Theme Parks and available undeveloped land at certain locations has also
provided opportunities for Second Gate attractions. For example, there is a SEA LIFE centre located
close to Gardaland Resort and a Dungeons Warwick Castle on the Warwick Castle site.

**_Intellectual Property Partnerships_**

Given our global reach and multi-format expertise, we believe we are well placed to benefit from the
growing opportunities to partner with leading owners of intellectual property content, which enables us
to deliver memorable experiences to our visitors and offer our partners opportunities to increase
engagement with their customers. We maintain a core global, multi-product and exclusive relationship
with the LEGO Group. In particular, we hold the global, exclusive rights to the LEGOLAND brand
under the licensing and co-operation agreement with KIRKBI, our largest shareholder. We have a
synergistic relationship with the LEGO Group and KIRKBI A/S, which as of 31 December 2022, is a
75 per cent. shareholder of the LEGO Group with a 100 per cent. ownership of the LEGO and
LEGOLAND trademarks and a 47.49 per cent. shareholder of JVco.

We maintain multiple other intellectual property agreements, ranging from local relationships for
specific attractions, to global, multi-product relationships. These include our multi-territory exclusivity
arrangement to develop a range of attractions based on the Peppa Pig brand, an established global brand
aimed at pre-school children. In addition, we established multiple other intellectual property
partnerships, allowing us to use brands such as Ghostbusters, the Gruffalo, Shrek, Bear Grylls, Kung
Fu Panda, Ferrari and CBeebies, the latter through our partnership with BBC Worldwide. We also
continue to develop new global intellectual property partnerships. For example, in 2022 we opened a
“JUMANJI — The Adventure” ride and, in 2023, a “JUMANJI: The Labyrinth” ride in our Gardaland
Theme Resort, as part of our multi-territory exclusivity agreement with Sony Pictures Entertainment, to
develop and operate attractions, rides, lands, retail outlets and themed hotel rooms based on the studio’s
“Jumanji” film franchise. In 2023, we have also opened a “World of Jumanji” themed land at our


-----

Chessington World of Adventures Theme Park Resort, along with Jumanji-themed rooms at the local
resort hotel, and a Jumanji themed rollercoaster.
