**_Long Term Attractive Market Trends_**

We believe that we operate in an attractive market benefiting from underlying growth characteristics
and favourable dynamics, such as long-term increases in leisure spending, including in emerging
economies. Notwithstanding the recent impact of the COVID 19 pandemic, we believe the global leisure
market possesses a number of attractive features that facilitate growth over the long-term. These include
increasing leisure time in both developed and emerging economies, the value placed on time spent
together with friends and family and growing tourism to gateway cities.

This is underpinned by our long-term belief in domestic as well as international tourism, where we
experienced a strong post-COVID recovery during 2022. We continue to see long-term growth
opportunities from tourism more widely, which benefits our resorts and drives visitation to our gateway
city locations, where we operate our Midway attraction clusters.

According to the WTTC, travel and tourism’s contribution to the global economy is forecast to increase
by a CAGR of 5.1 per cent. per annum between 2023 and 2033, which reflects faster growth than that
of the global economy. A key indicator measuring the size of the tourism industry is the number of
international tourist arrivals. According to the UN World Tourism Organization (UNWTO), in 2019,
tourism growth continued to outpace the global economy, with approximately 1.5 billion international
tourist arrivals, which is an increase of approximately 4 per cent. over the previous year.

We also expect to experience continuing growth in domestic short break holidays (typically composed
of one-to three-day stays). According to the ONS, short breaks taken abroad by UK residents have
grown at a CAGR of 5.5 per cent. per annum from 2009-2019 period, increasing from 6 million short
break holidays taken in 2009 to 10.3 million in 2019. We are increasingly well-positioned to meet this
demand through our combined offering of themed, on-site accommodation and Second Gate attractions
that extend the duration of our visitors’ stay. Accommodation offerings also enable greater cross-selling
opportunities, drive improved levels of guest satisfaction, and lead to increases in pre-bookings, revenue
visibility and positive working capital. Our domestically focused resort positioning also provides a
partial hedge against the impact of macro-economic or geopolitical volatility on international tourism
(including because of COVID-19, as well as the current cost-of-living crisis and inflation) due to the
relatively lower cost of domestic short-break holidays. According to the WTTC, global domestic
tourism increased to a 85 per cent. share in 2021, compared to 72 per cent. in 2019. We believe that our
business has historically demonstrated resilience during periods of economic slowdown and
geopolitical volatility. We believe that consumer spending on family visitor Attractions tends to be


-----

more resistant to cutbacks than many other forms of discretionary spending during periods of economic
downturn because visiting our Attractions may represent a less expensive holiday or leisure alternative
compared to overseas travel holidays for domestic customers in the countries in which we operate.
Additionally, the Attractions may represent a less expensive holiday or leisure alternative compared to
overseas travel holidays for domestic customers in the countries in which we operate.

In addition, we believe that the short break market is growing in many of the countries and regions in
which we operate and, in particular, in key destination cities, such as London, Berlin, Sydney and
Shanghai. According to the Office for National Statistics, in the UK, short breaks taken by UK residents
to visit abroad have grown at an average rate of 5.5 per cent. per annum from 2009-19 period, while the
growth rate of longer holidays (14-27 nights) over the same period was -0.1 per cent. per annum.

We maintain a long-term belief in international tourism. We also seek to benefit from opportunities
arising from tourism more widely, which benefits our Resort Theme Parks and drives visitors to our
gateway city locations (where we operate our Midway Attraction clusters). We estimate that in the 2022
financial year, 77 per cent. of visitors to our Attractions were domestic visitors (as compared with 72
per cent. in the 2019 financial year) and 23 per cent. were international tourists (as compared with 28
per cent. in the 2019 financial year), based on a survey of a sample of our visitors. This survey highlights
a higher weighting of domestic visitors, than we expect for a typical year in the future, as a result of
lower levels in international tourism recorded in recent periods compared to typical pre-pandemic
levels.

While the COVID-19 pandemic had a particularly serious effect on the travel and tourism industry, in
2022, international tourist arrivals totalled 917 million and grew by 102 per cent. compared to 2021,
according to the UNWTO, representing strong recovery. We have Attractions in eight of the top ten
cities ranked as top city destinations for 2022.

Moreover, theme park attendance continues to grow globally. According to the TEA/AECOM Theme
Index and Museum Index: The Global Attractions Attendance Report (2021), attendance at the top 25
global theme parks has grown by 70 per cent., from approximately 83 million visitors in 2020 to
approximately 141 million visitors in 2021. Such strong recovery in 2021 was largely influenced by the
easing up of COVID-related travel restrictions, the success of COVID-19 vaccine administration, and
general consumer confidence levels. According to the 2012-2019 TEA/AECOM Reports, Theme park
attendance on an average grew by 3 per cent. per annum from 2012 to 2019 across all major markets.

**_Strong Market Positions with High Guest Satisfaction Underpinning High Revenue per Capita_**

According to the TEA/AECOM Report for 2019, we were the second largest theme park operator
globally by number of visitors in 2019. We also own eight of Europe’s largest 20 theme parks by number
of visitors as of 2021. Each of our operating groups commands a strong market share within its market
and benefits from competitive advantages. The strength of our brand and our experience in the industry
is supported by a consistent track record of high guest satisfaction and growing revenues per capita. We
believe that our ongoing product investment and innovation, and strong focus on creating memorable
experiences for our guests, have resulted in continued strong levels of guest satisfaction. In 2022 and
2021, we delivered an overall guest satisfaction score across our group of 94 per cent. and a “Net
_Promoter” score above 50 per cent., which measures the propensity for our guests to recommend our_
Attractions. Moreover, our “top box” measure (i.e., the highest level of customer satisfaction that we
record in our customer surveys, indicating when guests are “very satisfied”) and our value for money
rating have also increased in 2022 compared to 2021.


-----

Our guest satisfaction has consistently ranked above our 90 per cent. benchmark since 2008, as shown
by the graph below:

We believe that high guest satisfaction is driven, in part by our ability to deliver shorter queues (with
lower waiting times for rides) and an overall pleasant experience for our visitors. In addition to driving
visitation, we believe that high guest satisfaction scores also contribute to our revenue growth and is
therefore important for our long-term success. In particular, our revenue per capita increased from £22.3
in 2019 to £30.1 in 2022, respectively, underpinning an increasing willingness by visitors who have a
positive experience at our Attractions to spend more (including on our other services and activities).

This increase is also supported by robust customer demand, particularly at our domestically-focused
attractions in the UK, the US and Continental Europe, by our active management of peak day capacity
and by our revenue management initiatives, which allow us to pass increased costs to visitors. Our
revenue management initiatives are also complemented by a dynamic approach to capacity
management, which we tailor to ensure optimal staffing levels and associated costs across our
attractions.

We believe that the strong market position and breadth of the operations of our Resort Theme Parks,
LEGOLAND Parks and Midway Attractions are also supported by our historic investment in each
category. In particular, our existing portfolio of strong brands and use of the LEGO brand offer a
compelling proposition that distinguishes our business. In each of our three operating groups, we benefit
from in house technical and creative capacity, well located sites in attractive markets, permits and
branding relationships.

We also retain a number of competitive advantages in the Midway Attractions operating group. These
advantages include strong brand recognition in connection with existing brands such as Madame
Tussauds, SEA LIFE, the Eye and the LEGO and LEGOLAND brands used by our
LEGO/LEGOLAND Discovery Centres, our own in house Merlin Magic Making team which includes
wax sculptors, our SEA LIFE marine biologists and our ability to operate our Midway Attractions as
part of “clusters,” where multiple Attractions are situated in one city or region to capitalise on crossselling, including through our multi attraction pass opportunities. A popular package amongst customers
is the sale of annual and monthly passes, which are purchased online or at our parks for a one off price
that enables customers to visit all Attractions within a particular country for one year for no additional
admission fee.

In addition, our scale also allows us to capitalise on operating cost efficiencies, including marketing
costs, central management, site development expertise and application of visitor management
experiences across our portfolio.

We also expect to see continuing growth in domestic short break holidays, primarily due to their lower
cost. We believe we are increasingly well-positioned to meet this demand through our offering of
themed, on-site accommodation and Second Gate attractions that extend the duration of our visitors’
stay. Accommodation offerings also enable greater cross-selling opportunities, drive improved levels
of guest satisfaction, and lead to increases in pre-bookings, revenue visibility and positive working


-----

capital. In addition, we believe that domestically-focused resort positioning also provides a partial
hedge against the impact of macro-economic or geopolitical volatility on international tourism.

**_Efficient and Synergistic Operating Model_**

We continue to leverage the scale and synergies within our Group to achieve enhanced revenue
generation as well as operational, marketing and buying power. At the same time, we continue to focus
on operational excellence, delivering memorable experiences for our guests, simplifying our operations
and maximising the synergies afforded by our scale.

We believe that our operating model has developed as our scale has grown, allowing us to operate more
efficiency and flexibly, while maintaining our focus on providing a high-quality experience for our
visitors. In particular, we have re-engineered how we react to changes in guest volumes, applying
dynamic pricing and promotional strategies with a focus on yield management. Our operations are
aimed at managing visitor numbers through periods of high and low attendance volume, extending the
length of stay, encouraging repeat visits, and enhancing overall revenue by also improving our
customers’ online “digital journey.” In addition, we believe that our ability to maintain tight control
over attraction capacities during peak season and lowering peak day volumes delivers a tangible
improvement in the guest experience, increases rides per guest, reduces queuing, and improves average
guest spends.

In key cities including London, Sydney and Tokyo, we developed “clusters” by deploying multiple
Midway Attractions in one urban area or region, with the aim to capitalise on strong cross promotional
and operational synergies, including multi attraction pass opportunities, to drive cross-selling. For
example, in 2022, we opened a Peppa Pig World of Play Attraction in Leidschendam (the Netherlands),
a LEGO Discovery Centre in Brussels (Belgium) and have taken over the management contract of
Amsterdam’s THIS IS HOLLAND flying theatre experience, thereby expanding our local clusters. Our
clustering drive is supplemented by our scale and portfolio diversification of strong brands, which also
allows us to leverage a number of strategic synergies and operate more efficiency and flexibly, while
maintaining our focus on providing a high-quality experience for our visitors.

In addition, we continue to transform our theme parks into destination resorts, thereby extending visitor
market reach and enhancing revenues by unlocking multiple sales channels (including
accommodations), driven by overall visit durations being extended to longer than a single day. We also
invest in ongoing opportunities to drive visitation at our theme parks by opening Second Gate
attractions. For example, we operate a SEA LIFE centre close to Gardaland Resort and a Dungeons
Warwick Castle on the premises of the Warwick Castle site while in 2022 we opened Peppa Pig Theme
Park in Florida, next to LEGOLAND Florida. In addition, we are also planning to open the UK’s first
LEGO themed holiday village at LEGOLAND Windsor Resort in 2024.

Our scale also allows us to benefit from procurement cost efficiencies within clusters, countries, or
regions, while in certain territories our Merlin Annual Pass and Merlin Pass Monthly Memberships
enable our customers to visit all attractions within a particular country for an upfront or monthly fee. In
addition, we maintain Attraction-specific annual passes, allowing visitors to visit a particular attraction
for one year and monthly membership schemes at our North American LEGOLAND Parks. Merlin
Annual Passes can be purchased for a one-off price and enable our customers to visit all Attractions
within a particular country for one year for no additional admission fee, subject to occasional
restrictions, including certain ‘restricted days’. We use the Merlin Annual Pass and the Merlin Pass
Monthly Membership to drive visitor loyalty and brand awareness, to provide us with revenue visibility,
to secure cash flows in advance and to increase levels of secondary spending (including commercial
spending) at the Attractions. We also intend to invest in developing a reliable technological
infrastructure, to support our growth.

We also adopted national promotions at Group level, comprising promotional discounts, or national
marketing campaigns in conjunction with local partners. We also partner with specialist outsourcing


-----

providers in areas such as food and beverage offerings. We believe that higher volumes for an individual
Attraction can be achieved through the use of entry promotions and admission fee discounts. and we
can use such promotions and discounts to distribute visitor attendance across an Attraction’s opening
hours or opening period.

We have also been transforming our support functions through shared service centre initiatives such as
our recent “finance transformation project”. To date, over two-thirds of the value of our revenues are
generated from Attractions whose accounting is managed through our shared service centre.

**_Wide-ranging In-house Development Capabilities_**

We offer an end-to-end value proposition, ranging from research and development to innovation, which
we leverage to run our world class Attractions. In particular, our three operating groups are supported
by teams including our in-house innovation and product delivery group, MMM, which includes teams
across Europe, North America and the Asia Pacific region. Together, such teams capture a unique
combination of skills, including research, creative, production and project management, delivering an
end-to-end value proposition from conceptualisation, development and day-to-day running of
attractions.

We maintain specific resources within our operating groups that are dedicated to researching future
opportunities, searching out locations for potential new attractions and negotiating with local landlords,
developers and civic bodies. Our LEGOLAND Parks, in addition to the LEGO Discovery Center,
Brussels, which opened in 2022 and the LEGO Discovery Center in Springfield, Washington D.C.,
which is expected to open in 2023, represent prime examples of these efforts. In addition, our MMM
team is our in-house specialist team in charge of activities which include the creation of compelling
propositions and development of new concepts into commercially viable attractions. MMM also
supports our other team in pursuing acquisition and investment opportunities, while cooperating in
creative design, production, and project management tasks. Our in-house production capabilities
include bespoke content such as wax figures, attraction theming and LEGO model production, thereby
creating efficiencies and reducing costs. For example, the castle rooms at our Warwick Castle Resort
contain a variety of exhibits and artefacts, including bespoke wax figures depicting aspects of the
castle’s history that have been produced by our MMM team. Our MMM team’s inputs were also
instrumental in finalizing major projects including the “Jumanji” themed rides and accommodations at
our Gardaland and Chessington World of Adventure Theme Park Resorts and our first Peppa Pig Theme
Park as a Second Gate attraction in close proximity to our LEGOLAND Florida site and the “LEGO
_Ferrari Build and Race” at our LEGOLAND California Resort, as well as for new Midway Attractions_
we recently deployed and our Peppa Pig World of Play sites. We also maintain teams focusing on
developing and monitoring our health, safety and security programmes, with the aim to deliver industry
leading health, safety and security standards, and work closely with our recruiting and training teams,
to ensure our workforce has the right skills to be the best at what they do and fulfil their potential in
their career with us.

Through our in-house capabilities, we are able to develop and run attractions of varying scale, also
managing the related construction processes. In 2022, we completed the construction and opened
LEGOLAND Korea, which is fully owned and operated by us and, as of the date of this Offering
Memorandum, we are developing three LEGOLAND Parks in China in cooperation with local partners.

We also believe that our extensive experience in the leisure and entertainment industry represents an
opportunity for investors to develop joint entertainment offerings. For example, we are developing three
LEGOLAND Parks in China in cooperation with local partners (LEGOLAND Sichuan resort,
LEGOLAND Shanghai resort and LEGOLAND Shenzhen resort).


-----

**_Well-Diversified Portfolio_**

Through our broad portfolio of Attractions, our overall business is diversified across geography,
attraction type, brand and customer demographic. This diversification helps us deliver strong financial
results across a variety of different market conditions and to minimise the impact of external factors,
such as regional economic performance, extreme weather and other external factors. We estimate that
in the 2022 financial year, 77 per cent. of visitors to our Attractions were domestic visitors and 23 per
cent. were international tourists, based on a survey of a sample of our visitors.

As of 1 April 2023, we operate in 24 countries globally, including 15 countries in Europe and North
America and nine countries in the Asia Pacific region, drawing both domestic and international visitors
in each location. In the 53 weeks ended 1 April 2023, the United Kingdom, Continental Europe
(excluding the United Kingdom), North America and the Asia Pacific region accounted for 29 per cent.,
23 per cent., 35 per cent. and 13 per cent. of our revenue, respectively.

Our Attractions range in format from city centre to destination resorts and coastal Attractions, capturing
both the urban and resort-based tourist market and appealing to visitors ranging from families with
young children to teenagers and adults. In addition, on site, themed accommodation has historically
improved guest satisfaction and contributed to our revenue growth. In the 53 weeks ended 31 December
2022, we generated 15 per cent. of our revenue from our accommodation offering (mainly through
overnight stays), 81 per cent. from our visitors (through admissions tickets, retail, food and beverage
sales and other commercial offerings at our Attractions) and 4 per cent. from other sources (mainly
including sponsorships and development contract revenues).

Our Attractions are also partially insulated against extreme weather or seasonal changes through a
mixture of formats, with 45 per cent. of our revenue having been derived from our LEGOLAND Parks
and 22 per cent. of our revenue having been derived from our Resort Theme Parks operations, both of
which are primarily organised around outdoor activities, and 33 per cent. of our revenue having been
derived from our Midway Attractions operating group, which is primarily organised around indoor
activities, in the 53 weeks ended 1 April 2023. In the 53 weeks ended 1 April 2023, 67 per cent. of our
revenue came from outdoor sites, and 33 per cent. from indoor sites. Most of our Attractions are
scheduled to remain open year-round, other than our European Theme Parks, LEGOLAND New York
and LEGOLAND Korea, which tend to be closed during the winter. In the 53 weeks ended 31 December
2022, 58 per cent. of our revenue came from sites that are open all year round.

Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, we had experienced a trend towards increased pre-booked revenues,
leading to reduced volatility in Attraction revenues. This trend continued in the 2022 financial year, as
the global economy recovered from the COVID-19 pandemic. In the 53 weeks ended 31 December
2022, 79 per cent. of total admissions revenue were generated prior to visitation from pre bookings or
annual passes, also resulting in a positive financial contribution to working capital. An increase in pre
bookings adds visibility to cash flows and provides resilience against external factors, such as the impact
of weather.

**_Consistent Financial Track Record with Flexible Cost Base_**

We have a strong financial track record as we recover from the impact of COVID-19, with reported
revenue recovering to £2,006 million in the 2022 financial year, reflecting a growth of 219.1 per cent.
between 2020 and 2022. We have also demonstrated an ability to rapidly recover and improve EBITDA
following periods of macroeconomic volatility, geo-political uncertainty and challenging trading
conditions within our operating groups (including, most recently, as a result of COVID-19). For
example, Adjusted EBITDA grew significantly between 2020 and 2022 from a loss of £102 million to
£692 million.

Our gross margins have been stable, supported by elevated revenue per capita, certain cost saving
initiatives and the outsourcing of certain food & beverage operations. In 2020, building on work that


-----

was already underway, we deployed structural cost saving measures to refine the operating model across
all Attractions, with the aim to create a lower fixed cost and more flexible cost base. Such measures
have partially offset ongoing inflationary headwinds. Staff expenses are the largest portion of costs and
we manage these dynamically by optimising our variable workforce, based on flexible agreements,
multi and cross skilling and rostering tools.

Our marketing spend was significantly reduced in 2020 and 2021 reflecting lower trading levels, but
started to return to more typical levels in 2022.

In addition, while energy contracts we renewed in the second half of 2022 and Q1 2023 have resulted
in significant price increases, utilities costs do not represent a significant portion of our cost base, and
amounted to 3 per cent. of revenues for the 2022 financial year.

**_Prudent Capital Allocation and Flexible Capital Expenditure Spend Resulting in Strong and_**
**_Recurring Cash Flow Generation_**

Our track record of delivering attractive returns from efficient investment is a result of a disciplined
internal focus on investment criteria, return thresholds and hurdles; in house expertise in capital
expenditure efficiency, project delivery, yield and variable cost management; and experience in
maximising the returns from marketing spend.

As part of our capital allocation strategy, we aim to maintain prudent investment practices throughout
our Existing Estate, by leveraging our strong brand portfolio. In addition, we are transforming our
Resort Theme Parks into short break destinations, by strengthening our short break proposition while
diversifying our product offering. We are also expanding our accommodation offering and Second Gate
Attractions footprint, to extend visitation time and increase revenue growth by unlocking cross-selling
opportunities. This has resulted in increases in accommodation revenue and pre-bookings, while
increasing our revenue and cash flow visibility and reduce volatility levels. We also believe that our
diverse offering of themed, on-site accommodation at our Resort Theme Parks further contributes to
the increase in revenues per capita, by enabling greater cross-selling opportunities. Further, our own inhouse Merlin Magic Making team delivers innovative new product ideas including ride concept and
design and wax figure manufacture, and therefore yields synergies and cost savings over third parties
that would otherwise be engaged to develop our Attractions. We also maximise our marketing spend
through targeted campaigns focused on educating prospective customers about new Attractions and
rides. Throughout this process, we take advantage of our market leverage and our scale to maximize
operational, marketing, product and cost synergies. In particular, we implement cost efficiencies such
as shared marketing costs, central management, site development expertise and application of visitor
management experiences across the portfolio. In addition to the benefits we derive from our core
competencies, we maintain our estate through regular planned maintenance capital expenditure, which
means that incremental capital expenditure can be targeted at driving incremental revenue opportunities.

In deploying our capital and planning our investments, we leverage strategic synergies across our three
operating groups, for example by developing “clusters” of Attractions in key locations, and through the
opening of on-site Second Gate attractions. A typical LEGOLAND Park generally requires lower
capital expenditure than a Resort Theme Park, because it is geared towards families with young children
and does not require expensive, large format roller coasters. Our Resort Theme Parks tend to be
nationally pre-eminent in their respective markets and therefore lack the significant competitive
intensity of the theme park operators in the United States. As a result, we do not need to compete solely
on the basis of the latest and largest coasters but can open significant new coasters on an opportunistic
basis. In addition, although not directly comparable to other theme park operators, a typical Midway
Attraction does not require substantial ongoing capital expenditure due to the lack of large scale
coasters, or rides, and the low overall degree of capital employed in each site. Capital expenditure
programmes for the Midway Attractions operating group vary between Attractions, depending on the
size and anticipated growth of the Attraction. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial
_Condition and Results of Operations—Capital Expenditure.” We believe we maintain an efficient_


-----

working capital profile, supported by a high proportion of admissions revenue (79 per cent. in 2022)
being generated prior to visitations from pre-bookings or annual passes.

Capital expenditure across our portfolio of Attractions is primarily funded out of our operating free cash
flow. Our total reported capital expenditure for the 2022 financial year was £195 million, of which £55
million was used for New Business Development, including new Attractions and new accommodations,
which included LEGOLAND Korea, and £140 million was used for our Existing Estate. We maintain
prudent investment practices throughout our Existing Estate, by leveraging our strong brand portfolio.
Our Existing Estate capital expenditure, which covers adding new rides and attractions, replace outdated
features and general maintenance activities, was 12 per cent., 6 per cent. and 7 per cent. of revenue in
the 2020, 2021 and 2022 financial years, respectively. Our successful and flexible capital expenditure
programme has translated into consistently positive cash conversion with operating free cash flow
conversion of 81 per cent. and 79 per cent. in the 2021 and 2022 financial years, respectively.

**_Highly Experienced and Diverse Management Team Backed by Equity Owners with In-depth_**
**_Knowledge of the Company_**

Our senior management team is highly experienced within both the attractions industry and our
businesses, with decades of combined sector experience, supplemented with relevant experience from
outside the attractions industry. See “Management.” Our Chief Executive Officer, Scott M. O’Neil was
appointed in November 2022. Scott has over 25 years of experience in leading and managing global
sports and entertainment brands. Our Chief Financial Officer, Alistair Windybank was appointed in
November 2020. He joined the Group in 2008 and has previously held various senior finance roles
within the Group including Head of Corporate Finance, Group Investor Relations Director, Senior
Finance Director Capital Projects and Deputy Chief Financial Officer. Our senior management team
drives the development and execution of our strategy to deliver growth both organically and through
acquisitions.

Our senior management team is supported by local management teams, which run our operating groups
and Attractions. Each Resort Theme Park, LEGOLAND Park and regional or functional division of the
Midway Attractions operating group has a divisional director, who is supported by a management team
and who reports directly to the relevant operating group managing director. This decentralised
management structure empowers site management to make commercial and operational decisions
locally, enabling real time reaction to local market conditions. Our senior management team is also
supported by the Merlin Magic Making team, which is our unique, creative and project management
resource. Merlin Magic Making also provides creative design and production. Our strong local
management teams are often a result of our culture of training and development, with central and local
programmes to develop skills at all levels of the organisation. The commitment of our employees is
best demonstrated by the results of the 2022 annual staff survey. More than 18,000 employees
completed the survey, a response rate of 84 per cent. Our employee engagement is one of our key
performance indicators measuring whether our teams think we are a “great place to perform,” “a great
_place for customers” and a “great place to work.” In 2022, our engagement was 68 per cent. favourable,_
an encouraging increase of 5 per cent. compared to 2021.

We also enjoy strong shareholder support and commitment, by highly experienced through-cycle
investors contributing substantial governance and oversight. Since 2019, we have been controlled by a
consortium of three principal long-term investors with the capability to support our growth ambitions.
These investors are KIRKBI, Blackstone and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPP
Investments). Blackstone had previously been our majority shareholder since a management backed
buy out investment in 2005. At the same time, we acquired rights to LEGOLAND Parks from KIRKBI
A/S, who signed the licensing and co-operation agreement with us, and KIRKBI became one of our
shareholders. See “Business—History—Our Relationship with the KIRKBI Group.” Blackstone and
KIRKBI continued to jointly control Merlin for eight years from 2005 to 2013, during which period we
successfully grew, with a revenue CAGR of 12.5 per cent. from 2008 to 2013, to become the second
largest theme park operator globally by number of visitors in 2019. Blackstone has longstanding


-----

experience investing in the visitor attractions industry as well as the broader hospitality, travel and
leisure sectors. Blackstone’s previous investments include Merlin Entertainments, SeaWorld, Six Flags,
Universal Orlando, Center Parcs, Hilton Hotels and The Cosmopolitan Hotel.

**Our Strategy**

**_Existing Estate Growth Driven by Access to Powerful Intellectual Property_**

We believe in the growth of our Existing Estate, to strengthen our global position and improve our offer
to all our visitors. We continue to invest in our existing Attractions to grow demand, increase capacity
and to refresh and improve the visitor experience, which we believe is a key driver for increased visitor
numbers and revenue growth. We also aim to fully unlock the benefits of combining our brand
experience with the strength of our Attractions portfolio, and are driven by a constant focus to refresh
and retool our portfolio to maintain and expand our attractiveness. While we strive to improve our
product appeal, maintain our high levels of customer satisfaction and drive organic growth, we also
have developed prudent investment practices. Investments are planned well in advance, where possible,
according to the forecasted potential returns and the capital requirements of the respective Attraction,
operating groups and location. Existing Estate capital expenditure is divided between adding new rides
or displays and enhancements to our Attractions, replacing old features with newer, more compelling
ones and general maintenance, including ensuring health and safety standards are met or exceeded. Our
capital expenditure practices are designed to develop the product portfolio over time so as to increase
visitor numbers and visitors’ length of stay and to support value added increases in admissions fee prices
and commercial spend, thereby delivering growth in revenue and profitability.

We are increasingly able to develop these investments in partnership with leading intellectual property
owners to provide an immersive, themed experience for our visitors. For example, in 2022 we opened
a “JUMANJI — The Adventure” ride and, in 2023, a “JUMANJI: The Labyrinth” ride in our Gardaland
Theme Resort, as part of our multi-territory exclusivity agreement with Sony Pictures Entertainment, to
develop and operate attractions, rides, lands, retail outlets and themed hotel rooms based on the studio’s
“Jumanji” film franchise. In 2023, we have also opened a “World of Jumanji” themed land at our
Chessington Theme Park Resort, along with Jumanji-themed rooms at the local resort hotel, and plan
to open a Jumanji themed rollercoaster in 2023. In addition, in May 2022 we opened “LEGO Ferrari
_Build and Race” at our LEGOLAND California Resort. Featuring a life-size LEGO Ferrari F40 model,_
this interactive attraction aims offer visitors a full “in the driver’s seat” experience, by allowing to build,
test and race LEGO Ferrari models.

In addition to major rides and developments, we also make smaller investments at most Attractions to
support a continually refreshed marketing message and sustained level of visitor satisfaction such as the
Warner Bros. Icons of Horror attraction at Madame Tussauds New York or Rainforest Adventure at
SEA LIFE London Aquarium. We intend to continue maintaining the existing standards of general
maintenance and commitments to ensure health and safety standards and making strategic, value
accretive investments in our Existing Estate and in respect of New Business Development to maintain
and strengthen our leading positions in the industry in which we operate.

In addition, we aim to keep a committed workforce by remaining a great place to work, with high levels
of employee engagement. We believe our employee satisfaction is also driven by our rigid health, safety
and security programmes (based on our “Protecting the Magic” vision), our commitment towards the
environment and animal welfare and our strong focus on developing our front-line team (including
through career acceleration opportunities).

**_Evolution of Theme Parks to Destination Resorts_**

We aim to enhance our operational excellence, by unlocking value across our pricing, data and retail
strategies. We continue to transform our Theme Parks into destination resorts, extending visitor market
reach and enhancing revenues from a number of sales channels. These include primary admissions


-----

(including multi-day tickets and second gate admission fees), and commercial spend such as the sale of
food and beverages, retail merchandise, and souvenirs such as photos.

In addition, the themed accommodation offerings in our hotels and holiday villages continue to be very
successful. We believe these provide an integral contribution to the overall visitor experience, helping
to drive pre-bookings, increase multi-day ticket sales and improve guest satisfaction.

We are developing and plan to open in May 2024 a LEGOLAND Woodland Village, the UK’s first
LEGO themed holiday village, at LEGOLAND Windsor Resort. LEGOLAND Woodland Village will
feature 150 lodges, an on-site restaurant, and a family entertainment hub.

We also intend to benefit from ongoing opportunities to add new visitor attractions at our theme parks,
for which additional admission fees are charged. These attractions, such as waterparks, are referred to
as Second Gate attractions.

As of 1 April 2023, we offered a total of 5,342 rooms across our Theme Parks, including themed on-site
accommodation at all LEGOLAND Parks. In addition, our Heide Park, Warwick Castle and Alton
Towers resorts, along with our LEGOLAND Deutschland, LEGOLAND Billund, and LEGOLAND
Florida parks each include a holiday village, ranging from 65 to 367 rooms. We believe these hotels
and holiday villages provide an integral contribution to the overall customer experience, help drive
pre-booking, increase multi-day ticket sales and improve guest satisfaction. We believe that this
destination positioning has already extended visitor market reach to over five hours drive time and has
enhanced revenues from both primary admissions, including multi-day tickets and second gate
admission fees, and commercial spend. The latter is typically comprised of the sale of food and
beverages, merchandise and souvenirs as a result of longer average lengths of stay.

**_Clustering of Midway Attractions_**

Our growth strategy includes the opening of our chainable Midway attractions in new locations and
countries including key gateway cities, often creating ‘clusters’, where multiple attractions are
developed in one location. We have developed “clusters” of Midway Attractions in Amsterdam,
Arizona, Bangkok, Berlin, Birmingham, Blackpool, Dallas, Istanbul, Kansas City, London,
Manchester, Melbourne, Michigan, New Jersey, Oberhausen, Orlando, San Antonio, Shanghai, Sydney
and Tokyo, where multiple Attractions are situated in one city or region to capitalise on strong cross
promotional and operational synergies, including multi-attraction tickets to drive cross selling. For
example, in 2022, we opened a Peppa Pig World of Play Attraction in Leidschendam (the Netherlands),
a LEGO Discovery Centre in Brussels (Belgium) and have taken over the management contract of
Amsterdam’s THIS IS HOLLAND flying theatre experience, thereby expanding our local cluster of
attractions.

**_LEGOLAND Park Developments_**

We aim to fully unleash the potential of our LEGOLAND Parks footprint, leveraging on our proven
track record of developing and operating LEGOLAND Parks globally. We opened new LEGOLAND
Parks in Florida in 2011, in Malaysia in 2012, in Dubai in 2016, in Nagoya, Japan in 2017, in New York
in 2021 and in South Korea in 2022. LEGOLAND Malaysia and LEGOLAND Dubai are operated
under management contracts. In addition, we are also developing three LEGOLAND Parks in China in
cooperation with local partners. Each of LEGOLAND Sichuan resort, LEGOLAND Shanghai resort
and LEGOLAND Shenzhen resort is expected to open during or after 2025. All three will be operated
under a management contract model.

We have three operating and investment models with respect to the development of LEGOLAND Parks.

Firstly, in more proven locations, we follow an “owned and operated” model. Under this approach, we
make the necessary capital investment to secure the land and develop the infrastructure ourselves. We


-----

have used this model in our European and North American LEGOLAND Parks as well as for
LEGOLAND Korea (which has been developed under this model with support from local authorities).

Secondly, we work with a local partner, marrying their capabilities and expertise with our strengths and
experience to both parties’ mutual benefit. Typically, the funding for the capital investment is provided
by a third party and we operate the park under a management contract. We do not own the park but
instead operate it pursuant to a development and management contract with our partners. We operate
LEGOLAND Malaysia under this model. The Malaysian government provided the funds to develop
LEGOLAND Malaysia. We own a 20 per cent. interest in the company that owns LEGOLAND
Malaysia. LEGOLAND Dubai is operated under a similar management contract model, whereby LL
Dubai Theme Park LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of DXB Entertainments, owns the assets and we
operate the park. We do not have an equity interest in LEGOLAND Dubai but hold a 40 per cent.,
equity interest in LL Dubai Hotel LLC, the company that developed the hotel at LEGOLAND Dubai
(opened in 2022) and owns the hotel’s premises. See “Business—Material Contracts.”

Third, we can operate parks under a “leased and operated” model. Under this approach, the acquisition
of the park site, the development of the infrastructure and the basic construction is funded by a third
party partner. We fund and build the rides and the necessary theming, lease the site on a long-term basis,
and operate the LEGOLAND Park. LEGOLAND Japan, for example, was developed using this
approach with a subsidiary of KIRKBI as the lessor.

**_Acquisitions and New Format Opportunities_**

We continue to consider acquisitions of, or investments in, visitor attractions, sites and brands that could
strategically enhance our portfolio and enable us to grow into new geographies, and reallocate our
capital expenditure accordingly. Over the course of our operating history, we have demonstrated a track
record of identifying, implementing and integrating both large and small acquisitions and delivering
significant value uplift through improving acquired operations, while maintaining a standard level of
excellence across our estate. We believe that there remain further attractive acquisition opportunities
that would meet our investment criteria in the future.

In 2022 we completed the acquisition of the COEX Aquarium in Seoul, South Korea, adding a further
significant attraction to the SEA LIFE portfolio, and consistent with our wider strategy to build clusters
of Midway indoor attractions in key gateway cities.

In 2022, we also acquired the operations and brand licence of Cadbury World (a popular attraction in
the UK) pursuant to an exclusive partnership with Mondelēz International, thereby deepening our
relationship with a leading UK chocolate brand. As part of the agreement, we will be responsible for
the day-to-day running of the Cadbury World site, its employees, and all operational decisions, as well
as holding brand usage rights for Cadbury World in the UK. The Cadbury World attraction has been
added to our Midway Attractions portfolio.

We also develop new formats of attraction, where currently our focus is on Peppa Pig branded
attractions aimed at pre-school children. We have opened five pilot indoor Peppa Pig World of Play
attractions, and one standalone Peppa Pig theme park that opened next to LEGOLAND Florida Resort
in early 2022. We plan to open our second Peppa Pig theme park in the Dallas-Fort Worth area in 2024.

**_Potential Financing Transactions_**

We continually evaluate different financing alternatives and may decide to enter into new credit
facilities, access the debt capital markets (including by tapping the Notes offered hereby) or incur other
indebtedness or enter into liability management transactions from time to time, including following the
pricing of this Offering and prior to, or within a short time period following, the Issue Date (the
“Potential Financing Transactions”). The cash proceeds of any Potential Financing Transactions may
be used to refinance indebtedness or for general corporate purposes. The issuance of indebtedness under
any such Potential Financing Transactions would be incurred in compliance with the applicable
covenants under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing 2026 Indenture, the Existing Senior
Notes Indenture and the Indenture. Any Potential Financing Transaction will be made at our election or
the election of our relevant subsidiaries, and, if such debt is in the form of securities, such debt would
be offered and sold pursuant to, and on the terms described in, a separate offering memorandum or
liability management document. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Structure—
_We may incur additional indebtedness prior to, or within a short time period following, the Issue Date_
_of the Notes, which indebtedness could increase our leverage and may have terms that are more or less_
_favourable than the terms of the Notes and our other existing indebtedness.”_

**The Issuer**

The Issuer is a private limited liability company (société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under
the laws of Luxembourg and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register with
registration number B234977. The address of its registered office is 2 4 rue Eugène Ruppert, L 2453
Luxembourg. The Issuer has no material assets, other than derivative assets to hedge certain interest
rate exposures arising from debt issued by the Issuer, equity interests in, and/or intercompany balances
with, other subsidiaries or affiliates of the Group. The Issuer has no revenue generating activities of its
own and no business operations. The Issuer is indirectly controlled, through wholly owned holding
company subsidiaries, by the Consortium, comprising long-term capital providers with substantial
equity capital of £2.9 billion invested in the Group in the context of the Acquisition. A further £150
million of equity was contributed to the Group by The Wellcome Trust as a minority investment in
2020.

**The Consortium**

Topco is controlled by the Consortium, with Blackstone indirectly holding approximately 31.99 per
cent., CPP Investments indirectly holding approximately 15.50 per cent. and KIRKBI indirectly owning
47.49 per cent. of the share capital of JVco. For a description of our shareholders’ agreement, see
“Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Shareholders’ Agreement.”

**_Blackstone_**

Blackstone is one of the world’s largest alternative asset managers with $991 billion in assets under
management as at 31 March 2023. Blackstone seeks to create positive economic impact and long-term
value for investors, the companies in which it invests and the communities in which it works. Blackstone
has longstanding experience investing in the location-based entertainments businesses like ours, as well
as the wider hospitality, travel and leisure sectors. Blackstone’s previous investments include Merlin


-----

Entertainments, SeaWorld, Six Flags, Universal Orlando, Center Parcs, Hilton Hotels and The
Cosmopolitan Hotel. Blackstone’s investment in us has been made through its long-dated Core Private
Equity fund, which invests in high quality businesses and has the flexibility to hold assets for a longer
duration than traditional private equity funds.

**_CPP Investments_**

CPP Investments is a professional investment management organisation that manages the Canada
Pension Plan in the best interests of its 21 million contributors and beneficiaries. In order to build a
diversified portfolio, CPP Investments invests in public equities, private equities, real estate,
infrastructure and fixed income instruments.

As of 31 December 2022, CPP Investments’ assets under management totalled C$536 billion, including
approximately C$25 billion of assets invested in the United Kingdom, and net investments of C$146
billion in private equity. CPP Investments’ private equity team is a committed long-term investor with
permanent capital, a focus on sizeable investments alongside aligned partners, the ability to invest
across the full spectrum of ownership, and the ability to shape the duration and underwriting approach
of investments to support longer-date returns on investment initiatives.

**KIRKBI**

KIRKBI A/S is the Kirk Kristiansen family’s private holding and investment company founded to build
a sustainable future for the family ownership of the LEGO brand through generations. KIRKBI’s work
is focused on three fundamental tasks all contributing to enabling the Kirk Kristiansen family to succeed
with the mission to inspire and develop the builders of tomorrow. KIRKBI works to protect, develop,
and leverage the LEGO brand across all the LEGO branded entities. KIRKBI is committed to a longterm and responsible investment strategy to ensure a sound financial foundation for the owner family’s
activities as well as contributing to sustainable development in the world. KIRKBI is dedicated to
support the family members as they prepare for future generations to continue the active and engaged
ownership as well as supporting their private activities, companies, and philanthropic work. KIRKBI’s
investment activities include investments in energy transition, circular plastic and significant long-term
investments in listed and privately held companies as well as real estate investments in Denmark,
Switzerland, Germany and the UK.

(1) The Consortium indirectly controls (through wholly owned intermediate holding companies) MAL, with Blackstone indirectly holding

approximately 31.99 per cent., CPP Investments indirectly holding approximately 15.50 per cent. and KIRKBI indirectly owning 47.59
per cent. of share capital in JVco. In addition, approximately 5 per cent. is indirectly held by The Wellcome Trust.

(2) JVco, Topco and Midco were incorporated as holding companies for the purpose of the Acquisition and the Senior Notes Issuer was

incorporated for purposes of issuing the Existing Senior Notes in connection with the financing of the Acquisition. None of these
companies have independent business operations, or have any significant assets (except, in the case of the Senior Notes Issuer and Midco
their interests in certain intercompany loans), other than the equity interest each of these companies holds in its subsidiaries. The
restrictive covenants in the Indenture will only apply to MAL and its subsidiaries. In 2021, we introduced our Management Incentive
Plans, which allowed eligible employees to invest in the Group on customary terms and conditions. Pursuant to the Management Share
Incentive Plans, we issued preference shares and ordinary shares in our subsidiary Topco to senior management in exchange for
consideration. See “Management—Management Share Incentive Plans.”

(3) The Issuer is offering €650.0 million in aggregate principal amount of its % senior secured notes due 2030. On or about the Issue

Date, the proceeds of the Offering will be used, together with cash on balance sheet: (i) to redeem the Issuer’s €500 million Senior
Secured Notes due 2025 (the “2025 Notes”), including paying the redemption premium thereon and accrued and unpaid interest to the
date of the redemption (the “Refinancing” and together with the Offering, the “Transactions”), (ii) maintain cash on balance sheet to
repay, redeem, repurchase (including from the open-market) or address maturities of, our other secured indebtedness, and (iii) to pay the
fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.”


-----

(4) The Notes will be general obligations of the Issuer and will, upon issuance, (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s

existing and future obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Issuer’s guarantee of the Existing
2026 Notes and its obligations under the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations, (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all
existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Issuer’s
obligations under its guarantee of the Existing Senior Notes, (iii) be effectively subordinated to all future obligations of the Issuer that
are secured by property and assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such
obligations, (iv) be structurally subordinated to all obligations of MAL’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes (other than the
Issuer), (v) be guaranteed on a senior basis by MAL and the Subsidiary Guarantors, subject to limitations under applicable law, and (vi)
be secured as set forth under “Description of Notes—Security.”

(5) The Notes will be guaranteed on the Issue Date by the Parent Guarantor and the Subsidiary Guarantors. The Parent Guarantee granted

by MAL will be a general, senior obligation of MAL and will (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with all existing and future senior
obligations of MAL that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Parent Guarantee, including MAL’s obligations under the Senior
Facilities, certain hedging obligations and the Existing 2026 Notes (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all existing and future
obligations of MAL that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Parent Guarantee, including MAL’s obligations under its
guarantee of the Existing Senior Notes, (iii) be effectively subordinated to all existing and future obligations of MAL that are secured
by property and assets that do not secure the Notes to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations, (iv) be
structurally subordinated to all existing and future obligations of MAL’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee or issue the Notes and (v) be
secured as set forth under “Description of Notes—Security.” Each Guarantee granted by the Subsidiary Guarantors will be a general,
senior obligation of the relevant Subsidiary Guarantor and will (i) rank pari passu in right of payment to all existing and future senior
obligations of such Subsidiary Guarantor (including such Subsidiary Guarantor’s obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement,
certain hedging obligations and obligations under the Existing 2026 Notes), (ii) rank senior in right of payment with all existing and
future obligations of such Subsidiary Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Subsidiary Guarantor’s
Guarantee, including such Subsidiary Guarantor’s obligations under its guarantee of the Existing Senior Notes (iii) be effectively
subordinated to all existing and future secured obligations of such Subsidiary Guarantor that are secured by property and assets that do
not secure the Notes to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations, (v) be structurally subordinated to all
existing and future obligations of the subsidiaries of such Subsidiary Guarantor that do not guarantee the Notes and (vi) be secured as
set forth under “Description of Notes—Security.” During the 53 weeks ended 1 April 2023, the Guarantors accounted for 79 per cent. of
the consolidated revenue and 81 per cent. of the consolidated EBITDA of the Group, and as of 1 April 2023, the Guarantors accounted
for 63 per cent. of the consolidated assets (excluding brand values, goodwill, minority equity investments and investments in wholly
owned subsidiaries) of the Group. See “Description of Notes—The Guarantees.”

(6) Within 30 days from the Issue Date, the Notes and the Guarantees will be secured on a first priority basis by the Senior Security that

also secures the Existing 2026 Notes, the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations on a first priority basis. the Notes and the
Guarantees will be further secured on a first priority basis by the Shared Collateral that also secures the Existing 2026 Notes, the Senior
Facilities and certain hedging obligations on a first priority basis and the Existing Senior Notes on a second priority basis. The validity
and enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain
limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and
_Security.” The security interests in favour of the Notes and the Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances._

(7) In connection with the financing for the Acquisition, the Issuer and the U.S. Co Borrower entered into the Senior Facilities Agreement.

In addition to certain term loan facilities, the Senior Facilities provide for borrowings of up to £400 million (equivalent) under the
Revolving Facility. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Revolving Facility was undrawn by way of cash loans while £30
million has been utilized by way of certain ancillary facilities, including letters of credit. See “Capitalisation” and “Description of
_Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”_

(8) On 9 May 2018, MEL issued $400 million aggregate principal amount of 5[3]/4% Senior Notes due 2026 (the “Existing 2026 Notes”)

pursuant to the Existing 2026 Indenture. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Existing 2026 Notes.” Security interests
equal and rateable to those granted in favour of obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement were granted in favour of the Existing
2026 Notes following the Acquisition.

(1) EBITDA is defined as profit before finance income and costs, taxation, depreciation, amortisation and impairment and is after taking

account of attributable profit after tax of jointly controlled entities. Adjusted EBITDA is defined as profit before finance income and
costs, taxation, depreciation, amortisation and impairment, share-based payments under the Management Share Incentive Plans and
exceptional items and is after taking account of attributable profit after tax of joint controlled entities. Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16),
as used in this Offering Memorandum, represents Adjusted EBITDA less adjustments made to exclude the impact of the application of
IFRS 16 to Adjusted EBITDA. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) do not reflect any weighted foreign
exchange rate adjustments.

These adjustments are based upon various assumptions, forecasts and management estimates and are in part based upon historical
information. This information does not represent the results we would have achieved had each of the adjustments occurred and been
fully implemented on the first day of the relevant financial period. These numbers have not been, and cannot be, audited, reviewed or
verified by an independent accounting firm. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. It may not be comparable
to our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum and should not be
relied upon when making an investment decision. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) are included in
this Offering Memorandum because we believe they are helpful to investors as measures of our operating performance and ability to
service our debt. These measures are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered in isolation
or as an alternative to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived in
accordance with IFRS. Other companies, including those in our industry, may calculate similarly titled financial measures differently
from us, and so the presentation of such financial measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies.
See “Presentation of Financial Information.” Funds depicted by certain of these measures may not be available for management’s
discretionary use due to covenant restrictions, debt service payments or other commitments.
