Global Notes representing the Notes will be made to the relevant paying agent, which will make
payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, these payments will be credited to participants’
accounts that hold book entry interests in the Global Notes representing the Notes and credited by such
participants to indirect participants. After payment to the common depositary for Euroclear and
Clearstream, the Issuer will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest, principal or
other amounts to the owners of book entry interests. Accordingly, if investors own a book entry interest,
they must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and if investors are not participants in
Euroclear and Clearstream, they must rely on the procedures of the participant through which they own
their interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of Notes under the Indenture.

Unlike the holders of the Notes themselves, owners of book entry interests will not have the direct right
to act upon the Issuer’s solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of
the Notes. Instead, if an investor owns a book entry interest, it will be permitted to act only to the extent
it has received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream. The procedures
implemented for the granting of such proxies may not be sufficient to enable such investor to vote on a
timely basis.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until Definitive
Registered Notes (as defined herein) are issued in respect of all book entry interests, if investors own
book entry interests, they will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. The procedures
to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream may not be adequate to ensure the timely exercise
of rights under the Notes.

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may_**
**_be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time._**

One or more independent credit rating agencies have assigned and may in the future assign credit ratings
to the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market,
additional risk factors discussed above and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit
rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension
or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will
remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn
entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A
suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or
more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our
financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

In the event that the Notes are redeemed early in accordance with “Description of Notes—Optional

The Notes will be denominated and payable in euro. An investment in the Notes denominated in a

**Overview**

We are a global leader in branded, location-based family entertainment. As of 1 April 2023, we operated
141 Attractions, 24 hotels and 6 holiday villages in 24 countries across four continents, and in the 53
weeks ended 31 December 2022, we welcomed approximately 56 million visitors to our Attractions.
We were the second largest theme park operator globally by number of visitors in 2019, according to
TEA/AECOM. We also own eight of Europe’s largest 20 theme parks by number of visitors as of 2021.
We believe we are a market leader in the United Kingdom, Northern Germany and Italy, based on total
visitor numbers in 2021 to Europe’s top 20 theme parks, with an already significant and growing
presence in the United States and the Asia Pacific region. We believe we own and/or operate a unique
portfolio of chainable iconic assets and brands, possessing strong heritage within their original markets,
as well as being globally scalable and supported by our extensive technical and creative expertise.

Our vision is to establish ourselves as the global leader in location-based entertainment. To this end, we
consider our main purpose to deliver memorable experiences to all our visitors, while maintaining a
strategy aimed at creating a high growth, high return, family entertainment business, naturally balanced
against the pressures of the macroeconomic environment in which we operate. We possess a unique
portfolio of family entertainment brands and iconic assets, which are highly diversified across
geography, attraction type, brand and customer demographic and well balanced between indoor and
outdoor Attractions and international and domestic visitation (with international and domestic visitation
measured relative to the relevant Attraction). We believe our footprint across 24 countries provides us
with a favourable platform to benefit from global growth in spending on travel and tourism, which
according to the WTTC, is forecast to increase by a CAGR of 5.1 per cent. per annum between 2023


-----

and 2033 (from $9.5 trillion to $15.5 trillion), by allowing us to attract both international tourists and
domestic visitors, and providing us with a buffer in the event of macroeconomic and currency risks.
Our operating groups offer our visitors diverse entertainment options, including both indoor Attractions
within city centres as well as outdoor theme parks offering multi day visits. In the 53 weeks ended 1
April 2023, 45 per cent. of our revenue was derived from our LEGOLAND Parks and 22 per cent. of
our revenue was derived from our Resort Theme Parks operations, which are primarily organised around
outdoor activities, and 33 per cent. of our revenue was derived from our Midway Attractions operating
group, which is primarily organised around indoor activities, providing a natural hedge against weather
disruptions.

We have established a diverse portfolio of nationally and internationally recognised premium brands
focused on delivering memorable experiences to millions of visitors around the world. We generated
revenue of £2,084 million, Adjusted EBITDA of £717 million, Adjusted EBITDA (pre-IFRS 16) of
£601 million and profit before tax of £126 million in the 53 weeks ended 1 April 2023.

**Factors Affecting our Results of Operations**

**_Admissions_**

Visitor attendance levels are the primary driver of our revenue and one of the primary drivers of our
profitability. From 2020 to 2022, visitor attendance grew by a CAGR of 57.9 per cent., while from 2019
to 2022 visitor attendance grew by a CAGR of (6.3) per cent. (primarily as a result of the impact of
COVID-19 and related restrictions on the number of our visitors in 2020, compared to 2019 (which was
unaffected by COVID-19)). Most of our revenue is generated by visitors through admission fees and
commercial spend such as on food and beverages and retail opportunities.

For the 2022 financial year, visitor revenue, accommodation revenue and other revenue constituted 81
per cent., 15 per cent. and 4 per cent. of our total revenue, respectively.

Visitor attendance has historically been primarily driven by, and dependent upon, the appeal of our
Attractions, and we believe that the sustainability of visitor attendance at the Attractions is contingent
upon maintaining high visitor satisfaction levels. We measure visitor satisfaction through monitoring
guest feedback on a daily basis by both local and central monitoring teams. This process assists
management in pricing and directing capital investment and resources to improve our product offering,
including through updating and refreshing the Attractions on a regular basis. We target an overall
satisfaction level of over 90 per cent. at each of the Attractions, and most of our Attractions consistently
achieve scores above 90 per cent. Our average guest satisfaction score across our group in 2022
remained stable at 94 per cent., compared to a score of 94 per cent. in 2021. We also monitor the
propensity for our guests to recommend our Attractions, having received a “Net Promoter” score (which
measures the propensity for our guests to recommend our Attractions) of over 50 per cent. in the 2022
financial year.

Visitor attendance is also impacted by our pricing and marketing strategies. The effectiveness of these
strategies is dependent upon their alignment with the appropriate target audience, which requires
management to implement and deliver brand clarity in respect of each Attraction’s proposition. Visitor
attendance is also influenced by economic conditions, conditions of the tourism industry and external
factors beyond our control.

The factors affecting growth in visitor attendance may vary amongst our operating groups. We believe
the evolution in visitor attendance during the periods under review for the Midway Attractions,
LEGOLAND Parks and Resort Theme Parks operating groups has been driven largely by the negative
impact of COVID-19 related closures and restrictions in the 2020 financial year, while visitor
attendance in the 2021 financial year began to recover, benefiting from a rebound in customer demand
primarily as a result of COVID-19 restrictions easing. While a portion of our brands and certain
geographies where we operate were still impacted by COVID-19 restrictions in 2022, overall visitation


-----

and revenue continued to rise versus the prior periods as a result of robust consumer demand, elevated
revenues per visitor and the continued recovery in international tourism supporting strong trading in
North America, the United Kingdom and parts of Continental Europe. As a result, we recorded an
increase in revenue per customer in 2022, which was also driven by our enhanced revenue management,
and focus on a flexible and lower-cost operating model.

Visitor attendance at the Midway Attractions operating group increased by 32 per cent. from 2020 to
2021 as a result of a strong recovery from the impact of COVID-19 mandated restrictions and
lockdowns and renewed customer demand. During the 2021 financial year, we recorded positive
visitation at regional and coastal Midway attractions primarily focused on resident markets, such as our
regional LEGOLAND Discovery Centre and our SEA LIFE Centre attractions. At the same time, we
recorded a slower recovery in gateway city locations (such as London and New York) which usually
rely on a significant element of international tourist visitation and in Midway Attractions located in
regions impacted by continuing COVID-19 restrictions. In addition, visitor attendance has been
positively impacted by the opening of eight new Midway Attractions in 2021, which were all delayed
openings originally scheduled for 2020 (such Attractions included four LEGOLAND Discovery
Centres in the United States, one Madame Tussauds in Dubai, two SEA LIFE Centres in the United
States, and one Peppa Pig World of Play in the United States). Visitor attendance at our LEGOLAND
Parks also increased significantly by 90 per cent. over the same period, primarily driven by the opening
of LEGOLAND New York, with LEGOLAND Florida remaining open throughout 2021 and
LEGOLAND California and LEGOLAND Windsor recording a strong recovery in demand following
their reopening in April 2021 and the second quarter of 2021, respectively. Visitor attendance also grew
significantly at our Resort Theme Parks, as COVID-19 restrictions were lifted across Continental
Europe and the UK between the first and the second quarter of 2021, thereby enabling our sites to trade
during the main summer trading season.

Visitor attendance at the Midway Attractions operating group increased significantly by 71 per cent.
from 2021 to 2022 primarily due to continuing recovery in domestic customer demand from the impact
of COVID-19, which was supported by a steady recovery in international tourism that benefited
primarily our Attractions in gateway locations. In addition, visitor attendance has been positively
impacted by the opening of two new Midway Attractions in 2022, which included one Peppa Pig World
of Play in the Netherlands and one LEGO Discovery Centre in Belgium, as well as by the acquisition
of the COEX Aquarium in Seoul, which has been added to our SEA LIFE portfolio of Attractions. This
recorded growth was partly offset by COVID-19 related restrictions and lockdowns being still in place
in the Asia-Pacific region (particularly in China). Visitor attendance at our LEGOLAND Parks
increased by 71 per cent. during this time due to customer demand at our LEGOLAND Florida and
California resorts, with total visitor attendance at our LEGOLAND Florida Resort growing ahead of
2019 visitation figures in part due to the opening of the adjacent standalone Peppa Pig Theme Park as
a Second Gate attraction. Visitor attendance for the Resort Theme Parks increased by 28 per cent. from
2021 to 2022, due to the unhindered opening of all of our locations in the spring, thereby allowing a
full year of trading. In addition, visitor attendance at our Resort Theme Parks was positively impacted
by the combination of robust domestic demand in each location and a recovery in international tourist
visitation. For example, our Gardaland resort benefited from a rebound in domestic Italian demand


-----

combined with increased tourist flows from nearby countries, including Germany. Over the same
period, performance at our UK theme parks and our Heide park resort was mainly driven by domestic
demand. On a local level, our Gardaland resort (Italy) also benefited from the opening of the new
“JUMANJI — The Adventure” ride.

Visitor numbers, as used in this Offering Memorandum, represent the number of individual visits to an
Attraction, as measured by our admissions systems, for the period indicated. Unless otherwise specified,
visitor numbers include visitors to Attractions operated under management contracts (which, during the
periods under review, included LEGOLAND Malaysia, LEGOLAND Dubai and the recently acquired
THIS IS HOLLAND attraction in the Netherlands), in respect of which we earn revenues through
management fees rather than directly through visitor admission fees and visitors to Attractions operated
as joint ventures, which, during a portion of the periods under review, included the hotel at LEGOLAND
Dubai which opened in 2022.

**_Management of Capital Investments_**

Our success is dependent upon the appeal of the Attractions, which impacts visitor attendance and our
results of operations. Maintaining the appeal of our Attractions requires prudent capital investment in
both our Existing Estate as well as in connection with New Business Development.

In the 2022 financial year, total capital expenditure amounted to £195 million, of which £140 million
related to Existing Estate capital expenditure. See “—Capital Expenditure.”

_Existing Estate_

Part of our growth strategy is to make targeted investments to update and refresh our Existing Estate on
a regular basis. We seek to achieve this through both operating and capital expenditures that are intended
to improve product appeal and guest experience, which are key to increasing visitor attendance levels
and length of stay with the aim to improve overall guest satisfaction. Such investments include (i)
adding new rides and Attractions and improving food and beverage facilities and retail offerings, (ii)
replacing old features with new, more up to date features and (iii) general maintenance of existing
Attractions, including ensuring health and safety standards are met or exceeded.

Such investment supports increases in admission fees and commercial spend and helps drive our
revenue growth and profitability. For example, accommodation not only continues to increase the
duration of our visitors’ stay, allowing greater cross-selling opportunities and driving improved levels
of guest satisfaction, but also leads to increases in pre bookings, revenue visibility and positive working
capital. We also make capital investments to improve back office and IT efficiency. In addition, we are
increasingly deploying investments in our Existing Estate on projects developed in cooperation with
leading intellectual property owners.

The percentage of revenue invested in Existing Estate capital expenditure varies by operating group.
Midway Attractions require relatively lower capital expenditure due to the smaller scale of the
Attractions and the higher proportion of first-time tourist visitors while Resort Theme Parks, and to a
lesser extent LEGOLAND Parks, which target a younger age range than Resort Theme Parks, require
relatively higher capital expenditure due to the development of new rides and Attractions of significant
scale and the drive to attract repeat visitors.

We establish targeted returns for all capital expenditure incurred in respect of projects expected to make
a positive contribution to EBITDA, and we build these targeted returns into our annual budgets. While
it is not possible to accurately ascertain returns for individual investments, we believe that the launch
of new features at the Attractions following capital investments are a key contributing factor in
increasing visitor attendance numbers, particularly during the year of launch.

In the 2022 financial year, our significant capital investments in the Resort Theme Parks included the
opening of the “JUMANJI — The Adventure” ride at our Gardaland Resort in Italy, pursuant to a multi

-----

territory exclusivity agreement with Sony Pictures Entertainment. In the Midway Attractions operating
group, we made significant capital investments including the acquisition of the COEX Aquarium in
Seoul, which has been added to our SEA LIFE portfolio consistently with our strategy to enhance
clusters of indoor Midway Attractions in key gateway cities. In December 2022 we also acquired the
operations and brand licence of Cadbury World (a popular attraction in the UK) pursuant to an exclusive
partnership with Mondelēz International, thereby deepening our relationship with a leading UK
chocolate brand. As part of the agreement, we will be responsible for the day-to-day running of the
Cadbury World site, its employees, and all operational decisions, as well as holding brand usage rights
for Cadbury World.

In the 2021 financial year, we made significant capital investments in the Midway Attractions operating
group, which included two SEA LIFE centres located in San Antonio and New Jersey in the USA, one
Madame Tussauds attraction in Dubai and one Peppa Pig World of Play in Chicago. Over the same
period, with respect to the LEGOLAND Parks, we have made significant investments in new
Attractions such as the LEGOLAND Korea and LEGOLAND New York parks.

In the 2020 financial year, we made significant capital investments in the development new
LEGOLAND parks, specifically LEGOLAND New York and LEGOLAND Korea.

Our Existing Estate capital expenditure was 12 per cent., 6 per cent. and 7 per cent. of revenue in the
2020, 2021 and 2022 financial years, respectively. We generally fund our Existing Estate capital
expenditure from our operating free cash flow and we expect to continue to do so going forward.

In respect of the Midway Attractions, we aim to consistently update and refresh our entertainment
offerings through the rotation of themed exhibitions across the SEA LIFE Centres; the annual addition
of new wax figures at each Madame Tussauds Attraction; the addition of a new ride, feature or new 4
D film at each LEGOLAND Discovery Centre approximately once every five years; and the regular
introduction of new story lines at The Dungeons sites. Additionally, we expect to periodically undertake
a refurbishment of the capsules of the London Eye, which takes three to four years to complete, in order
to update and improve the visitor experience. The last capsule refurbishment was completed between
the 2008 and 2012 financial years at a cost of approximately £13 million in aggregate.

Historically, capital investments have been managed in cycles and through an organized deployment,
generally determined based on periodic low, medium and high levels of investment, for each individual
Attraction across our business. We benefit from an ability to defer capital expenditure, which when
combined with an efficient net working capital profile and increased cash flow visibility from pre
bookings and our accommodation strategy, supports sustainable cash flow conversion.

We intend to continue maintaining the existing standards of general maintenance and commitments to
ensure health and safety standards and making strategic, value accretive investments in our Existing
Estate.

Our planned capital expenditure programme was reduced during the periods impacted by the COVID19 pandemic (excluding expenditure on LEGOLAND New York and LEGOLAND Korea). In the 2020,
2021 and 2022 financial years, our planned capital expenditure focused on concluding current projects,
essential maintenance and infrastructure work in our Existing Estate portfolio. As of the date of this
Offering Memorandum, we expect our capital expenditure for the 52 weeks ended 30 December 2023,
to be higher than that incurred in the 2022 financial year mainly as a result of a reduced impact from
the COVID-19 pandemic on our planned capital expenditure programme. See “Forward-Looking
_Statements.”_

_New Business Development_

We also focus on a New Business Development programme to drive strategic growth. This programme
includes, amongst others, adding visitor attractions that are located next to Theme Parks and for which


-----

additional admission fees are charged, referred to as Second Gate attractions and improving and
expanding accommodation facilities and opening new LEGOLAND Parks and Midway Attractions.

In the 2022 financial year, our New Business Development capital expenditure was £55 million, which
decreased from £219 million in 2021. Spend on New Business Development in the 2022 financial year
primarily included £33 million related to the development of our LEGOLAND parks and, primarily,
LEGOLAND Korea, which opened during the period. In addition, spend on New Business
Development in the 2022 financial year included £6 million related to the development of new
accommodation across our Theme Park Resorts, £7 million related to new Midway Attractions and £9
million in connection with other investment projects.

**_Development of LEGOLAND Parks_**

Another significant factor affecting our results of operations is the development of new LEGOLAND
Parks. Our LEGOLAND Parks are operated under one of our three operating models: (i) “owned and
_operated,” (ii) “leased and operated” and (iii) “manage and operate” under management contracts. Of_
the parks currently in operation, five are “owned and operated,” two, LEGOLAND Malaysia and
LEGOLAND Dubai, are operated under a management contract, and one, LEGOLAND Japan, is
operated under our “leased and operated” model.

We opened LEGOLAND Florida, the first LEGOLAND Park launched under our ownership, in
October 2011. LEGOLAND Florida is owned and operated by us, with admissions fees reflected
directly in revenues for the LEGOLAND Parks operating group.

LEGOLAND Malaysia opened in September 2012 and is managed by us pursuant to a management
contract with Malaysian partners. The resort was developed with funds provided by the Malaysian
government. As part of an agreement for the development and operation of LEGOLAND Malaysia, we
contributed fees earned during the development and operating phase back to IDR Resorts Sdn. Bhd.
(“IDR”) which, together with its subsidiaries, owns LEGOLAND Malaysia until we held 20 per cent.
of the share capital in IDR. That level has been reached and thus we own 20 per cent. of the company
that owns the park and no longer contribute management fees to IDR. We believe this operating model
enables us to enter certain new markets, while reducing our risk in those markets. Under the
management contract model, we typically receive development and management fees in return for the
provision of design, construction and ongoing operational management services; however, we do not
own the underlying assets or fund the site’s capital expenditure requirements. The management fee is
included in revenues for the LEGOLAND Parks operating group. We have an agreement with LL
Theme Parks LLC, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of DXB Entertainments, to operate
LEGOLAND Dubai under this management contract model, with no investment in equity.
LEGOLAND Dubai opened in 2016.

We opened a LEGOLAND Park in Nagoya, Japan in 2017, developed under our “leased and operated”
model, whereby we invested in the park with a partner from which we lease unowned assets in exchange
for rent. Under this model, we invested approximately one third of the total park development
expenditure, with the balance of the assets, primarily park infrastructure assets, owned by one of
KIRKBI’s subsidiaries and funded through a combination of equity and external debt provided by
Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation. We lease the park and associated assets on arm’s length
commercial terms, paying a turnover based rent with an annual floor on a 50 year lease. See “Certain
_Relationships and Related Party Transactions.” During the 2018 financial year, we opened SEA LIFE_
Nagoya, as well as a 252 room hotel at LEGOLAND Japan.

In 2021, we opened LEGOLAND New York while in 2022 we opened LEGOLAND Korea (with
support from the local province). Both LEGOLAND New York and LEGOLAND Korea are fully
owned and operated by us, consistent with all our U.S. and European LEGOLAND Parks.

In addition, we have also identified tangible opportunities to open new LEGOLAND Parks in China
with a focus on operating these parks under management contracts. We have entered into discussions
and agreements with the local governments and private parties with respect to these development
projects. See “Business—Material Contracts.” In addition, we are also developing three LEGOLAND
Parks in China in cooperation with local partners. Each of LEGOLAND Sichuan resort, LEGOLAND
Shanghai resort and LEGOLAND Shenzhen resort is expected to open during or after 2025. All three
will be operated under a management contract model. Capital expenditure for such LEGOLAND
projects is generally not incurred by us directly, but rather by our local partners. For example, the capital
expenditure related to our LEGOLAND Shenzhen and LEGOLAND Sichuan resorts are incurred by
our local partners, while the capital expenditure related to the LEGOLAND Shanghai resort is incurred
by a joint venture in which we are a minority investor. We intend to consider LEGOLAND Park


-----

development opportunities and the operating models for these opportunities on a case by case basis in
light of our strategic objectives.

**_Development of New Resort Hotels and Other Accommodation Facilities_**

Besides contributing to overall revenues through direct accommodation fees, our hotels and holiday
villages are a key component of our strategy of transforming our LEGOLAND Parks and Resort Theme
Parks into destination resorts to attract a broader customer base and encourage multi day visits, thereby
increasing overall visitor attendance and satisfaction while reducing the impact of short term weather
conditions. Accommodation also allows greater cross-selling opportunities and leads to increases in pre
bookings, revenue visibility and positive working capital. During the 2020, 2021 and 2022 financial
years, we launched a total of five new accommodation developments.

During 2020, we opened a 150 room accommodation offering at LEGOLAND Florida.

During 2021, we opened a 250 room resort at LEGOLAND New York.

During 2022, we increased our accommodation offering, by adding 476 new rooms through the opening
of a 250 room hotel at LEGOLAND Dubai, in partnership with the park’s owners, a 154 room hotel at
LEGOLAND Korea, and a 72 room extension to the holiday village at LEGOLAND Germany. Over
the same period, we closed 24 of our rooms at LEGOLAND Germany.

Our aggregate room capacity was over 5,300 rooms as of 1 April 2023. Room capacity within our
LEGOLAND Parks and Resort Theme Parks operating groups was 3,433 and 1,909, respectively as of
1 April 2023.

**_Strategic Acquisitions and Disposals_**

In addition to the roll out and development of new Attractions, our revenue growth and profitability are
affected by strategic acquisitions and disposals. During the periods under review, we acquired the
operations and brand licence of Cadbury World (a popular attraction in the UK) pursuant to an exclusive
partnership with Mondelēz International, thereby deepening our relationship with a leading UK
chocolate brand. As part of the agreement, we will be responsible for the day-to-day running of the
Cadbury World site, its employees, and all operational decisions, as well as holding brand usage rights
for Cadbury World. We recognised a total consideration of £8 million in connection with this
acquisition, which we expect to become payable in 2024, subject to the performance of the acquired
Attraction. We believe that the Cadbury World acquisition has enabled us to deepen our strategic
relationship with the leading UK’s chocolate brand, and will enable us to increase cross promotion and
drive visitor traffic to our Attractions. In addition, In April 2022 we completed the acquisition of the
COEX Aquarium in Seoul, South Korea by acquiring 100 per cent. of the issued share capital of Seoul
Ocean Aquarium Co., Ltd. for £31 million, net of cash acquired. In addition, as part of our overall
growth strategy, we proactively manage the composition of our portfolio and have occasionally
disposed of or closed certain of our businesses and assets to increase efficiencies, profit and cash flows
or to reduce liabilities. In addition, while we did not complete any significant disposal over the periods
under review, from time to time we may close or divest certain smaller Midway Attractions, primarily
as a result of reduced customer demand following COVID-19 or as part of our business strategy. In
particular, from 2020 through to 1 April 2023 we have closed six Midway Attractions.

**_Variations in Weather_**

Our portfolio is diversified across outdoor and indoor Attractions with 33 per cent. of our total revenue
being generated at indoor Attractions and 67 per cent. at outdoor Attractions for the 53 weeks ended 1
April 2023, and multiple geographies, which provides a degree of natural hedging against the financial
impact of certain external factors such as variations in weather. In the 2022 financial year, 46 per cent.
of our revenue was derived from our LEGOLAND Parks and 22 per cent. of our revenue was derived
from our Resort Theme Parks operations, which are primarily organised around outdoor activities, and


-----

32 per cent. of our revenue was derived from our Midway Attractions operating group, which is
primarily organised around indoor activities, mitigating the impact of adverse weather. However,
unfavourable weather and forecasts of unfavourable weather, especially during our peak opening period
and on or for weekend days, can adversely affect visitor attendance at the Attractions and, consequently,
our financial performance, particularly at our LEGOLAND and Resort Theme Parks Attractions.

The Midway Attractions operating group can also be impacted by weather conditions. Unlike our Resort
Theme Parks and our LEGOLAND Parks, almost all of our Midway Attractions are located indoors and
thus hot weather can have a negative impact on visitor numbers as potential visitors are diverted to
outdoor Attractions, such as theme parks.

In addition, mild weather may increase occupancy levels in leisure destinations, particularly during
peak travel season. Weather also typically affects our energy costs, which may increase when there are
abnormally severe weather conditions or prolonged cold or hot temperatures.

We seek to reduce the risk to our operations imposed by unfavourable weather conditions through the
use of an advance purchase pricing model for online ticket sales, providing a discount to customers who
book in advance, as well as sales of Merlin Annual Passes, Merlin Monthly Memberships and individual
Attraction season passes. We also seek to draw trade visitors, such as coach tours and school visits, to
the Attractions, and the vast majority of these trade visitors book tickets in advance. Our strategy of
transforming our Resort Theme Parks and LEGOLAND Parks into destination resorts, chiefly by the
development of accommodation facilities, further supports pre booked ticket sales by encouraging
visitors to plan multi day trips further in advance. In the 2022 financial year, approximately 79 per cent.
of our revenue from admissions was pre booked, of which 9 per cent. came through Merlin passes.

**_Seasonality_**

Our operations are subject to seasonal factors. The majority of our revenue is generated between midMarch and November due to a variety of factors affecting the northern hemisphere, where the majority
of the Attractions are located. Such factors include school holiday periods, with the longest peak during
July and August and shorter peaks during the Easter and (in the United Kingdom) October school
holiday periods, and generally favourable weather conditions. The timing of the Easter holiday each
year may affect our results of operations because when the Easter holiday occurs later in the year, it is
more likely to coincide with periods of favourable weather. In the 2022 financial year 23 per cent. of
our revenue was generated between January and April, 17 per cent. of our revenue was generated
between May and June, 38 per cent. of our revenue was generated between July and September, and 22
per cent. of our revenue was generated between October and December. These results are representative
of the effect of seasonal variation on our revenue during the periods under review. During the winter
months (November to mid-March in the northern hemisphere), our revenues have historically reduced
substantially and, in particular, our seasonal Attractions (including all of the Resort Theme Parks and
the European LEGOLAND Parks) are either closed or open for more limited hours during certain
periods. Even at the Attractions that are open year round, including LEGOLAND Florida, LEGOLAND
California and all of our Midway Attractions, attendance patterns have historically experienced
significant seasonality, driven by, amongst other factors, tourism patterns and school holidays. We
typically incur capital expenditure during the winter months (which vary depending on the location of
the Attractions) in carrying out maintenance and refurbishment work and the addition of new rides to
the Resort Theme Parks and LEGOLAND Parks.

We seek to manage our expenses to match this seasonality in revenue by the use of seasonal employees
during the peak months. Additionally, the expansion of our operations in the United States, Asia and
Australia has created some variance in peak seasons between our Attractions. This increasing
geographical diversification is a part of our growth strategy that we believe will, over time, reduce the
effects of seasonality on our business.


-----

The seasonality of our business may also, from time to time, cause our results to be affected
disproportionately by any significant “one-off” events that occur in our principal trading markets during
the peak seasons of operation. Such “one-off” events may impact particular financial years and may
make comparability across different financial years more difficult. For example, our Asia Pacific
operations were impacted by COVID-19 restrictions in the 2022 summer months.

**_COVID-19 Impact_**

The worldwide outbreak of COVID-19 in 2020 and the consequent containment measures implemented
by the public authorities of the affected countries in 2020 and 2021 has had an enormous social impact
and a significant impact on general economic performance and on consumption and investments,
leading to general uncertainty. COVID-19 significantly particularly strained the entertainment industry
due to travel restrictions and stay-at-home directives in place at various times during 2020 and 2021,
resulting in widespread disruptions and significantly reduced travel around the world. The reduction in
travel resulted in the complete and partial suspensions of our operations in many of the areas where our
Attractions are located, including the closure of the overwhelming majority of our Attractions for
protracted periods of time in 2020 and in 2021. As such, the COVID-19 pandemic had a material impact
on our results for the 2020 and 2021 financial years. As a result of the impact of the COVID-19
pandemic on our results of operations for the 2020 financial year and the 2021 financial year, the
comparability of our results for the periods under review (particularly for the 2021 financial year
compared to the 2020 financial year), with the relevant corresponding periods and the comparability
with future periods may also be limited.

Following the outbreak of COVID-19 in 2020, we timely adopted all necessary prevention, control and
containment measures throughout our global operations. In addition, we rapidly implemented additional
measures including a tight management of cash outflows in the form of operating cost and cash control,
as well as cost cutting and cash savings measures, which included access to employee furlough schemes.
At the same time, in April 2020 we secured €500 million of additional liquidity through the issuance of
the 2025 Notes. Despite the deployment of these measures, COVID-19 negatively impacted our
performance in 2020, with our revenues decreasing significantly compared to our revenues in 2019.
While we also experienced impacts from COVID-19 related restrictions and lockdowns in 2021, over
the same period our revenues increased compared to 2020 as a result of a recovery in customer demand
(particularly on a domestic scale). Our trading performance further recovered through the 2022 financial
year, as a result of governmental restrictions being lifted in key geographical areas such as North
America, the UK and Continental Europe, which allowed an increasing number of our Attractions to
operate for a higher number of trading days compared to 2021. Over the course of 2022, we also
benefited from a recovery in international tourism (particularly at Attractions in key tourist hubs such
as London and New York).

We believe that our business has demonstrated resilience during the COVID-19 pandemic, with each
of our operating groups recording a robust recovery following the easing of restrictions.

**_Macroeconomic Conditions_**

As an operator of leisure attractions, our success depends to an extent on discretionary consumer
spending, which is influenced by general economic conditions and the availability of discretionary
income. Low economic growth in many of the countries in which we operate, coupled with future
economic uncertainty, has had and continues to have an adverse effect on consumers’ discretionary
spending and consumer confidence.

Our results of operations and financial condition are also impacted by other global macroeconomic
factors such as the prevailing market interest rates, consumer spending and consumer confidence,
overall inflation levels and energy costs. In particular, increases in interest rates, which are determined
and controlled by central banks in response to macroeconomic events (including the recent February
2023, March 2023 and May 2023 increases by the European Central Bank), may negatively affect


-----

general economic growth in the countries in which we operate and, consequently, could have a negative
impact on customer demand as well as our financing costs. On the other hand, inflation surges and the
increase in energy costs may have a negative impact on our cost base and overall profitability levels. In
addition, global economic conditions may also be impacted by continued adverse developments in the
banking and financial services industry. In March 2023, Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank were
closed by regulators in the United States following liquidity concerns. In Europe, Credit Suisse came
close to a collapse in March 2023, which led to UBS agreeing to acquire its business, following the
intervention of Swiss regulatory authorities. Increasing pressure on U.S. regional banks has continued,
leading to the announcement by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on May 1, 2023, that First
Republic Bank, a California based regional bank, would be taken over by JPMorgan Chase. While we
have no material exposure to these institutions, there is no guarantee that other financial institutions will
not experience similar liquidity issues in the near future, or that actions taken by government authorities
to mitigate these risks will be sufficient to ensure access to our cash deposits and sources of liquidity.
In addition, there can be no assurance that there will not be additional bank failures or issues in the
broader financial system, which may have an impact on the broader capital markets and, in turn, our
ability to access those markets. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Market and Industry—
_Economic conditions beyond our control could have an adverse effect on our results of operations.”_

In addition, while our operations are not directly impacted by the war in Ukraine, such conflict has
contributed to an increase in energy costs and could cause sustained inflationary pressures if not
concluded in the short term. The cost-of-living crisis, driven by high levels of inflation, has the potential
to impact demand and consumer choices. However, our business has historically demonstrated
resilience during periods of economic slowdown. We believe our resilience in adverse economic
conditions is due to, amongst other reasons, consumer spending on family visitor Attractions tending to
be more resistant to cutbacks than many other forms of discretionary spending during periods of
economic downturn. Additionally, the Attractions may represent a less expensive holiday or leisure
alternative compared to overseas travel holidays for domestic customers in the countries in which we
operate.

Following the UK referendum on Brexit in June 2016, sterling weakened considerably relative to other
world currencies. As 65, 64 and 70 per cent. of our revenue in the 2020, 2021 and 2022 financial years,
respectively, was derived from other countries, notably the United States and Continental Europe, we
saw positive translation effects that benefitted our results for the 2020, 2021 and 2022 financial years.
In the medium term, we believe a more competitive pound could increase in bound tourism to London
and drive more “staycations” on the part of UK residents. In 2021, due to a limited recovery in
international tourism we benefited from a “staycation” effect of domestic customers that supported our
revenue recovery.

Notwithstanding this general resilience to economic downturns, significant macroeconomic events in
the countries in which we operate may have an adverse effect on our performance, and unemployment
may also play a significant role in the level of discretionary consumer spending and, in particular, the
unemployment level amongst our target demographics may affect visitor attendance levels and revenues
at certain Attractions.

**_Geographical Expansion and Diversification_**

One of our key strategies is geographical expansion and diversification. We believe we own and operate
a unique portfolio of chainable iconic assets and brands, which possess a strong heritage within their
original markets, and which are globally scalable and supported by our extensive technical and creative
expertise. Our success implementing this strategy is a key driver of our growth and financial
performance. The geographic scope of our business has expanded significantly since our inception, and
now includes a portfolio of Attractions across Europe, North America and the Asia Pacific region.
Expanding into new cities and countries allows us to continually increase the number of Attractions in
our portfolio, which in turn helps to increase visitor numbers and revenues. This also provides us with


-----

some opportunities to create “clusters,” developing multiple Attractions in one city or region to
capitalise on operational, marketing and cross-selling advantages.

**_Geographical diversification can also reduce the effects of seasonality. With Attractions in different_**
**_cities, countries and hemispheres, there is some variance in peak seasons between Attractions._**

The Asia Pacific region, in particular, represents an area of increasing strategic focus for us, with a
growing number of Midway Attractions and LEGOLAND Parks located in the region. In 2022, we have
opened LEGOLAND Korea, and completed the acquisition of the COEX Aquarium in Seoul (South
Korea), which has been added to our SEA LIFE portfolio. As of 1 April 2023, we operated 39
Attractions in nine countries across the Asia Pacific region. In addition, we are also developing three
LEGOLAND Parks in China in cooperation with local partners. Each of LEGOLAND Sichuan resort,
LEGOLAND Shanghai resort and LEGOLAND Shenzhen resort is expected to open during or after
2025. All three will be operated under our management contract model. At the same time, we are also
considering to strengthen our footprint with the opening of additional Midway Attractions throughout
the region. For further information, see “—Development of LEGOLAND Parks.”

Geographical diversification also provides us with a degree of natural hedging against certain external
factors, such as variations in weather, localised economic downturns and other localised events that
may have a temporary or sustained impact on visitor numbers at particular Attractions.

This geographical expansion and diversification requires careful strategic planning and active
management as we enter jurisdictions with different legal, political and economic circumstances, such
as Madame Tussauds Dubai, which we opened in 2021. We may enter a new jurisdiction in multiple
ways. In addition to launching new sites on our own, we may enter a new jurisdiction by acquiring and
rebranding existing leisure attractions, as demonstrated by our acquisitions of the Sydney Attractions
Group and Living and Leisure Australia, or by entering into partnership with local governments or third
parties, as reflected by LEGOLAND Malaysia, LEGOLAND Dubai and LEGOLAND Korea. We
consider entering into new jurisdictions, including the method of entering into such jurisdictions, on a
case by case basis in light of our strategic objectives.

**_Volume and Yield Strategies_**

Although visitor volumes are the primary driver of our revenue growth and profitability, profitability is
also a function of the admissions revenue per capita. We define “admissions revenue per capita” as the
amount of revenue each visitor provides by way of admission fees. Admissions revenue per capita is a
function of the lead price (being the full price for visitors), excluding VAT and other sales taxes, and
any promotional discounts we provide. To maximise total revenue and profit, we continuously monitor
both visitor volumes and admissions yield, being the admissions revenue per capita divided by the lead
price, for each of the Attractions. Our revenue per capita has increased from approximately £20 to £22
for each of the 2016, 2017, 2018 and 2019 financial years to approximately £29 to £30 in each of the
2021 and 2022 financial years, and represents a key driver of our profitability. Rising revenue per capita
also allow us to pass increased costs to our visitors, as we benefit from a cost pass-through capability
across our operating groups.

Decisions about volume and yield strategies for each Attraction are made weekly, monthly, quarterly
and annually by central and local management. In making these decisions, management seeks to
respond to changing patterns of demand, taking into account a wide variety of factors, including
prevailing economic circumstances, the time of year, the age of an Attractions and the Attractions’
propositions, customer ratings of “value for money” and target audience. Both volume and yield
strategies rely on our ability to implement effective pricing and marketing strategies.

We can achieve higher volumes for an individual Attraction through the use of entry promotions and
admission fee discounts, including national promotions and marketing campaigns in conjunction with
partners. We can use such promotions and discounts to distribute visitor attendance across an


-----

Attraction’s opening hours or opening period. For example, we may offer discounts for off peak times
of day or off peak days, thereby improving visitor volumes during those times. We may also use
promotions to help establish Attractions in local markets, typically using promotions in the second year
after opening once the initial heightened visitor volumes associated with a new launch have subsided.

We can also affect the admissions revenue per capita for an individual Attraction by incrementally
increasing an Attraction’s lead price and/or changing the quantum or level of discounts offered in
respect of an Attraction’s admission fee. We seek to increase revenue and profit generated during an
Attraction’s periods of peak demand and by high demand Attractions by increasing the admissions
revenue per capita during those periods and for those Attractions.

Similar to decisions about volume and yield strategies for individual Attractions, decisions about
volume and yield strategies for Merlin Annual Passes, Merlin Monthly Memberships and individual
Attraction seasonal passes are made regularly by central management to respond to changing patterns
of demand and use.

In addition, in 2022 we have deployed several revenue management initiatives primarily focused on
supporting and growing our revenues per capita which, combined with recovering visitation rates, has
contributed to driving our revenue growth and Adjusted EBITDA performance over the same period.
These initiatives included, among others, a reduction of the overall number of days on which certain
discounts were available to our visitors, which has contributed to an increase in our revenue per capita
for the 2022 financial year.

**_Impact of Exchange Rates_**

Our presentational currency is pounds sterling, but our operations outside the United Kingdom use
currencies other than pounds sterling, principally the euro, the Danish Kroner and the U.S. dollar, as
well as other currencies including the Australian dollar, the Japanese Yen, the New Zealand dollar, the
Canadian dollar, the South Korean Won and other various currencies in Asia. For example, in the 2022
financial year, 30 per cent. of our revenue was generated in pounds sterling, 23 per cent. in euro and
Danish Kroner and 35 per cent. in U.S. dollars. Our financial performance is therefore subject to
fluctuations as a result of foreign currency exchange rate movements whenever financial information is
translated from non-pounds sterling currencies. For example, in the second half of 2022, the pound
sterling experienced a material weakening against other currencies, particularly the U.S. Dollar. As a
result, our performance positively impacted by a translation of our U.S. dollars revenues into pound
sterling. Retranslating 2022 financial year performance at 2021 financial rates would have resulted in a
£59 million decrease in revenue and a £23 million decrease in EBITDA.


-----

To eliminate the impact of foreign exchange movements on our reported revenue and EBITDA,
management uses revenue and EBITDA on a constant currency basis to evaluate business performance.
We also seek to structure our indebtedness in currencies that help reduce translational foreign exchange
exposure by drawing debt denominated in our major currencies of operation.

In addition to the translational impact of exchange rate fluctuations, we are exposed to transactional
exchange rate risk. Certain operating expenses and capital expenditures are from time to time
denominated in foreign currencies, though in general, most payments and revenues are denominated in
the same local currencies used in the countries in which we have Attractions. Additionally, we seek to
limit our exposure to foreign currency fluctuations through the use of derivative instruments under an
approved control framework. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Hedging
_Agreements” and “—Disclosure about Market and Credit Risks—Currency Risk” for a further_
description of our foreign currency hedging activities and certain risks related thereto.

**_Staff Expenses and Other Operating Expenses_**

Staff expenses represent the largest portion of our operating expenses. Staff expenses include
compensation and benefits for our employees and change over time based on changes in the number of
personnel employed and the compensation level per employee. Our staff expenses for the 2020 financial
year were £304 million and for the 2021 financial year were £374 million. Total staff expenses for the
2022 financial year were £536 million. Staff expenses as a percentage of revenues were 30 per cent. in
the 2021 financial year and 27 per cent. in the 2022 financial year, having decreased primarily as a
result of increasing revenues primarily driven by the re-opening of existing Attractions as a result of a
recovery from COVID-19 and the roll out and development of new Attractions.

Due to the seasonality of our business, employee headcount varies significantly throughout the year.
We manage our employment costs by optimizing our fixed-time and part-time workforce, also based
on flexible (including hourly) agreements that are highly variable. For example, we hire a substantial
number of workers on a flexible, seasonal basis, which is typical for operators of seasonal attractions in
the leisure industry. Depending on the Attraction, and subject to the relevant laws and regulations of
the jurisdiction in which the Attraction is located, seasonal employees are hired for the entire summer
season or on a periodic basis, in each case with flexible arrangements, enabling us to vary the hours
worked as we deem necessary. Although the use of seasonal employees provides us with a certain
amount of flexibility on our cost base, our ability to make substantial savings through headcount
reduction of seasonal employees during the opening period may be constrained by the limited advance
visibility of visitor numbers and for some Attractions, such as Gardaland Resort, certain restrictions
imposed by local employment laws.

In addition, as other businesses operating in the leisure and hospitality industry, we continue to
experience employment cost pressures in a number of locations, primarily as a result of increases in
minimum wages and tight labour markets combined with high vacancy levels since the easing of the
COVID-19 pandemic. In response to the increased minimum wages and tight labour conditions we have
and we continue to focus on ways to improve our operational efficiency, including greater use of an
appropriate full-time/part time mix in each Attraction, and in common with many businesses in the
leisure and hospitality industry, we will seek to pass on elements of the cost increase to customers in
the form of higher charges. Most recently, our staff expenses have increased due to our efforts to service
a strong recovery in customer demand and to allow the opening of our Attractions further to COVID19 restrictions being lifted. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Market and Our Business—
_Increased costs of labour, work stoppages and other labour problems, and the seasonal nature of our_
_workforce may negatively impact our results of operations.”_

Our average number of permanent employees for the 2020, 2021 and 2022 financial years was 8,449,
8,367 and 11,954, respectively. Our average number of total employees, which also include seasonal or
temporary employees, for the 2020, 2021 and 2022 financial years 18,521, 17,672 and 21,214,
respectively.


-----

During 2022, increasing inflation has driven an increase in wholesale energy prices (particularly across
the UK and Continental Europe). We experienced an impact below the level of overall energy prices in
2022 due to a combination of forward contracts and government support packages. While we maintain
robust procurement processes allowing us to tactically build a hedged forward position for our energy
requirements, the energy contracts we renewed in 2022 and 2023 have resulted in significant price
increases while government support packages have largely been removed. This may in turn drive a
significant increase in our energy costs compared to our long-term historic average. While utilities costs
do not represent a significant portion of our cost base, and amounted to 3 per cent. of revenues for the
2022 financial year, as additional energy contracts expire and need to undergo a renewal process, we
may become subject to a greater impact from increased energy prices.

**_Hedging of Interest Rate and Currency Exposures_**

We hold derivative financial instruments primarily to hedge our interest rate and foreign currency
exposures. In general, we endeavour to implement hedging arrangements that will qualify for hedge
accounting treatment, but we are not always able to do so. To the extent we hold hedges that do not
qualify for hedge accounting treatment, we determine the fair value of those hedges at the end of each
accounting period and recognise the changes in fair value as finance income or finance cost. See note
5.3 to the audited consolidated financial statements for the 2020 and 2022 financial years, and note 4.3
to the audited consolidated financial statements for the 2021 financial year, included elsewhere in this
Offering Memorandum.

**_Impact of Leases_**

We lease and pay rent on a substantial portion of our Attractions, and the majority of our lease liabilities
are non-current lease liabilities. As of 31 December 2022, our IFRS 16 lease liabilities amounted to
£1,612 million (2021: £1,458 million) on a discounted basis. For further details, see note 5.4 to the
audited consolidated financial statements for the 2022 financial year. For a description of our principal
real estate interests and leases, see “Business—Property.”

**Additional Factors Affecting Comparability of Results of Operations**

**_COVID-19 Impact_**

The COVID-19 pandemic had a material impact on our results for the 2020 and 2021 financial years.
The comparability of our results for the periods under review (particularly for the 2021 financial year
compared to the 2020 financial year), with the relevant corresponding periods and the comparability
with future periods may also be limited, see “—Factors Affecting our Results of Operations —COVID_19 Impact.”_

**_Financial Periods_**

We prepare our financial statements on the basis of a 52 week financial period (as was the case for the
2020 and 2021 financial years) or a 53 week financial period (as was the case for the 2022 financial
year). Results for financial years that include 53 weeks are not directly comparable to results from
financial years that include 52 weeks. Accordingly, the historical results presented may not be directly
comparable to results from other financial periods.

**_The Offering_**

The Issuer will issue the Notes on the Issue Date. We estimate the gross proceeds of the Notes will be
€650 million. On or about the Issue Date, the proceeds of the Offering will be used, together with cash
on balance sheet: (i) to redeem the 2025 Notes, including paying the redemption premium thereon and
accrued and unpaid interest to the date of the redemption, (ii) maintain cash on balance sheet to repay,
redeem, repurchase (including from the open-market) or address maturities of, our other secured


-----

indebtedness, and (iii) to pay the fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See
“Use of Proceeds.”

Accordingly, our financial condition and results of operations may differ from the historical financial
condition and results of operations presented in this discussion as a result of the Offering.

**Key Components of Our Income Statement**

The key components of certain line items of our consolidated income statement are described below.

**_Revenue_**

Revenue primarily represents the amounts (excluding VAT and similar taxes) received from visitors for
admission fees and priority ride access passes, amounts generated from hotel and holiday village
operations and additional commercial spend by visitors, including food and beverages, merchandise,
souvenir photography, games, car parking and guide book sales. Revenue is also generated from private
functions and sponsorship arrangements. Revenue also includes development and management fees
received under development and management agreements for certain LEGOLAND Parks (including
with respect to the development and management of LEGOLAND Dubai, the management of
LEGOLAND Malaysia and the development of LEGOLAND Sichuan, LEGOLAND Shanghai and
LEGOLAND Shenzhen) during the periods under review. Revenue is also generated from private
functions and sponsorship arrangements.

Admissions revenue is recognised at point of entry. Revenue from the sale of Merlin Annual Passes,
Merlin Monthly Memberships, individual Attraction season passes and multi attraction tickets is
recognised by the Attraction that sold the pass and, in the case of Merlin Annual Passes, Merlin Monthly
Memberships and individual Attraction season passes, evenly over the period that the pass is valid.
Where Merlin Annual Passes for the United Kingdom have been sold through our central web store,
revenue has been allocated to the applicable Attractions visited.

In many locations across our estate, photography and game operations are operated with partners that
provide specialist knowledge under revenue sharing arrangements.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Cost of sales represents variable expenses (excluding VAT and similar taxes) incurred from revenue
generating activity. The expense of food and beverages, accommodation related expenses and retail
merchandise are the principal expenses recognised in cost of sales.

Royalty payments made to the KIRKBI Group are also recognised in cost of sales. We make a royalty
payment to the KIRKBI Group for the use of the LEGOLAND trademark and ancillary use of the LEGO
trademark, content and other intellectual property rights, pursuant to the LCA. See “Business—Material
_Contracts—Intellectual Property” for further details of the LCA._

**_Staff Expenses_**

Staff expenses are the principal component of our operating expenses. Staff expenses primarily
comprise wages and salaries, social security costs and pension costs, as well as any expenses arising
from share based payments and profit related bonuses.

**_Marketing_**

Costs relating to marketing include expenditures on advertising, e commerce and in connection with
third-party promotions for our Attractions.

**_Other Operating Expenses_**


-----

Other operating expenses include repairs and maintenance, displays (including displays relating to SEA
LIFE aquariums), utilities, travel costs, office costs, insurance and IT costs.

**_Depreciation, Amortisation and Impairment_**

Depreciation, amortisation and impairment relates to the ongoing depreciation of property, plant and
equipment (“PPE”) over the estimated applicable useful lives, amortisation of intangible assets over
their applicable estimated useful lives and impairment charges where the value of such assets do not
prove to be recoverable in full. When separate components of an item of PPE have different useful lives,
those components are accounted for separately.

**_Finance Income_**

Finance income is primarily comprised of interest income, foreign exchange gains and gains on hedging
instruments, which are recognised as they accrue. Finance income also includes gains generated on the
termination of certain derivative financial instruments.

**_Finance Costs_**

Finance costs comprise the interest paid by us on our bank debt including the amortisation of financing
costs in respect of bank facilities, together with financing charges on our finance leases, foreign
exchange losses and losses on hedging instruments, which are recognised as they accrue. Finance costs
also include losses generated on the closing out of certain derivative financial instruments.

**_Taxation_**

Taxation represents the corporation tax charge or credit on our profit or loss for the year, and includes
both current and deferred taxation. Taxation is recognised in the income statement unless it relates to
items recognised directly in equity, when it is recognised through the statement of comprehensive
income.

Current tax is the expected tax payable on the taxable income for the year, using rates enacted or
substantively enacted in each jurisdiction at the end of the reporting period, and any adjustments in
respect of previous periods. Deferred tax is provided on certain temporary differences between the
carrying amount of the assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and taxation purposes at
the end of each reporting period. The amount of deferred tax provided is based on the expected manner
of realisation or settlement of the carrying amount of assets and liabilities, using the tax rates enacted
in each jurisdiction at the end of the reporting period.

Our gross effective tax rate for any financial year is equal to total taxation divided by our consolidated
profit before tax. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Contingent Liabilities.”

_Revenue_

Revenue increased by £78 million, or 31 per cent., to £325 million for Q1 2023 from £247 million in
Q1 2022. This increase was driven by robust consumer demand, elevated revenues per visitor and the
continued recovery in international tourism which supported strong trading in North America, the UK,
and in parts of Continental Europe. Our trading primarily reflected the positive performance of our
Midway Attractions and our year-round LEGOLAND resorts, as the majority of our Resort Theme
Parks and LEGOLAND parks were seasonally closed during Q1 2023. While COVID-19 restrictions
have eased on parts of our Asia Pacific footprint, trading continues to be impacted by lower levels of
outbound Chinese tourism. The ongoing recovery in visitation, combined with our targeted approach to
revenue management, continue to support revenue growth. Lastly, our reported revenue for Q1 2023 is
also favourably impacted by foreign exchange rates.

_Cost of Sales_

Cost of sales increased by £12 million, or 24 per cent., to £63 million for Q1 2023 from £51 million in
Q1 2022. The increase was primarily driven by an increase in revenue generating activities compared
to Q1 2022, which have caused an increase in variable costs relating to food and beverage consumables
and retail merchandise, partly offset by focused cost control and efficiency initiatives.

_Staff Expenses_


-----

Staff expenses increased by £23 million, or 24 per cent., to £118 million for Q1 2023 from £95 million
in Q1 2022. This increase was primarily due to employment cost pressures in several locations,
particularly resulting from wage increases driven by inflation, increases to minimum wage levels, and
tightening labour markets. In addition, share-based payment charges in respect of the Management
Share Incentive Plans implemented in late 2021 totalled £5 million in Q1 2023, an increase of £2 million
from £3 million in Q1 2022.

_Marketing_

Marketing expenses increased by £6 million, or 57 per cent., to £17 million for Q1 2023 from £11
million in Q1 2022. This increase was driven primarily by increased marketing activity and planned
phased recovery of marketing spend, returning closer to pre-pandemic levels.

_Other Operating Expenses_

Other operating expenses increased by £14 million, or 16 per cent., to £99 million for Q1 2023 from
£85 million in Q1 2022. This increase was driven by the impact on our cost base of new attractions
opened in 2022 together with increased utility costs and repairs and maintenance costs improvement
works taking place at several sites over the winter season.

_Depreciation, Amortisation and Impairment_

Depreciation, amortisation and impairment increased by £2 million, or 4 per cent., to £64 million for
Q1 2023 from £62 million in Q1 2022. This increase was driven primarily by foreign exchange
movements and the impact of new attraction openings.

_Operating Profit/(loss)_

Operating loss decreased by £21 million, or 36 per cent., to £36 million for Q1 2023 from a loss of £57
million in Q1 2022. This decrease was driven primarily by the factors discussed above.

_Finance Income_

Finance income increased by £1 million, to £1 million for Q1 2023 from £nil million in Q1 2022. This
increase was driven primarily by the combined effect of higher interest rates and higher levels of
liquidity.

_Finance Costs_

Finance costs increased by £32 million, or 53 per cent., to £92 million for Q1 2023 from £60 million in
Q1 2022. This increase was driven primarily by the combined effect of increases in interest rates on our
unhedged interest-bearing loans and borrowings, and £8 million foreign exchange losses recorded on
non-sterling internal loan structures.

_Taxation_

Taxation increased by £59 million, to a credit of £55 million for Q1 2023 from a charge of £4 million
in Q1 2022. This increase was driven primarily by the effect of an increase in the estimated effective
tax rate for Q1 2023.

_Profit/(loss) for the Period_

Loss for the period decreased by £49 million, or 40 per cent., to a loss of £72 million for Q1 2023 from
a loss of £121 million in Q1 2022. This decrease was driven primarily by the factors discussed above.


-----

_EBITDA_

EBITDA increased by £23 million, or 477 per cent., to £28 million for Q1 2023 from £5 million in Q1
2022, primarily driven by increases in revenue.

_Adjusted EBITDA_

Adjusted EBITDA increased by £25 million or 312 per cent., to £33 million for Q1 2023 from £8 million
in Q1 2022. This increase was primarily driven by the factors discussed above.

_Revenue_

Revenue increased by £745 million, or 59 per cent., to £2,006 million for the 2022 financial year from
£1,261 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven by robust consumer demand,
elevated revenues per visitor and high average room rates in our accommodation portfolio, all
supporting strong trading particularly in North America, the UK and on parts of Continental Europe, as
well as a continuing post-COVID 19 recovery of international tourism (despite lower levels of outbound
Chinese tourism due to local restrictions impacting our Asia Pacific operations). In 2021 and 2022 we
also opened LEGOLAND New York and LEGOLAND Korea, respectively, two large Attractions
which contributed to revenue increases.

_Cost of Sales_

Cost of sales increased by £133 million, or 59 per cent., to £359 million for the 2022 financial year from
£226 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven primarily by increased visitor


-----

revenues, requiring additional cost for food and beverage consumables and retail merchandise, together
with a growth of our accommodation portfolio.

_Staff Expenses_

Staff expenses increased by £162 million, or 43 per cent., to £536 million for the 2022 financial year
from £374 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven by greater variable expenses
incurred from our revenue generating activities, combined with lower levels of governmental support
payments, which totalled £2 million received in the 2022 financial year compared to £19 million in the
2021 financial year. The financial year 2022 also includes £21 million of share-based payment
accounting charges in respect of the Management Share Incentive Plans implemented in late 2021. See
“Management—Management Share Incentive Plans.”

_Marketing_

Marketing expenses increased by £44 million, or 147 per cent., to £74 million for the 2022 financial
year from £30 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven primarily by increased
marketing to support the increase in our trading levels over the same period.

_Other Operating Expenses_

Other operating expenses increased by £111 million, or 44 per cent., to £366 million for the 2022
financial year from £255 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven primarily by the
combined effect of increased repairs and maintenance costs, as a result of an increase in Attractions
being open in the 2022 financial year compared to the 2021 financial year, and higher property costs in
the UK as a result of an increase in applicable business rates. Governmental support payments totalled
£33 million received in the 2022 financial year compared to £19 million received in the 2021 financial
year.

_Depreciation, Amortisation and Impairment_

Depreciation, amortisation and impairment amounted to £285 million for the 2022 financial year, an
increase of £39 million, or 16 per cent., from £246 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was
primarily due to increased depreciation charges in respect of our recently opened Attractions
LEGOLAND New York and LEGOLAND Korea, in addition to £29 million of impairment charges
relating to two Midway Attractions and one joint venture.

_Operating Profit_

Operating profit increased by £256 million or 196 per cent., to £386 million for the 2022 financial year
from £130 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven primarily by the factors discussed
above.

_Finance Income_

Finance income increased by £27 million to £29 million for the 2022 financial year from £2 million in
the 2021 financial year. Finance income in 2022 was primarily attributable to net foreign exchange
gains on non-sterling intercompany loans.

_Finance Costs_

Finance costs increased by £53 million, or 23 per cent., to £279 million for the 2022 financial year from
£226 million for the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven primarily by higher interest charges
on our financial liabilities. In addition, floating rates on interest-bearing loans and borrowings also
increased in the period, along with interest charges resulting from the extension of lease tenure at certain
Resort Theme Park locations in the 2021 and 2022 financial years.


-----

_Taxation_

Taxation slightly increased by £1 million, or 3 per cent., to £47 million for the 2022 financial year from
£46 million in the 2021 financial year. The effective tax rate in 2021 was (48.9) per cent. as a result of
the revaluation of deferred tax liabilities following corporation tax rate changes to be enacted from 1
April 2023 in the UK and the non-recognition of tax losses. The effective tax rate in 2022 was 34.6 per
cent., which was higher than the prevailing UK standard rate due primarily to the effect of tax rates in
foreign jurisdictions and certain non-deductible expenditure offset by movements in uncertain tax
provisions.

_Profit/(loss) for the Year_

Profit/(loss) for the year increased by £229 million to a profit of £89 million for the 2022 financial year
from a loss of £140 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was primarily driven by the factors
discussed above.

_EBITDA_

EBITDA increased by £295 million, or 78 per cent., to £671 million for the 2022 financial year from

year from £379 million in the 2021 financial year. This increase was driven by the factors discussed
