the relevant debtor for the return of funds or the payment of a consideration), while claims of a person
who becomes a creditor of the insolvency estate only after the opening of insolvency proceedings
generally rank senior to the claims of regular, unsecured creditors. Claims of subordinated creditors in
the insolvency proceedings (nachrangige Insolvenzgläubiger) are satisfied only after the claims of other
non-subordinated creditors (including the unsecured insolvency claims) have been fully satisfied.

The insolvency estate shall serve to satisfy the liquidated claims held by the personal creditors against
the debtor on the date the insolvency proceedings were opened. The following claims shall be satisfied
ranking below the other claims of insolvency creditors in the order given herein, and in proportion to
their amounts if ranking with equal status: (i) interest and penalty payments accrued on the claims of
the insolvency creditors from the opening of the insolvency proceedings; (ii) costs incurred by
individual insolvency creditors due to their participation in the proceedings; (iii) fines, regulatory fines,
coercive fines and administrative fines, as well as such incidental legal consequences of a criminal or
administrative offense binding the debtor to pay money; (iv) claims on the debtor’s gratuitous
performance of a consideration; and (v) claims for the restitution of shareholder loans
(Gesellschafterdarlehen) or claims resulting from legal transactions corresponding in economic terms
to such a loan.

While in ordinary insolvency proceedings, the value of the German Security Grantor will be realized
by a piecemeal sale or, as the case may be, by a bulk sale of the entity’s business as a going concern, a
different approach aiming at the rehabilitation of such entities can be taken based on an insolvency plan
(Insolvenzplan). Such plan can be submitted by the debtor or the insolvency administrator and requires,
among other things and subject to certain exceptions, the consent of the German Security Grantor and
the consent of each class of creditors in accordance with specific majority rules and the approval of the
insolvency court (while a group of dissenting creditors or the debtor can—under certain
circumstances—be crammed down). If the debtor is a corporate entity, also the shares or, as the case


-----

may be, the membership rights in the debtor can be included in the insolvency plan, e.g., they can be
transferred to third parties, including a transfer to creditors based on a debt to equity swap. Moreover,
if the debtor has filed a petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings based on an insolvency
reason other than illiquidity (i.e., imminent illiquidity or over indebtedness), combined with a petition
to initiate such process based on a debtor-in-possession status and can, _inter alia, prove that a_
restructuring of its business is not obviously futile (offensichtlich aussichtslos), the court may grant a
period of up to three months to utilize an insolvency plan for the debtor business (Schutzschirm). During
this period, the creditors’ rights to enforce security may—upon application of the filing debtor—be
suspended. Under these circumstances, the insolvency court has to appoint a custodian (Sachwalter) to
supervise the process. The debtor is entitled to suggest an individual to be appointed as custodian with
such suggestion being binding on the insolvency court unless the suggested person is obviously not
eligible to become a custodian (i.e., is obviously not competent or impartial). Under the German
Insolvency Code, the insolvency administrator (or in case of debtor-in-possession proceedings, the
custodian) may void (anfechten) transactions, performances or other acts that are deemed detrimental
to insolvency creditors and which were effected prior to the commencement of formal insolvency
proceedings during applicable voidable periods. Generally, if transactions, performances or other acts
are successfully voided by the insolvency administrator, any amounts or other benefits derived from
such challenged transaction, performance or act will have to be returned to the insolvency estate. The
administrator’s right to void transactions can, depending on the circumstances, extend to transactions
having occurred up to ten years prior to the filing for the commencement of insolvency proceedings.

In the event of insolvency proceedings with respect to the German Security Grantor based on and
governed by the insolvency laws of Germany, the payment of any amounts to the holders could be
subject to potential challenges (i.e., clawback rights) by an insolvency administrator under the rules of
voidness as set out in the German Insolvency Code. In the event such a transaction is successfully
voided (angefochten), the holders of the Notes, as applicable, may not be able to recover or retain any
amounts under the Notes and may participate in the insolvency proceedings as unsecured creditor only.
If payments have already been made under the Notes, any amounts received from a transaction that had
been voided would have to be repaid to the insolvency estate (Insolvenzmasse). In this case, the holders
of the Notes, as applicable, would only have a general unsecured claim under the Notes without
preference in insolvency proceedings. In particular, an act (Rechtshandlung) or a legal transaction
(Rechtsgeschäft) (which term includes the granting of a guarantee, the provision of security and the
payment of debt) detrimental to the creditors of the debtor may be voided according to the German
Insolvency Code (Insolvenzordnung) in the following cases:

  - any act granting an insolvency creditor, or enabling an insolvency creditor to obtain, security
or satisfaction (Befriedigung) if such act was taken (i) during the last three months prior to the
filing of the petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings, provided that the debtor was
illiquid (zahlungsunfähig) at the time such act was taken and the creditor knew of such
illiquidity (or of circumstances that clearly suggest that the debtor was illiquid) at such time, or
(ii) after the filing of the petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings, if the creditor knew
of the debtor’s illiquidity or the filing of such petition (or of circumstances that clearly suggest
such illiquidity or filing);

  - any act granting an insolvency creditor, or enabling an insolvency creditor to obtain, security
or satisfaction (Befriedigung) to which such creditor was not entitled, or which was granted or
obtained in a form or at a time to which or at which such creditor was not entitled to such
security or satisfaction, if (i) such act was taken during the last month prior to the filing of the
petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings or after such filing, (ii) such act was taken
during the second or third month prior to the filing of the petition and the debtor was illiquid at
such time or (iii) such act was taken during the second or third month prior to the filing of the
petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings and the creditor knew at the time such act
was taken that such act was detrimental to the other insolvency creditors (or had knowledge of
circumstances that clearly suggest such detrimental effect);


-----

  - a legal transaction by the debtor that is directly detrimental to the insolvency creditors or by
which the debtor loses a right or the ability to enforce a right or by which a proprietary claim
against a debtor is obtained or becomes enforceable, if it was entered into (i) during the three
months prior to the filing of the petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings and the
debtor was illiquid at the time of such transaction and the counterparty to such transaction knew
of the illiquidity at such time or (ii) after the filing of the petition for the opening of insolvency
proceedings and the counterparty to such transaction knew either of the debtor’s illiquidity or
of such filing at the time of the transaction;

  - any act by the debtor without (adequate) consideration (e.g., whereby a debtor grants security
for a third party debt, which might be regarded as having been granted gratuitously
(unentgeltlich)), if it was effected in the four years prior to the filing of the petition for the
opening of insolvency proceedings;

  - any act performed by the debtor during the ten years prior to the filing of the petition for the
opening of insolvency proceedings or at any time after the filing, if the debtor acted with the
intention of prejudicing its insolvency creditors (vorsätzliche Gläubigerbenachteiligung) and
the beneficiary of the act knew of such intention at the time of such act. In the case that the
relevant act granted a creditor, or enabled a creditor to obtain, security or satisfaction for a debt,
the avoidability of acts is limited to four years. “Knowledge by the beneficiary of the act” in
terms of such provision is presumed if the beneficiary knew that the debtor was illiquid and
that the relevant act disadvantaged the other creditors. The fact that the creditor agreed on a
payment plan with the debtor or agreed to deferred payments shall establish the presumption
that he had no knowledge of the debtor being illiquid at this time.

  - any non-gratuitous contract concluded between the debtor and an affiliated party that directly
operates to the detriment of the creditors can be voided unless such contract was concluded
earlier than two years prior to the filing of the petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings
or the other party had no knowledge of the debtor’s intention to disadvantage its creditors as of
the time the contract was concluded; in relation to corporate entities, the term “affiliated party”
includes, subject to certain limitations, members of the management or supervisory board,
general partners and shareholders owning more than 25% of the debtor’s share capital, persons
or companies holding comparable positions that give them access to information about the
economic situation of the debtor, and other persons who are spouses, relatives or members of
the household of any of the foregoing persons;

  - any act that provides security or satisfaction (Befriedigung) for a claim of a shareholder for
repayment of a shareholder loan or a similar claim if (i) in the case of the provision of security,
the act took place during the last ten years prior to the filing of the petition for the opening of
insolvency proceedings or after the filing of such petition or (ii) in the case of satisfaction, the
act took place during the last year prior to the filing of the petition for the opening of the
insolvency proceedings or after the filing of such petition; or

  - any act whereby the debtor grants satisfaction for a loan claim or an economically equivalent
claim to a third party if (i) the satisfaction was effected in the last year prior to the filing of a
petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings or thereafter, and (ii) a shareholder of the
debtor had granted security or was liable as a guarantor or surety (Garant oder Bürge) (in which
case the shareholder must compensate the debtor for the amounts paid (subject to further
conditions).

In this context, “knowledge” is generally deemed to exist if the other party is aware of the facts from
which the conclusion must be drawn that the debtor was unable to pay its debts generally as they fell
due, that a petition for the opening of insolvency proceedings had been filed, or that the act was
detrimental to, or intended to prejudice, the insolvency creditors, as the case may be. A person deemed
to have knowledge of the debtor’s intention to prejudice the insolvency creditors if he or she knew of


-----

the debtor’s imminent illiquidity and that the transaction prejudiced the debtor’s creditors. With respect
to an “affiliated party”, there is a general statutory presumption that such party had “knowledge.”

The granting of security concurrently with the incurrence of debt may be qualified as a “cash
_transaction” and may as such be privileged, under certain circumstances, under the German Insolvency_
Code (Bargeschäftsprivileg) by not being subject to voidness rights.

Apart from the examples of an insolvency administrator voiding transactions according to the German
Insolvency Code (Insolvenzordnung) described above, a creditor who has obtained an enforcement
order (Vollstreckungstitel) could possibly also void any security right or payment performed under the
relevant security right according to the German Law of Voidness (Anfechtungsgesetz) outside formal
insolvency proceedings. The prerequisites vary to a certain extent from the rules described above and
the voidance periods are calculated from the date a creditor exercises its rights of voidance in the courts.

**_Satisfaction of Subordinated Claims_**

The insolvency estate shall serve to satisfy the liquidated claims held by the personal creditors against
the debtor on the date when the insolvency proceedings were opened. The following claims shall be
satisfied ranking below the other claims of insolvency creditors in the order given below, and according
to the proportion of their amounts if ranking with equal status: (i) interest and penalty payments accrued
on the claims of the insolvency creditors from the opening of the insolvency proceedings; (ii) costs
incurred by individual insolvency creditors due to their participation in the proceedings; (iii) fines,
regulatory fines, coercive fines and administrative fines, as well as such incidental legal consequences
of a criminal or administrative offence binding the debtor to pay money; (iv) claims to the debtor’s
gratuitous performance of a consideration; and (v) claims for restitution of a shareholder loan replacing
equity capital or claims resulting from legal transactions corresponding in economic terms to such a
loan.

**_German StaRUG Scheme_**

Outside of formal insolvency proceedings, an imminent illiquid company can enter into a restructuring
scheme pursuant to the German Act on the Stabilisation and Restructuring Framework for Businesses
(StaRUG). The ability of investors to enforce their rights under the German Security Agreements and
obtain recovery of amounts due and owing under the Notes could also be adversely affected by the
StaRUG restructuring measures, _inter alia, by the implementation of a restructuring plan and_
stabilization measures, in particular a general or individual stay.

During the StaRUG restructuring proceedings, the company can implement restructuring measures by
way of majority vote of the creditors in classes, i.e. even dissenting creditors within a class (cram-down)
and dissenting classes of creditors (cross-class cram-down) may be bound to restructuring measures,
relating to, _inter alia, and including haircuts of unsecured and secured claims and notes, change of_
ownership interests etc.

After the company has given notice to the restructuring court the company can request stabilizing
measures pursuant to section 49 StaRUG (Stabilisierungsanordnung) if they are necessary to preserve
the prospects of achieving the restructuring goal, i.e. a general or individual stay for a duration of up to
three months but no longer than eight months. If the competent court approves the request, enforcement
measures against the company will be prohibited or discontinued on an interim basis
(Vollstreckungssperre) and rights for preferential satisfaction (Absonderungsrecht) or right to
segregation (Aussonderungsrecht) in the event that insolvency proceedings are opened may not be
claimed by the creditor and that the assets subject to those rights may be used to continue the debtor’s
business to the extent that they are of considerable significance for this purpose (Verwertungssperre).
Additionally, section 55 StaRUG stipulates that at the time the stabilization order is issued, the creditor
will not be entitled solely on the basis of overdue performance to refuse performance to be rendered by
it during the duration of the order or assert rights to terminate or modify the contract; this will not affect


-----

the right of the creditor to refuse to provide that part to the counter-performance that is to be rendered
by it in relation to the debtor’s overdue performance.

**Italy**

**_Limitation on Granting of Guarantees and on Enforcement under Italian Law_**

Under Italian law, the entry into of a transaction (including the creation of a security interest or the
granting of a guarantee) by a company incorporated under Italian law must be permitted by the
applicable laws and by its by-laws (statuto sociale) and is subject to compliance with rules on corporate
benefits, corporate authorisation and certain other Italian mandatory provisions. If a guarantee or a
security interest is being provided in the context of an acquisition, group reorganization or restructuring,
financial assistance issues may also be triggered.

An Italian company (each an “Italian Guarantor”) granting a guarantee must receive a real and adequate
benefit in exchange for the guarantee. Such principle on corporate benefit applies equally to downstream, cross-stream and up-stream guarantees granted by Italian companies. While the existence of a
corporate benefit in relation to a downstream guarantee is usually self-evident (i.e., a guarantee
guaranteeing financial obligations of direct or indirect subsidiaries of the relevant guarantor), the
existence of a corporate benefit in relation to a cross-stream or an up-stream guarantee (i.e., a guarantee
guaranteeing financial obligations of direct or indirect parent companies or sister companies of the
relevant guarantor) may be challenged unless it can be proved that the guarantor may derive some
benefits or advantages from the granting of the guarantee, therefore it should be carefully considered
on a case-by-case basis (such as in the case of Subsidiary Guarantors which are providing the
Guarantees in connection with the Notes offered hereby).

The concept of “corporate benefit” is not expressly defined under Italian law and it is assessed and
determined on a case-by-case basis, further its existence is purely a business decision of the directors
and the statutory auditors. As a general rule, corporate benefit is assessed at the level of the relevant
company on a standalone basis, although in certain circumstances, and subject to specific rules, the
interest of the group to which such company belongs may also be taken into consideration. In particular,
in case of up-stream and cross-stream guarantees for the financial obligations of group companies,
examples may include financial consideration in the form of access to cash flows through intercompany
loans from other members of the group, while transactions featuring debt financings of distributions to
shareholders are largely untested in Italian courts, and, therefore, limited guidance is provided as to
whether and to what extent such transactions could be challenged for lack of corporate benefit and
conflict of interest. Generally, the risk assumed by an Italian Guarantor must not be disproportionate to
the direct or indirect economic benefit to such Italian Guarantor.

In principle, absence of a real and adequate benefit could make the Guarantees ultra vires and potentially
affected by conflict of interest and the related corporate resolutions adopted by the shareholders and
directors may be subject matter of challenges and annulment.

As a result, civil liabilities may be imposed on the directors of an Italian Guarantor if it is assessed that
they did not act in the best interest of such Italian Guarantor and that the acts they carried out do not
fall within the corporate purpose of the relevant Italian Guarantor or were against mandatory provisions
of Italian law. The lack of corporate benefit could also result in the imposition of civil liabilities on
those companies or persons ultimately exercising control over an Italian Guarantor or having knowingly
received an advantage or profit from such improper control. However, no liability can be attributed
where no prejudice or actual damage is suffered by the Italian Guarantor because of the determination
of the controlling shareholder as provided under Article 2497 of the Italian Civil Code having regard to
the overall result of the controlling activity. Moreover, the Guarantees could be declared null and void
if the lack of corporate benefit was known or presumed to be known by the third-party involved in the
transaction and such third-party acted intentionally against the interest of such Italian Guarantor.


-----

The above principles on corporate benefit apply equally to up-stream, down-stream or cross-stream
guarantees granted by an Italian Guarantor.

As to corporate authorisations prospective, the granting of a guarantee by an Italian company in favour
of third-parties or other corporations belonging to the same group of companies of the Italian Guarantor
must be permitted by the by-laws (statuto) of the Italian company providing such guarantee.

In addition, the granting of a guarantee by an Italian company cannot include any liability which would
result in unlawful financial assistance within the meaning of Article 2358 or 2474, as the case may be,
of the Italian Civil Code pursuant to which, subject to specific exceptions, it is unlawful for a company
to give financial assistance (whether by means of loans, security, guarantees or otherwise) to support
the acquisition or subscription by a third-party of its own shares or quotas or those of any entity that
(directly or indirectly) controls the Italian company. Financial assistance for refinancing indebtedness
originally incurred for the purchase or subscription of its own shares or quotas or those of its direct or
indirect parent company would also be a violation. Any loan, guarantee or security given or granted in
breach of these provisions is null and void. In addition, directors may be personally liable for failure to
act in the best interests of the company.

In the light of the above, in no event shall the obligations and liabilities of an Italian Guarantor under a
guarantee include the obligation to guarantee financial indebtedness which was incurred, in full or in
part, to purchase the shares of such Italian Guarantor (or of any of its direct or indirect holding company)
and which would therefore constitute the provision of financial assistance within the meaning of Article
2358 and/or Article 2474, as the case may be, of the Italian Civil Code and/or any other law or regulation
having the same effect, as interpreted by Italian courts.

If the proceeds of the Notes were to be used for the acquisition of shares (or quotas, as applicable) in
the Subsidiary Guarantors (the entities which, amongst others, provided the Guarantees) incorporated
in Italy (or of any of its direct or indirect holding company), this may be construed as a violation of
Article 2474 and/or Article 2358 of the Italian Civil Code whereas, in the latter case, an authorisation
proceeding in the shareholders’ meeting is not implemented. To this extent the total value of the
guarantee cannot exceed the profits and the distributable reserves as resulting from the approved
financial statements.

Upon certain conditions, the granting of guarantees may be considered as a restricted financial activity
within the meaning of Article 106 of the Legislative Decree No. 385 of 1 September 1993 (the “Italian
_Banking Act”), whose exercise is exclusively demanded to banks and authorised financial_
intermediaries. Non-compliance with the provisions of the Italian Banking Act may, inter alia, entail
the Guarantees being considered null and void. In this respect, the Ministerial Decree No. 53 of 2 April
2015, implementing Article 106, paragraph 3, of the Italian Banking Act, states that the issuance of
guarantees or security by a company for the obligations of another company which is part of the same
group does not qualify as a restricted financial activity, whereby “group” includes controlling and
controlled companies within the meaning of Article 2359 of the Italian Civil Code as well as companies,
which are under the control of the same entity. As a result of the above described rules, subject to the
Italian Guarantor and the guaranteed entity being part of the same group of companies, the provision of
the guarantees would not amount to a restricted financial activity.

In addition, under Article 1938 of the Italian Civil Code, if a personal guarantee is issued to guarantee
conditional or future obligations, the guarantee must be limited to a maximum amount. Such maximum
amount should be expressly identified at the outset and expressed in figures (either in the guarantee
deed or by reference to a separate document, such as the Indenture). It has been held, that such
determination must be proportionate to the relevant guarantor’s assets. It is uncertain, however, whether
courts are entitled to debate and to rule over such determination.

Italian Law No. 108 of 7 March 1996, as amended, implemented or supplemented from time to time
(the “Italian Usury Law”), prevents lenders from applying interests higher than certain rates, as set forth


-----

in accordance with the Italian Usury Law (the “Usury Rates”). In addition, even where the Usury Rates
are not exceeded, the interest rate applicable may be held usurious if: (i) it is considered to be
disproportionate to the amount lent (taking into account the specific circumstances of the transaction
and the average rate applicable to similar transactions in the market) and (ii) the debtor is deemed to
have been in financial and economic difficulties at the time the indebtedness was incurred.

In order to comply with (i) the Italian Usury Law and Article 1815 of the Italian Civil Code) and (ii)
the mandatory provisions of Italian law in relation to capitalization of interests (including Article 1283
of the Italian Civil Code), the obligations of any Italian Guarantor under a guarantee shall not include
and shall not extend to (x) Usury Rates and (y) any interest on overdue amounts compounded in
violation of the provisions set forth by Article 1283 of the Italian Civil Code, respectively.

In any event, pursuant to Article 1938 of the Italian Civil Code, a guarantee granted by an Italian
Guarantor must be capped to a maximum guaranteed amount.

**_Certain Italian Insolvency Law Considerations_**

The Italian laws and regulations on insolvency have recently been replaced by a new comprehensive
regulatory framework in order to regulate, inter alia, the matter of insolvency (the so-called “Codice
_della crisi d’impresa e dell’insolvenza”, hereinafter the “Insolvency Code”). In particular, on 12 January_
2019, the Italian Government approved Legislative Decree No. 14 of 12 January 2019 implementing
the guidelines contained in Law No. 155 of 19 October 2017, setting forth the outline of a new
comprehensive regulatory framework for the purpose of regulating, inter alia, the matter of insolvency
(the “Legislative Decree”), which enacts the Insolvency Code.

The main changes introduced by the Insolvency Code include: (i) the suppression of the term
“bankrupt” because of its negative connotation and the replacement of the bankruptcy procedure
(bankruptcy) with a judicial liquidation; (ii) a new definition of “state of crisis”; (iii) the endorsement
of the same procedural framework for the ascertainment of such state of crisis and for admission to the
different judicial insolvency procedures set forth in the Insolvency Code itself; (iv) the introduction of
the definition of the debtor’s centre of main interests’ as provided for in the new set of rules on group
restructurings; (v) restrictions on the use of composition with creditors in order to promote business
continuity; (vi) the introduction of provisions dedicated to groups of companies; (vii) the competence
of specialist courts for proceedings involving major debtors; (viii) the introduction of specific
provisions in relation to the adoption of measures and agreements aimed at the early detection of
business crisis; and (ix) amendments to certain provisions of the Italian Civil Code aimed at ensuring
the general effectiveness of the reform. The Insolvency Code was amended and supplemented, inter
alia, by Legislative Decree No. 147 of 26 October 2020 (as amended and supplemented, most recently,
by Legislative Decree No. 83 of 17 June 2022), providing the first corrective intervention to the
Insolvency Code.

The following is a brief description of the main provisions of the types of procedures under the
Insolvency Code, which replaced the Royal Decree no. 267 of 16 March 1942 (the “Bankruptcy Law”)
after the Insolvency Code came into force (on 15 July, 2022):

- judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale) under the Insolvency Code;

- composition with creditors (concordato preventivo) under the Insolvency Code;

- negotiated crisis composition procedure (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa) under the
Insolvency Code;

- simplified composition with creditors proceeding (concordato semplificato per la liquidazione del
patrimonio) under the Insolvency Code;


-----

- certified restructuring plans (piani attestati di risanamento) under the Insolvency Code;

- debt-restructuring agreements (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti) under the Insolvency Code;

- restructuring plans subject to homologation (piani di ristrutturazione soggetti a omologazione)
under the Insolvency Code.

The aforementioned restructuring/insolvency tools are available under the Insolvency Code for
insolvent companies or debtors in a state of crisis, as the case may be, and, in some cases, also for
debtors whose economic or financial imbalance is such that a state of crisis and/or distress or their
insolvency is likely to occur. For the sake of completeness, it should be noted that the Insolvency Code
also provides for a simplified arrangement with creditors (concordato minore), in cases where the debtor
does not meet the size requirements for access to other restructuring instruments, which follows the
main procedural steps and effects provided for the composition with creditors (concordato preventivo),
but includes the involvement and assistance to the debtor of the crisis resolution body (organismo di
_risoluzione della crisi)._

In addition, the following is a brief summary of the procedures, which are still available to major
companies even in the framework of the new rules provided by the reform process.

- extraordinary administration for large insolvent companies (amministrazione straordinaria delle
grandi imprese insolventi), under the Decree 270; and

- extraordinary administration for the industrial restructuring of large insolvent companies
(amministrazione straordinaria per la ristrutturazione industriale delle grandi imprese insolventi),
under the Law Decree No. 39 of 18 February 2004, as amended (“Decree 347”). For businesses
performing essential public services, this type of proceedings would also be subject to the Law
Decree 134 of 28 August 2008 (“Decree 134”).

Below there is a summary description of the compulsory liquidation procedure as well (procedura di
_liquidazione coatta amministrativa)._

**_Definition of “insolvency” and “crisis” under the Insolvency Code_**

The Insolvency Code introduced a specific definition of a crisis, which is defined in Article 2 (a) of the
Insolvency Code as the debtor’s state such that insolvency is considered as likely, manifesting as the
inadequacy of prospective cash flows to meet obligations in the following 12 months.

Insolvency is defined by Article 2 (b) of the Insolvency Code as the debtor’s inability to meet its
obligations regularly as they fall due, as evidenced by defaults and/or other exogenous factors.

Both insolvency and crisis are factual situations upon the occurrence of which several instruments
provided for in the Insolvency Code can be triggered.

**_The Judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale) under the Insolvency Code_**

The Judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale) under the Insolvency Code is a court-supervised
procedure aimed at the liquidation of the assets of the insolvent company and the distribution of the
relevant income.

Under the Insolvency Code, judicial liquidation is declared by the competent court and is enforceable
by satisfying the following two requirements:

(i) an objective requirement, which is met if any of the following criteria is met, and specifically:


-----

(a) annual assets (attivo patrimoniale) exceeding 300,000 euros in the last three financial years
(as of the date of filing of the petition for judicial liquidation) or since the company’s
incorporation if the company was incorporated less than three years prior to the filing of the
petition for judicial liquidation;

(b) annual gross revenues (ricavi lordi) exceeding 200.000 in the last three financial years (as
of the date of filing of the petition for judicial liquidation) or since the company’s
incorporation if the company was incorporated less than three years prior to the filing of the
petition for judicial liquidation; or

(c) indebtedness (including debt that is not overdue and payable) greater than 500,000 euros;
and

(ii) a subjective requirement, which is satisfied when the debtor is a commercial company

(imprenditori commerciali) engaged in business activity and is insolvent.

Judicial liquidation is opened and declared by the competent courts following a request specifically
filed by (i) the debtor itself; (ii) the administrative bodies and authorities that have functions of control
and supervision over the company; (iii) one or more creditors; and (iv) in certain cases, the Public
Prosecutor.

With the opening of judicial liquidation proceedings, the courts appoint (among other things) a receiver,
as well as the debtor loses management control over all of its assets and the administration of its
business, which is assumed by the court-appointed receiver.

In principle, as of the date of the opening of the judicial liquidation, a suspension of action shall apply,
and executive and provisional proceedings cannot be initiated or continued against the debtor on the
assets included in the estate. And specifically, at the opening of the judicial liquidation, inter alia:

(i) with some exceptions, all creditor actions are suspended, and creditors must file claims within a

specified period;

(ii) the debtor’s administration and management of its assets are transferred to the receiver. The debtor

can no longer legally act as a plaintiff or defendant in court in relation to the assets, and the receiver
is granted these powers by permission of the delegated judge. However, all pending proceedings
in which the debtor is involved are automatically suspended from the date of the issuance of the
judgment and must be resumed by or against the receiver;

(iii) the business continuation may be authorized by the court, but only if the business continuation does

not lead to damages to creditors. If the court authorizes the continuation of the business (esercizio
_provvisorio dell’impresa), the management is entrusted to the curator (who may himself use third_
parties qualified for this scope);

(iv) any act (including payments, pledges, and the giving of guarantees/security) performed by the

debtor, except those carried out through the receiver, after (and in some cases even before for a
limited period of time) the opening of the judicial liquidation becomes (or may become if
performed before) ineffective against creditors and/or may be recovered; and

(v) the execution of certain contracts and/or transactions in progress at the date of the bankruptcy filing

is suspended until the receiver has decided whether to enter into them. While the general rule is
that the receiver may continue or terminate contracts in which some or all of the obligations have
not been performed by both parties, some contracts are subject to specific rules expressly provided
for in the Insolvency Code. In order to overcome the uncertainty that may be foreseeably arising,
the other party to the contract may file a written request asking the court to grant the receiver a
time limit of no more than 60 days; within that period, the receiver must decide whether to enter
into the agreement or to terminate it. After the deadline expires without the receiver responding to
the other party’s request, the pending agreement is considered terminated. Even though the general


-----

rule is that the receiver may resolve agreements in which some or all of the obligations have not
been fulfilled, some agreements are subject to special rules expressly set forth in the Insolvency
Code.

Specific exceptions in law apply to certain claims secured by mortgages, pledges or guarantees
including, among others:

(i) mortgages securing loans pursuant to Articles 38 et seq. of the Legislative Decree September 1,

1993, n. 385 (“Consolidated Banking Act”) (so called “mutuo fondiario”): such mortgages may be
enforced by the lender even after the opening of judicial liquidation against the debtor;

(ii) pledges under Decree no. 170 dated 21 May 2004 (so called “financial pledge” (pegno

_finanziario)): on the occurrence of an enforcement event, the related secured creditor may instantly_
sell the pledged financial assets and hold an amount equal to the secured obligation, although
bankruptcy proceedings have been opened;

(iii) pledges on movable property: creditors secured by pledges on the debtor’s movable property may

be authorized to sell the pledged assets during the proceeding, subject to admission to the
bankruptcy estate (ammissione allo stato passivo) under collateral rank;

(iv) third-party guarantees: even after the opening of the judicial liquidation, creditors may choose to

enforce any guarantees (and/or security interests) provided by third parties in the interest of the
bankrupt debtor.

Regarding claims against the judicial liquidation procedure, each creditor must file his or her claims
with the competent court. The creditor’s filing of proof of claim is necessary to prove the creditor’s
right to participate in the liquidation, the amount of his claim, and his standing. The judge delegated
(Giudice delegato) by the court, upon the proposal of the liquidator, will decide which claims are
admitted to the statement of liabilities (stato passivo), for what amount they are admitted, and whether
the claims are to be qualified as secured or unsecured. Any creditor may challenge (opposizione) the
judge’s decision before the court. The same procedure also applies to physical and legal persons
claiming the right to obtain the return of assets. The sale of the debtor’s assets is carried out by the
liquidator-or the delegate-through public auctions, in accordance with a liquidation program proposed
by the receiver and approved by the creditors’ committee. The creditors are then refunded with the
proceeds of the liquidation, which is managed by the receiver in accordance with the principle of equal
treatment of creditors (so-called par condicio creditorum) and in keeping with the legal order of priority
among creditors.

Further to the above, it should be noted that at the opening of the judicial liquidation, certain acts,
payments, guarantees, or security interests may be declared ineffective and/or revoked under the
Insolvency Code.

The transactions that can be annulled through a bankruptcy claw-back action under Article 166 of the
Insolvency Code can be divided into two categories:

(i) transactions that can be annulled by the receiver unless the counterparty can prove that it had no

knowledge of the debtor’s insolvency (Article 166(1) of the Insolvency Code), and specifically:

(a) transactions at a lower value made after the filing followed by the opening of judicial
liquidation proceedings or in the previous year (this period is extended to 2 years for
intercompany transactions);

(b) repayment of a debt by means other than money or other common methods of payment after
the filing followed by the opening of the judicial liquidation proceeding or in the previous
year (such term is extended to 2 years for intercompany transactions);


-----

(c) pledges and voluntary mortgages created in the year preceding the filing of judicial
liquidation petition to secure pre-existing debts not yet overdue;

(d) pledges and judicial or voluntary mortgages created after the filing followed by the opening
of the judicial liquidation proceeding or in the prior six months (such term is extended to 1
year for intercompany transactions);

(ii) transactions made after the filing followed by the opening of judicial liquidation proceedings or

within the preceding six months, which may be annulled if the receiver proves that the other party
had knowledge of the debtor’s insolvency (Article 166(2) of the Insolvency Code) and, in
particular:

(a) payments of debts due and payable;

(b) transactions for valuable consideration;

(c) transactions creating priority rights/security interests relating to simultaneously incurred
debts.

In addition to the above, under article 166 of the Insolvency Code, the following operations are exempt
from claw back actions:

(i) payments for goods or services made in the ordinary course of business in accordance with

customary market standards;

(ii) a transfer to a bank account (rimesse effettuate su un conto corrente bancario); on condition that

it does not substantially and permanently reduce the entity’s debt to the bank;

(iii) a sale, including a sale and purchase agreement registered pursuant to Article 2645-bis of the Italian

Civil Code, carried out for fair value and involving a residential property intended as the principal
residence of the purchaser or the purchaser’s family (within three degrees of relationship) or a nonresidential property intended as the principal place of business of the purchaser; provided that, as
of the date of the declaration of insolvency, business is actually carried on there or investments
have been made there for the start-up of such business;

(iv) entered into transactions, payments made or guarantees granted in respect of the debtor’s assets,

provided that they concern the implementation of a certified plan of rehabilitation (piano attestato
_di risanamento) pursuant to Articles 56 or 284 of the Insolvency Code;_

(v) a stipulated transaction, payment made or guarantee or security interest granted in the context of

composition proceedings (concordato preventivo), a restructuring plan subject to approval (piano
_di ristrutturazione soggetto ad omologazione) under Article 64-bis of the Insolvency Code or_
approved debt restructuring agreements (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti omologati) and/or
stipulated transactions, payments made and security lawfully granted by the debtor after the filing
of an application for composition proceedings (concordato preventivo) or a debt restructuring
agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti). The exemption also operates for ordinary clawback;

(vi) payments of compensation to employees and consultants of the entity in connection with work

performed by them; and

(vii) payments of a debt immediately due, payable, and made on the due date in connection with

services required for access to restructuring and insolvency facilities under the Insolvency Code.

Pursuant to Article 170 of the Insolvency Code, the limitation period for starting a claw-back action is
three years from the opening of the judicial liquidation proceedings or five years from the act or
transaction to be recovered, whichever is earlier. In case the judicial liquidation is opened after the filing


-----

of a petition for admission to insolvency proceedings, pursuant to Article 170(2) of the Insolvency
Code, the limitation period shall be calculated backward from the date of filing of such petition.

Pursuant to Article 165 of the Insolvency Code, which refers back to Article 2901 of the Italian Civil
Code (which - in turn - provides for an ordinary and general claw-back action (azione revocatoria
_ordinaria) - which can be exercised against the debtor (and its counterparty) even if no judicial_
liquidation proceedings are pending), acts by which the debtor disposes of its assets (other than
payments of sums due and payable) may be revoked if the receiver can demonstrate that the debtor was
aware of the prejudice that such act would cause to his creditors (including future creditors, to the extent
that the act was done for the purpose of causing such prejudice) and, to the extent that the act was
unrewarding, the other party was aware of such prejudice.

In addition, pursuant to article 163 of the Insolvency Code, subject to certain limited exception, all
transactions entered into for no consideration are ineffective vis-à-vis creditors if entered into by the
debtor after the filing to the relevant court followed by the opening of the judicial winding-up procedure
or within the two years preceding the opening of such insolvency proceeding. Any asset subject to a
transaction which is ineffective pursuant to article 163 of the Insolvency Code becomes part of the
liquidation estate by operation of law upon registration of the court’s decision opening the insolvency
proceeding (trascrizione della sentenza che ha dichiarato l’apertura della procedura concorsuale),
without needing to wait for the ineffectiveness of the transaction to be sanctioned by a court. Any
interested person may challenge the registration before the delegated judge as a violation of law.

In addition, pursuant to Article 164 of the Insolvency Code, among other things, the following are
ineffective against creditors:

(i) payments of claims overdue on or after the day of the declaration of the opening of judicial

liquidation, if made by the debtor after the filing of the petition followed by the opening of the
insolvency proceeding or in the prior two-year period; and

(ii) payments made by the debtor in connection with any intercompany loan, if made by the debtor

after the filing of the petition followed by the opening of insolvency proceedings or in the preceding
year.

The Insolvency Code contains special regimes for preferences and avoidance of intercompany
transactions. Specifically, under Article 290 of the Insolvency Code, the statute of limitations for
initiating intra-group claw-back actions (which refer to acts and transactions carried out by companies
within the same group that have resulted in shifting resources to another group company to the detriment
of creditors, subject to certain exceptions) is extended to five years from the filing of the judicial
liquidation.

Article 2929-bis of the Italian Civil Code (introduced by Law 132/2015) provides for a “simplified”
claw-back action with reference to certain typologies of operations conducted by the debtor without any
consideration and with the purpose of removing registered assets from foreclosure by its creditors. The
creditor may initiate enforcement proceedings on the assets in question without having previously
obtained a court decision removing or annulling the fraudulent transaction in question. In the case of
gratuitous transactions, enforcement action may also be brought by the creditor against the third-party
purchaser.

According to Italian law, the income from the sale of the debtor’s assets is distributed according to the
legal rules of priority. Neither the debtor nor the court can depart from these priority rules by proposing
its own priority of claims or by subordinating one claim to another based on principles of equitable
subordination (consequently, it should be noted that payment priorities such as those commonly
provided for in intercreditor contractual agreements cannot be enforced against an Italian judicial
liquidation estate to the extent that they conflict with the priorities provided by law). The law creates a
priority of claims that must be respected in the distribution of proceeds from the sale of all or part of


-----

the debtor’s assets, or of a single asset. According to Article 221 of the Insolvency Code, among other
things, the income from the liquidation of the assets must be distributed in the following order: (i) for
the payment of preferential claims (crediti prededucibili), including, among others, claims originated
by the insolvency proceedings, such as expenses related to the proceedings; (ii) for the payment of
preferential claims, such as claims of secured creditors; and (iii) for the payment of claims of unsecured
creditors (creditori chirigrafari).

Under Italian law, the claims with the highest priority (after payment of court costs) are the claims of
preferential creditors, including, among others, claims whose priority is legally vested (e.g., repayment
of salvage or provisional financing), claims of the Italian tax authorities and social security institutions,
and claims for employees’ wages. The remaining priority claims are, in order of priority, those related
to secured creditors (creditori privilegiati); a preference in payment in most, but not exclusively,
provided for by law, mortgages (creditori ipotecari), pledges (creditori pignoratizi), and, finally,
unsecured creditors (creditori chirigrafari).

**_Bankruptcy composition agreement with creditors (concordato nella liquidazione giudiziale)_**

According to Article 240 of the Insolvency Code, judicial liquidation proceedings may be concluded
prior to liquidation through an arrangement in bankruptcy (concordato nella liquidazione giudiziale),
provided certain requirements are met. The relevant application may be presented by one or more
creditors or third parties after the judicial liquidation is opened and even before the decree declaring the
effectiveness of the statement of liabilities (decreto che rende esecutivo lo stato passivo) is issued, as
long as, on the basis of the available accounting data and other relevant information, the receiver can
establish a temporary list of creditors to be submitted to the delegated judge for approval, while the
debtor (or its subsidiaries or jointly controlled companies) may submit such a proposal only after one
year from the judgment under which the judicial liquidation was opened, but within two years from the
decree declaring the effectiveness of the statement of liabilities (decreto che rende esecutivo lo stato
_passivo), on condition that the proposal includes the provision of funds that will increase the value of_
assets by at least 10%.

The proposal shall be submitted to the competent judge, shall then be approved by the creditors and
finally by the court. In case the court’s decree approving the bankruptcy composition agreement with
creditors (concordato nella liquidazione giudiziale) becomes final (definitivo), the court declares the
judicial liquidation to be closed and terminated, initiating the enactment phase of the bankruptcy
composition agreement with creditors. In the context of a bankruptcy composition agreement with
creditors (concordato nella liquidazione giudiziale), the competent court supervises both the proposal
and execution phases while the judicial receiver, once the liquidation is closed, loses his management
functions and retains only supervisory duties over the fulfillment of the terms and the conditions of the
arrangement obligations arising from or in connection with the bankruptcy composition agreement with
creditors (concordato nella liquidazione giudiziale).

The proposal may provide for:

(i) the subdivision of creditors into different classes according to homogeneous legal position and

economic interests;

(ii) differential treatment between creditors belonging to different classes, indicating the reasons of

such differences;

(iii) debts’ rescheduling and the satisfaction of creditors’ claims in any manner, including, by way of

example, by assignment of assets, assumption (accollo) as well as by means of other extraordinary
transactions, including the assignment to creditors (as well as to companies in which they have an
interest), of shares, quotas or bonds, including those convertible into shares or other financial
instruments and debt securities.


-----

The petition may also contemplate the option for secured claims to be paid only in part. However, it is
necessary for the relevant proposal that the plan provides for their satisfaction to an extent not less than
that realizable, due to the preferential placement, from the corresponding income in the event of judicial
liquidation, having regard to the value in the market attributable to the assets or rights on which the
cause of pre-emption exists.

The proposed bankruptcy composition agreement with creditors (concordato nella liquidazione
_giudiziale) must have the approval of the creditors’ committee and the creditors holding most of the_
claims (and, in case of class formation, most of the claims of the majority of the classes). Secured
creditors have no right to vote on the proposal unless (i) they waive their security interest; or (ii) the
bankruptcy composition agreement with creditors provides that they will not receive full satisfaction of
the fair market value of their secured assets (note that such value must be assessed by an independent
expert), in which case they may vote only with respect to the portion of their debt affected by the
proposal. Final confirmation by the court is also required.

The bankruptcy composition agreement with creditors (concordato nella liquidazione giudiziale), once
approved and homologated, is mandatory for: (i) all creditors existing prior to the opening of the judicial
liquidation proceedings; and (ii) creditors who have not filed for admission to the judicial liquidation
estate, to whom the security interests or guarantees provided by third parties in the bankruptcy
arrangement (concordato nella liquidazione giudiziale) do not extend.

At the end of the judicial liquidation - following the homologation decree (decreto di omologa), which
pursuant to Article 247 of the Insolvency Code may be appealed and filed within 30 days of its
notification - the debtor returns “in bonis.”

**_Composition with creditors (concordato preventivo) under the Insolvency Code_**

Prior to the opening of judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale), a debtor that is in a situation of
crisis or insolvency may file an application for composition with creditors (“concordato preventivo”)
under the Insolvency Code in order to settle its overall indebtedness and/or restructure its business,
thereby avoiding the declaration of insolvency and the opening of bankruptcy proceedings.

The proposal for composition may be submitted by a commercial enterprise (imprenditore
_commerciale) that exceeds one of the following thresholds: (i) annual assets (attivo patrimoniale)_
exceeding 300,000 euros in the last three financial years (from the date of submission of the petition for
judicial winding-up) or since the incorporation of the company if it was incorporated less than three
years prior to the petition for composition; (ii) annual gross revenues (ricavi lordi) exceeding 200,000
euros in the last three financial years (from the date of submission of the petition for composition) or
since the incorporation of the company if the company was incorporated less than three years prior to
the petition for composition; and (iii) indebtedness (including debts that are not due and payable)
exceeding 500,000 euros.

Only the debtor itself may file the composition petition before the court located at the place where the
debtor’s head office is located.

The petition for composition must be accompanied by a series of mandatory documents and
attachments, including, inter alia, a reorganisation plan, the contents of which must meet the specific
requirements set forth in the Insolvency Code, including, but not limited to, a description of the reasons
why the company is in a difficult situation, a description of the group and the company’s business, and
the liquidation value of the company’s assets in a court-ordered liquidation scenario, the content of the
restructuring proposal to the creditors and a report prepared by an independent third-party expert
meeting certain professional requirements certifying the veracity of the data on which the plan is based
and its feasibility, a copy of the company’s financial statements for the last three financial years, as well
as the company’s up-to-date economic and financial accounts, an exhaustive description of the
company’s assets and a list of the company’s creditors, indicating their names, the amount of their


-----

claims and the ranking of those claims. In addition, pursuant to the Insolvency Code, the debtor must
file a report describing all acts and transactions exceeding the ordinary course of business performed
by the company in the preceding five years; a description of possible actions for damages, as well as
possible recovery actions and lawsuits that could be brought against the company and its corporate
bodies in a judicial liquidation scenario; and, if the company belongs to a group, some additional
information on the group itself.

Pursuant to Articles 39 para. 3 and 44 of the Insolvency Code, the debtor may submit a ‘preliminary
and simplified application’ for admission to the arrangement procedure (so-called ‘concordato in
_bianco’ or ‘concordato con riserva’), i.e. he may request the court to grant a time limit - from a_
minimum of 30 days to a maximum of 60 days - within which to file the ‘complete application’,
including the arrangement plan and all other necessary documents. In the case of filing a ‘simplified
application’, the company need only attach to the relevant application: (i) a copy of the company’s
financial statements for the last three financial years; and (ii) a list of the company’s creditors, indicating
the name of the relevant creditor, the amount and ranking of its claim against the company, as well as
its digital domicile (domicilio digitale). According to the Insolvency Code, within the aforementioned
time limit the company also has the option to file (instead of the application for full arrangement) a
petition for approval of the debt restructuring agreement pursuant to Article 57 of the Insolvency Code
or approval of a restructuring plan subject to homologation pursuant to Article 64-bis of the Insolvency
Code. This time limit may be extended once for a further maximum of 60 days upon request of the
undertaking, provided that there are reasonable grounds (giustificati motivi) for such extension and that
no petitions for the opening of judicial liquidation are pending against the undertaking. If the debtor
fails to file the proposal, plan, expert’s report and other documents within the prescribed time limit, the
court shall not admit the debtor’s request and, if the criteria set forth in the Insolvency Code are met,
the court may open the compulsory liquidation upon request of a creditor or the public prosecutor. After
the court’s grant the time limit and until its expiration, the debtor must comply with the monthly
information undertakings set forth by the court, including, inter alia, the information undertakings
relating to the debtor’s financial management and the activities carried out to finalise the debtor’s
reorganisation plan and proposal to creditors. In addition, the debtor must file an updated report on the
company’s financial situation with the court on a monthly basis, which is then published in the
competent commercial register.

After the court’s grant of the time limit and until its expiration, the debtor must comply with the monthly
information undertakings set forth by the court, including, inter alia, the information undertakings
relating to the debtor’s financial management and the activities carried out to finalise the debtor’s
reorganisation plan and proposal to creditors. In addition, the debtor must file an updated report on the
company’s financial situation to the court on a monthly basis, which is then published in the competent
commercial register. Pending the aforementioned deadline, the debtor may carry out both ordinary
management activities and urgent extraordinary management activities, provided that, in the latter case,
it has been duly authorised in advance by the Court. After the filing of the preliminary and simplified
petition by the company, a Prejudicial Commissioner (pre-commissario giudiziale) is appointed, who
will supervise the proceedings and will have to examine - inter alia and jointly with the Court – all
claims of the company relating to the performance of extraordinary management activities. All thirdparty claims that may arise from acts legally performed by the debtor after the filing will be considered
super-senior (prededucibili).

The petition for composition is published by the debtor in the commercial register by the court registry
and communicated to the public prosecutor. From the date of such publication to the date of approval
of the composition agreement by the court, pre-existing creditors may not obtain security rights (unless
authorized by the court in advance) and mortgages registered within 90 days prior to the date of
publication of the composition agreement application in the commercial register are ineffective against
such pre-existing creditors.

Pursuant to Article 54(2) of the Insolvency Code, provided that the application for admission to the
composition procedure contains the relevant request for precautionary measures, from the date of


-----

publication of the application in the commercial register it is prohibited to initiate or prosecute
enforcement and precautionary measures (or, in any event, to engage in any initiative prohibited by the
relevant measures). The final decision on such an application (which is provisionally effective as of its
publication in the commercial register) shall be taken by the competent court and the duration of the
stay of the action shall be a maximum of four months (subject to extensions in certain circumstances,
in any event not exceeding a total period of twelve months). During the pendency of the action, inter
alia, the court may not open judicial liquidation. Precautionary measures may be revoked by the courts
upon the occurrence of certain circumstances, including, but not limited to, the discovery of fraudulent
acts by the debtor. The debtor may request, with a subsequent application, the granting of additional
protective measures to prevent certain actions of one or more creditors from prejudicing the successful
outcome of the steps taken to settle the crisis or insolvency at the negotiation stage. The aforementioned
measures may also be required by the debtor pursuant to Article 44 of the Insolvency Code, together
with a preliminary and simplified application for access to one of the restructuring instruments provided
for in the Insolvency Code. Unless specific provisions of the law or collective agreements (contratti
_collettivi) apply, a company employing more than 15 employees must inform the trade union_
representatives concerned in writing of the decisions taken during the drafting of the composition plan
and which have an impact on the employment contracts of a certain number of employees, including in
the event that such decisions affect work organisation and/or working arrangements. Trade union
representatives may request a meeting with the company within 3 days of receiving such notice and the
subsequent consultation between the parties shall commence within 5 days thereafter and – unless
otherwise agreed – shall last no longer than 10 days.

In addition to the above, at the time of the filing of the application for the arrangement (including the
filing of a simplified petition), inter alia (i) as a general rule, the company’s pecuniary obligations are
deemed due on the date of the filing of the arrangement; (ii) set-off is permitted only if (a) all
claims/debts subject to set-off arose prior to the filing date; or (b) all claims/debts subject to set-off
arose after the filing date; (iii) the accrual of interest on unsecured claims is suspended. Interest on
secured claims will continue to accrue according to the specific rules set forth in the Insolvency Code.

Any act, payment or security executed or created after the submission of the request for composition
with creditors (concordato preventivo) and in accordance with its rules and procedures shall be exempt
from claw-back action. The debtor shall also be exempt from certain bankruptcy offences provided for
in Articles 322(3) (“preferential bankruptcy”) and 323 (“simple bankruptcy”) of the Insolvency Code,
in relation to acts and payments made in execution of the composition agreement and/or in relation to
financing provided pursuant to Article 99 of the Insolvency Code with judicial authorisation. Claims
arising from acts lawfully performed by the company in crisis have absolute priority (prededucibili) in
the event of subsequent judicial liquidation.

The composition plan may be aimed at (i) the direct or indirect continuation of the business activity (socalled “concordato in continuità aziendale”) – in which case, the creditors are satisfied (in whole or in
part) with the proceeds from the continuation of the business activity; or (ii) the liquidation of the
company’s assets (so-called “concordato con liquidazione del patrimonio”) – in which case, the
composition plan must necessarily provide for an injection of liquidity, from third parties, that can
increase the available assets by at least 10% and ensure a minimum recovery of at least 20% for
unsecured creditors.

The proposal filed in connection with the petition for composition may provide for: (i) the restructuring
and payment of debts and the satisfaction of creditors’ claims (provided that, in any event, it ensures
the payment of at least 20% of unsecured claims, except in the case of an arrangement as a going concern
(concordato in continuità aziendale)), including through extraordinary transactions, such as the
granting to creditors and their subsidiaries or affiliates of shares, bonds (including bonds convertible
into shares), or other financial instruments and debt securities) (ii) the transfer of the assets of the debtor
company submitting the proposal for composition to an assumptor (assuntore); (iii) the division of
creditors into classes (mandatory in certain cases under Article 85 of the Insolvency Code), provided
that each class is composed of creditors having homogeneous legal positions and economic interests;


-----

and (iv) the different treatment of creditors belonging to different classes. The proposal for composition
may also contain a proposal for a tax settlement for the partial or deferred payment of certain taxes.

It should be noted that a composition with creditors qualifies as a going concern (in continuità
_aziendale) when the plan envisages the continuation, on a direct or indirect basis, of the business activity_
by the debtor business and the creditors are satisfied – even if not predominantly – through the proceeds
deriving from the continuation of the business activity. Pursuant to Article 84 of the Insolvency Code,
business continuity must safeguard the interests of creditors and, to the maximum extent possible, the
company’s employment levels.

Moreover, some specific rules apply only to composition proceedings with business continuity (in
_continuità aziendale). In particular, inter alia:_

(i) pursuant to Article 84(6) of the Insolvency Code, in an arrangement procedure with business

continuity (in continuità aziendale): (a) the proceeds arising from the liquidation of the company’s
assets are distributed to creditors according to the so-called “absolute priority rule”; (b) the
proceeds arising from the continuation of the business activity (i.e, exceeding the liquidation value)
may be distributed according to the so-called “relative priority rule”, meaning that it is not
mandatory to distribute them according to the ranking of the creditors, but it is sufficient to ensure
that all classes of creditors sharing the same ranking are treated equally and more favourably than
classes of creditors of lower ranking. Notwithstanding the foregoing, secured claims within the
meaning of Article 2751-bis of the Italian Civil Code (i.e. wages) must be satisfied in accordance
with the “absolute priority rule”;

(ii) division into classes is mandatory. Classes must also be created with respect to secured creditors,

unless they are repaid in full by cash within 180 days (reduced to 30 days for employees) after
approval without any waiver of their security interests. So-called “impresere minori” (i.e.
enterprises not subject to judicial liquidation) that are unsecured creditors of the enterprise under
contracts for the supply of goods or services will be placed in different classes;

(iii) subject to the provisions of Article 109 of the Insolvency Code, pursuant to Article 86 of the

Insolvency Code, the composition plan as a going concern (in continuità aziendale) may provide
for a suspension for secured creditors, which may extend up to six months from the date of
approval of the composition proposal for the payment of secured creditors (creditori privilegiati)
pursuant to Article 2751-bis of the Italian Civil Code (e.g. employees, professionals, etc.).

(iv) the composition plan for an arrangement with creditors on a going-concern basis (in continuità

_aziendale) must indicate, inter alia, the financial impact of the plan and the timeframe required to_
achieve the rebalancing of the company’s financial situation. In addition, where the plan envisages
the direct continuation of the business activity, the plan must contain a detailed indication of the
expected costs and revenues, financial requirements and related cash flows, also considering the
costs necessary to ensure compliance with applicable labour and environmental laws;

(v) the expert’s report must certify that the plan is aimed at overcoming or preventing the company’s

insolvency and ensuring its economic sustainability. In addition, the expert’s report must confirm
that the treatment (recovery) of creditors in the arrangement is no worse than the treatment
(recovery) of creditors in a judicial liquidation;

(vi) creditors may not unilaterally refuse to perform their obligations under ongoing agreements, nor

may they terminate or accelerate them or modify them in a manner detrimental to the debtor solely
on the grounds of the debtor’s application for an arrangement as a going concern (in continuità
_aziendale). Any contrary provision shall be ineffective. Notwithstanding the foregoing, creditors_
affected by the protective measures may not unilaterally refuse to perform their obligations arising
from “essential contracts in progress” nor may they terminate or advance their due dates or modify
them in a detrimental manner to the debtor solely on the ground of the debtor’s non-payment of
claims arising prior to the filing of the application for an arrangement as a going concern.


-----

According to the Insolvency Code, essential pending contracts (contratti essenziali in corso di
_esecuzione) if it is necessary for the continuation of ordinary business (in continuità aziendale),_
including supply contracts, the termination of which could prevent the company from continuing
its business.

Pursuant to Article 100 of the Insolvency Code, inter alia, a debtor who files for an arrangement as a
going concern (in continuità aziendale) may request the court to authorise the payment (i) of debts that
arose prior to the filing of the arrangement in connection with the supply of goods or services essential
to the business, provided that an independent expert certifies that they are essential to the continuation
of the business and to ensure the best satisfaction of creditors and (ii) in accordance with the relevant
contractual terms, of the instalments due under a loan agreement secured by a security interest in assets
used in the business, provided that (a) on the filing date, the debtor has fulfilled its obligations under
the agreement, or the court authorises the payment of the debt for principal and interest due on that date
and (b) an independent third-party expert certifies that such payments are essential for the continuation
of the business activity and serve to ensure the best satisfaction of creditors and that the secured claims
can be satisfied in full with the proceeds of the liquidation of the asset, carried out at market value, and
that the repayment of the instalments does not prejudice the rights of other creditors.

As previously mentioned, pursuant to Article 84 of the Insolvency Code, in a composition with creditors
without going-concern (“ con liquidazione del patrimonio”), the composition (concordato) proposal
must provide for a contribution (injection of liquidity) of resources by a third party, capable of
increasing the assets (attivo) available to creditors at the date of filing by at least 10% and ensuring a
minimum recovery of at least 20% for unsecured creditors. Third-party resources subject to the
mandatory contribution may also be distributed to creditors irrespective of their ranking, provided that
the aforementioned 20% minimum recovery is achieved. According to the Insolvency Code,
contributions made by the company’s shareholders without any obligation of repayment by the
company (as well as contributions by shareholders that are fully and expressly subordinated) qualify as
“third-party contributions” for the purposes of Section 84 of the Insolvency Code, if the plan provides
for their direct application for the benefit of the company’s creditors. As a rule, the division into classes
of creditors is not mandatory in the case of an arrangement with creditors without going concern (con
_liquidazione del patrimonio). However, pursuant to Article 85(2) of the Insolvency Code, classes must_
be created in relation to the following creditors: (i) creditors for tax and/or contribution claims that will
not be repaid in full; (ii) creditors benefiting from collateral/guarantees issued by third parties; (iii)
creditors that will be satisfied not in cash (even if the satisfaction is partly in cash and partly by other
means); (iv) creditors that have filed a “competing composition (concordato) proposal” and their related
parties.

At the time of filing, the Court, inter alia, determines whether the proposal of arrangement is admissible
by assessing: (i) in the case of an arrangement without business continuity (con liquidazione del
_patrimonio), the admissibility of the proposal and the feasibility of the plan (in the sense that the plan_
must not be manifestly unsuitable to achieve the envisaged objectives); and (ii) in the case of an
arrangement with business continuity (in continuità aziendale), the compliance of the proposal with the
applicable legal provisions (ritualità). The proposal for an arrangement with business continuity is, in
any event, not admissible if the plan is manifestly unsuitable to satisfy the creditors as proposed by the
debtor and to preserve business values (valori aziendali).

If the court determines that the proposal for composition (proposta di concordato) is admissible, inter
alia, it appoints a delegated judge (Giudice delegato) to supervise the procedure, appoints (or confirms,
as the case may be) one or more judicial commissioners (commissari giudiziali) and schedules a specific
period of time during which creditors can express their vote.

During the implementation of the proposal, the company generally continues to be managed by its
corporate bodies (usually the board of directors), but is supervised by the judicial commissioners and
the appointed judge (who will authorise all operations beyond ordinary administration). Moreover, until


-----

the proceedings are approved, the debtor may not make payments on debts that arose before the opening
of the proceedings, unless they have been specifically approved by the delegated judge.

Under the Insolvency Code: (i) one or more creditors (with the exception of natural or legal persons
controlled, controlling or under common control with the debtor) representing at least 10 per cent. of
the total claims resulting from the debtor’s updated balance sheets filed with the courts and (ii)
shareholders representing at least 10% of the company’s share capital may submit a proposal for
composition (proposta di concordato preventivo) with creditors competing with the debtor’s proposal
(proposta concorrente) – within 30 days prior to the commencement of the voting procedure – provided
that certain conditions are met, including, in particular, that the debtor’s proposal does not provide for
the payment of at least 30% of the unsecured claims (this threshold is reduced to 20% in the event that
the debtor has previously and successfully commenced a negotiated crisis resolution procedure
(composizione negoziata)).

In addition, pursuant to Article 91 of the Insolvency Code, if the composition plan includes an offer for
the sale of the debtor’s assets or for the sale of the debtor’s business to an identified third party, the
court or the delegated judge shall order that adequate publicity is given to such offer in order to acquire
competing offers (offerte concorrenti). If expressions of interest are received, the court or the delegated
judge, by decree, orders the opening of the competitive procedure. Moreover, the aforementioned decree
establishes the procedures for submitting irrevocable bids, providing that in all cases, inter alia, the
following must be ensured (i) their comparability; (ii) the requirements for the bidders to participate; I
the forms and timing of access to the relevant information; (iii) any limits on their use; (iv) the manner
in which the court-appointed liquidator must provide it to those who request it; (v) the manner in which
the competitive procedure has to be conducted; (vi) the minimum increase in the consideration to be
provided by subsequent bidders; (vii) the securities to be provided by the bidders; (viii) the forms of
advertising; and (ix) the date of the hearing for the evaluation of the bids, if the sale takes place before
the court. With the sale or with the assignment, whichever is earlier, to a person other than the original
bidder identified in the plan, the latter and the debtor are released from their mutual obligations and
consequently the debtor will have to amend the proposal and the plan according to the outcome of the
competitive procedure.

Normally, the composition agreement (concordato preventivo) is voted on within the time limit set by
the court and must be approved with the favourable vote of (i) the creditors representing a majority of
the claims allowed to vote and, even if the plan provides for more than one class of creditors, or (ii) a
majority of the claims allowed to vote is reached by a majority of the classes. Pursuant to Section 109(1)
of the Insolvency Code, in the event that a creditor has more than a majority of the claims allowed to
vote, a majority of heads (maggioranza per teste) must also be reached. The composition agreement
(concordato preventivo) is only approved if the required majorities of the creditors have expressly voted
in favour of the proposal. Creditors who have not exercised their right to vote shall be deemed not to
have approved the composition agreement proposal (proposta di concordato).

Secured creditors are not entitled to vote on the composition agreement proposal (proposta di
