_concordato) for an arrangement unless and to the extent that they waive their guarantee, or the_
arrangement agreement (concordato preventivo) provides that they will not receive full satisfaction of
the fair market value of their secured assets (such value being assessed by an independent expert), in
which case they may only vote in respect of the part of their debt affected by the proposal. Among
others, (i) companies controlling the debtor, those controlled by the debtor and those under the control
of the entity controlling the debtor, (ii) assignees of the claims of the entities referred to in paragraph
(i) above, if the assignment was completed in the year preceding the arrangement (concordato
_preventivo), and (iii) creditors with conflicting interests are excluded from voting._

In contrast to the general rules set out above, an arrangement as a going-concern (in continuità
_aziendale) is approved with the favourable vote of all classes of creditors. In each class, the arrangement_
is approved by the affirmative vote of creditors representing a majority of the claims allowed to vote
or, if this threshold is not reached, by the affirmative vote of creditors representing two-thirds of the


-----

claims of the voting creditors, provided that creditors holding at least half of the total claims of the same
class have voted. Secured creditors are not eligible to vote if they are repaid in full (and in cash) within
180 days (reduced to 30 days for employees) after approval without any waiver of their security
interests. If these requirements are not met, the secured creditors are entitled to vote. Notwithstanding
the foregoing, the Insolvency Code provides that an arrangement with creditors as a going concern (in
_continuità aziendale) may be approved by the Court even in the event that all creditors fail to approve_
the arrangement if certain specific conditions are met.

In addition to the above, under certain conditions, the composition plan may provide for the creation of
one or more classes of shareholders (more than one class of shareholders may be created if the
company’s articles of association - also, if applicable, as amended in the course of the composition
procedure - provide for different rights for shareholders). The creation of classes of shareholders is
required by law (i) if the composition plan provides for amendments that directly affect the
shareholders’ rights; and/or (ii) in the case of listed/public companies (società che fanno ricorso al
_mercato del capitale di rischio)._

If one or more classes of shareholders have been provided for, the shareholders are entitled to vote in
the form and on the terms provided for the creditors’ vote. Within the respective class, the relevant
shareholder is entitled to vote in proportion to the share of capital held prior to the filing of the
arrangement (concordato). If a shareholder does not vote within the prescribed time limit, he shall be
deemed to have voted in favour.

If composition proposals (proposte concorrenti) have been filed by one or more creditors, these will
also be submitted to a vote of the creditors. The winning proposal is the one that obtains the highest
majority of positive votes and, in the event of a tie, the debtor’s proposal prevails over that of a creditor,
while the proposal of one creditor prevails over that of another creditor if it was filed first. In the event
that none of the proposals reaches the required number of votes as described above, the judge will again
put the proposal that obtained the highest majority to a vote.

It should be noted that the delegated judge may provisionally admit (in whole or in part) creditors of
disputed claims to the voting session for the sole purpose of voting on the composition proposal
(proposta di concordato) and calculating the relevant majorities. Excluded creditors shall have the right
to object to this decision by filing a specific petition as part of the court’s approval, in any event, only
if their participation in the voting session may have influenced the calculation of the relevant majorities.

After the arrangement agreement has been approved by the creditors, the Court shall set the date of the
hearing for the formal homologation (omologazione) of the arrangement (concordato preventivo), and
the debtor shall notify the interested parties thereof. At least 10 (ten) days prior to the date of the
approval hearing, each dissenting creditor and/or any interested third party may file an objection/appeal
(opposizione) against the proposed approval of the composition agreement. In the absence of objections
(opposizioni), the court shall approve the arrangement (concordato) after verifying (i) the regularity of
the arrangement (concordato) procedure; (ii) the outcome of the creditors’ vote; (iii) the admissibility
of the proposal; (iv) the proper creation of the classes of creditors; and (v) the equal treatment of
creditors within each class. In addition, in the case of an arrangement (concordato) as a going concern,
the court will verify that all classes have voted in favour of the proposal, that the plan has reasonable
prospects of preventing or overcoming insolvency and that any new financing is necessary to implement
the plan and does not unfairly prejudice the interests of creditors. In any other case, the court must verify
the practicability of the plan (i.e. that the plan is not manifestly inadequate to achieve the stated
objectives).

In addition, in the case of an arrangement (concordato) as a going-concern, if one or more classes are
opposed, the court, at the debtor’s request (or, in the case of a concurrent arrangement (concordato)
proposal, with the debtor’s consent) may nevertheless approve the arrangement (concordato) if the
following conditions are jointly fulfilled (i) the liquidation value is allocated on the basis of the rank of
each claim (absolute priority rule); (ii) the resources resulting from the going-concern in excess of the


-----

liquidation value are distributed in such a way that the claims included in the dissenting classes receive
an overall treatment at least equal to that of the classes of equal rank and more favourable than that of
the classes of lower rank (relative priority rule) (iii) no single creditor is paid more than the amount of
its claim; and (iv) the proposal is approved by a majority of the classes, provided that at least one of the
classes is composed of secured creditors or, in the absence thereof, the proposal is approved by at least
one class of creditors that would be at least partially settled on the basis of their respective ranking of
claims also for the value in excess of the liquidation value.

In addition, pursuant to Article 88 of the Insolvency Code, if the debtor has submitted a “tax settlement”
proposal to the Tax Administration/Social Security Authority under the Insolvency Code, the court may
approve the arrangement even without the consent of such creditors when their consent is necessary to
obtain the applicable majorities, on condition that the expert’s report certifies that the proposal made
by the debtor to such creditor is more advantageous than a liquidation scenario.

In the event of a challenge to the homologation, the Court will decide on each of the objections. If the
Court rejects all challenges and has no further observations, it will issue the probate decree.

Article 112 of the Insolvency Code provides for a “cram-down” mechanism whereby:

(i) in the case of an arrangement with business continuity (in continuità aziendale), if a creditor
disputes the “convenience” of the arrangement (concordato) proposal, the court may approve
the arrangement (concordato) only if it considers that the relevant claim will be satisfied for
an amount not lower than that which would be paid under a judicial liquidation;

(ii) in all other cases, the court may approve an arrangement (concordato) which is challenged by
(a) a creditor belonging to a “dissenting class” of creditors; or (b) where there is no class of
creditors, by creditors representing 20% of the claims admitted to vote, to the extent that (c)
such challenges relate to the “appropriateness” of the arrangement (concordato) proposal and
(d) the court considers that the relevant claim will be satisfied for an amount not less than that
which would be paid in a court-supervised liquidation.

Moreover, if the plan provides for the pre-existing shareholders to benefit from the so-called
“restructuring value”, the arrangement may be approved if one or more classes of creditors are
dissenting, to the extent that the recoupment of each dissenting class is at least as good as the
recoupment of other classes of equal ranking and more favourable than the proposed recoupment of the
lower ranking classes, even if the restructuring value reserved for shareholders were to be applied to
those classes. According to the Insolvency Code, “restructuring value reserved for shareholders”
means the actual value of the shareholders’ interests in the company following the approval of the
proposal, without any contributions made by the shareholders for the purposes of the restructuring.
Shareholders may challenge the approval if it is prejudicial to them against a liquidation scenario.

If the arrangement provides for the liquidation of the debtor’s assets, the court, if it approves the
arrangement, shall appoint one or more liquidators to implement the approved plan if it is to be
implemented by the transfer of assets. The court may confer special powers on the liquidator to
implement the plan if the debtor does not collaborate, including by taking all necessary corporate
actions.

If the court does not approve the arrangement, it may open the judicial liquidation of the company only
if there are pending petitions to that effect.

The terms and performance of existing contracts entered into from time to time by the debtor are not
automatically affected by the arrangement procedure and normally continue pending the procedure, any
agreements to the contrary being ineffective. However, pursuant to Article 97 of the Insolvency Code,
the debtor may request the Court to terminate or suspend the effectiveness of such pending agreements
(subject to certain exceptions: e.g., employment contracts cannot be suspended or terminated) if the


-----

continuation of the agreement is neither in line with the plan nor functional to its implementation. It
should be noted that termination can only be requested only if the composition plan and proposal have
already been filed with the court. In such cases, the other party will be eligible for compensation equal
to the damages suffered as a result of the termination or suspension of the agreement. Such indemnity
shall be treated as an unsecured claim arising prior to the composition proceedings, without prejudice,
however, to the super-senior status of those claims arising as a result of settlements legally effected
after the publication of the composition petition in the Commercial Register (and prior to the notification
of the suspension/termination petition).

Specific rules are provided in relation to the termination of leasing contracts and ongoing loan
agreements. In this last regard, para. 14 of Article 97 of the Insolvency Code provides that, in the event
of the termination of a financing agreement, the lender has the right to collect and retain the sums paid
by the company’s debtors until full repayment of the advances made by the lender to the company
during the period between (i) the date falling 120 days prior to the filing of the composition agreement
and (ii) the date on which the lender is notified of the termination petition.

In addition to the above, Article 95 of the Insolvency Code explains that outstanding contracts with the
Italian public administration are not terminated following the filing of the composition agreement and
any provision to the contrary is ineffective; such contracts continue to be effective if the independent
third-party expert certifies that such contracts are coherent with the plan (if already drawn up) and that
the company is reasonable able to fulfil them. In the case of a composition with creditors as a going
concern (in continuità aziendale), the expert must also certify that the continuance of such contracts is
necessary to obtain the best possible liquidation of the going concern (migliore liquidazione
_dell’azienda in esercizio). After the filing of the composition agreement, the company may participate_
in public bidding subject to the Court’s authorization and subject to the fulfilment of certain
requirements of the Insolvency Code (including the filing of a third-party expert’s report in this regard).

Pursuant to Article 89 of the Insolvency Code, the rules regulating the loss and reduction of share capital
provided for by the Italian Civil Code do not apply to Italian companies during the period from the date
of filing of the application for composition to the date of its approval.

Moreover, during this period, the rule providing for the dissolution of the company in the event of a
reduction or loss of share capital does not apply. However, during the period preceding the filing of the
application for the arrangement, Article 2486 of the Italian Civil Code, which provides for the powers
and duties of the directors after the occurrence of an event of dissolution of the company, will apply.

For an analysis of the rules governing new financial resources, please refer to the specific section under
section “New Financial Resources.”

Pursuant to Articles 119 and 120 of the Insolvency Code, in the event of a breach of the composition
plan or fraud, upon the fulfilment of the requirements, the composition agreement may be terminated
or annulled, as the case may be, upon the request of one or more creditors; judicial liquidation may
follow. The composition agreement is binding on all creditors prior to the publication of the application
in the commercial register. However, creditors retain their rights vis-à-vis the debtor’s co-debtors and
guarantors.

In the event of minor violations, the arrangement may be terminated by any of the creditors or by the
judicial commissioner (in the event of an application by one or more creditors).

The relevant action must be filed within one year from the original term of the last business to be
conducted under the arrangement. The composition agreement may also be terminated upon application
of the court-appointed liquidator or one or more creditors if part of the debtor’s assets have been
concealed or liabilities have been maliciously exaggerated.


-----

The relevant lawsuit must be filed within six months from the discovery of the
concealment/exaggeration and, in any event, within two years from the original deadline for the last
activity to be carried out under the arrangement.

Finally, it should be noted that Articles 284 et seq. of the Insolvency Code provide for a group
arrangement. More precisely, if several companies (having the center of their main interests in Italy)
belonging to the same group find themselves in a situation of crisis or insolvency, they may file a single
request for composition with creditors, comprising a single composition plan or several linked plans.
The assets and liabilities of each group company will be evaluated on an individual basis. In such a
case, the legal framework of the group arrangement is the same as that applicable to the ordinary type,
subject to certain specific rules/exceptions, including, inter alia: (i) the arrangement petition must
specify the reasons why a group procedure is more convenient for creditors than individual and separate
proceedings; (ii) the arrangement petition and plan(s) must include certain additional information,
mainly related to the group structure, intercompany relations, etc.; (iii) the plan(s) must ensure the
restructuring of each group company and must be certified by the third party expert. The expert’s report
must also confirm that the group proceedings are more advantageous for creditors than separate
proceedings; (iv) the plan or plans may provide for both the continuation of some business activities
and the liquidation of others. The procedure qualifies as a going-concern arrangement (concordato in
_continuità aziendale) when the proceeds from the continuation of the business exceed those from the_
liquidation of the assets; and (v) certain specific rules apply in relation to the voting stage and the
approval stage of the procedure.

**_Negotiated crisis composition procedure (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa) under the_**
**_Insolvency Code_**

The negotiated settlement procedure for business crises (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa)
was originally introduced into the Italian legal framework by Decree 118/2021 and subsequently
incorporated into the Insolvency Code. It is a negotiated and out-of-court instrument applicable to both
commercial (imprenditori commerciali) and agricultural enterprises (imprenditori agricoli), which find
themselves in a situation of difficulty with reference to their assets, their business and/or their financial
situation, such as to make a situation of distress/crisis or insolvency likely to occur. It is therefore an
instrument aimed at anticipating the further deterioration of the debtor’s situation.

Notwithstanding the above, the court may become involved in the following two circumstances: (i)
when the entrepreneur files a petition pursuant to Article 18 of the Insolvency Code requesting the
competent court to confirm or modify the protective measures provided for in the same provision on
the same day as the publication of the petition in the commercial register and the acceptance of the
expert and, if necessary, to take the provisional measures necessary to complete the negotiations; and
(ii) when the entrepreneur files a petition requesting the court to authorise certain acts in line with the
provisions of Article 22 of the Insolvency Code.

Pursuant to Article 17 of the Insolvency Code, the entrepreneur or undertaking filing an application for
an arrangement with creditors (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa) shall, inter alia, certify
that no judicial winding-up proceedings or similar proceedings are pending against it, nor applications
for admission to proceedings under Articles 40 of the Insolvency Code, including pursuant to Articles
44(1)(a) and 54 of the Insolvency Code. 1(a) and 54(3) were previously filed. If an application for a
negotiated settlement of an enterprise’s crisis (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa) is
dismissed (archiviata), the entrepreneur may not file a new application until one year has elapsed since
the dismissal (the time limit is reduced, on a one-time basis, to four months if dismissal is requested by
the entrepreneur within two months of the expert’s acceptance).

The negotiated settlement procedure for business crises (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa)
is initiated on a voluntary basis only by filing an application for the appointment of a third and
independent expert with the Secretary General of the relevant Chamber of Commerce through a special
electronic platform, and the expert is appointed within five days of filing the application. Pursuant to


-----

the Insolvency Code, the person to be appointed as an expert must not have or maintain professional
relations with the business owner during the two years following the closure of the negotiated settlement
procedure for the business crisis (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa). The application may
not be filed during the pendency of a procedure for the restructuring of overindebtedness or liquidation
of assets pursuant to Articles 7 and 14-ter of Law No. 3/2012 (procedimenti di composizione della crisi
_da sovranindebitamento e di liquidazione del patrimonio). The expert’s role is to facilitate and manage_
negotiations between the company, creditors and other stakeholders in order to find a solution to
overcome the crisis or insolvency, including through the sale of the company or a branch thereof.

The expert evaluates his or her independence, the adequacy of his or her professional skills, and his or
her time availability with respect to the proposed assignment and, if the outcome of the evaluation is
positive, communicates his or her acceptance to the entrepreneur and uploads it onto the dedicated
electronic platform. If the expert accepts the assignment, he meets with the entrepreneur to assess
whether there are real and concrete possibilities for recovery. The entrepreneur attends the meeting in
person and may be assisted by his advisors.

If the expert considers that there are concrete and real possibilities for recovery, he meets the parties
involved in the recovery process of the business owner and presents possible strategies, planning
periodic close meetings.

During the negotiations, all parties involved must act in good faith and with fairness, must collaborate
and are required to maintain confidentiality about the situation of the business owner, the actions
performed or planned by the business owner and the information received during the negotiations. The
business owner must provide a complete and clear representation of its situation and manage its assets
without causing unfair prejudice to creditors. Banks and financial intermediaries, their agents and, in
the case of assignment and/or transfer of credit, their assignees or assignors, must participate in the
negotiation in an informed and active manner. Access to the arrangement procedure (composizione
_negoziata per la crisi di impresa) is not, in itself, a reason to revoke the credit facility. Specific rules_
apply to negotiations regarding employment contracts.

If the expert, after the meeting with the entrepreneur or afterwards, finds that there is no real possibility
of reorganisation, he must promptly notify the entrepreneur and the Secretary General of the Chamber
of Commerce, who will file the entrepreneur’s petition. The negotiated business crisis settlement
procedure (composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa) may not exceed 180 days, without prejudice
to a possible extension of a further 180 days in the presence of certain requirements. In particular, the
expert’s appointment is considered terminated if, after 180 days from the appointment, the parties have
not agreed on a solution (which may also be proposed by the expert) to overcome the entrepreneur’s
crisis situation. However, the engagement of the expert may continue for up to a further 180 days if (i)
all parties involved in the negotiations so request and the expert agrees, or (ii) the continuation of the
engagement is required by the fact that the entrepreneur has filed a petition with the court pursuant to
Article 19 and/or Article 22 of the Insolvency Code.

Upon completion of the assignment, the expert issues a final report, which is uploaded onto the platform,
and notifies the entrepreneur and the court that granted the precautionary measures and provisional
measures (if any) declaring the termination of their effects.

Under Article 18 of the Insolvency Code, along with the petition for appointment of the expert, or with
a subsequent petition, the business owner may apply for protective measures, which may also be limited,
at the business owner’s request, to certain claims or a specific category of creditors. If protective
measures are awarded, as from the date of publication of the relevant application, pre-existing creditors
cannot obtain pre-emption rights (diritti di prelazione) unless they have been agreed with the
entrepreneur, and all enforcement and provisional actions are suspended. However, it should be noted
that, differently from what it is provided under the Insolvency Code for composition proceedings
(concordato preventivo), payment of pre-existing creditors is not prohibited. The protective measures
do not apply to employees’ claims.


-----

From the date of the publication of the petition for the application of protective measures until the date
of the conclusion of negotiations or rejection of the petition for the arrangement procedure
(composizione negoziata per la crisi di impresa) the judgment opening judicial liquidation (sentenza di
_apertura della liquidazione giudiziale) or the declaration of the entrepreneur’s insolvency may not be_
declared by the court, unless the court revokes the protective measures.

Creditors whose rights are covered by the protective measures may not unilaterally reject fulfilment of
obligations arising from existing contracts with the entrepreneur, nor terminate such contracts, nor
anticipate their expiration, nor modify them with prejudicial consequences for the businessperson,
merely because of non-payment of claims that arose prior to the publication of the petition requesting
the application of the protective measures. However, creditors may stay the performance of ongoing
contracts from the publication of the request for precautionary measures until such measures are
obtained.

If the entrepreneur requests precautionary measures, it must simultaneously file the same request with
the competent court to allow a judge to verify these measures and confirm or, if necessary, modify them.
In the absence of such a request, the precautionary measures will be ineffective.

The length of the precautionary measures and, if necessary, the provisional measures, is set by order of
the court in a range between 30 and 120 days and, at the request of the parties and after obtaining the
expert’s opinion, may be extended for the time necessary to successfully conclude the negotiations up
to a maximum of 240 days, it being noted that the judge may discretionally order the revocation of such
precautionary measures or reduce their length.

Pending the negotiated settlement procedure for the business crisis (composizione negoziata per la crisi
_di impresa), there is no dispossession: the entrepreneur remains able to continue the ordinary and_
extraordinary management of the business, subject to certain conditions. More specifically, pursuant to
Article 21 of the Insolvency Code, pending the negotiated settlement procedure, the businessman may
perform acts pertaining to ordinary business. Subject to written notice to the expert, perform acts of
extraordinary activity or make payments that are inconsistent with the negotiations or the prospects of
recovery, so as not to endanger the economic and financial viability of the company. In particular, acts,
payments and guarantees/real interests made by the business owner after the appointment of the expert
within the scope of the negotiated settlement procedure for the business crisis are not subject to the
claw-back action pursuant to Article 166(2) of the Insolvency Code, if they are coherent with the state
of negotiations and the prospects for the company’s recovery. If it appears during the course of
negotiations that the businessperson is insolvent but that there are real recovery prospects, the
businessperson shall run the business in the best interest of the creditors, without prejudice to its
liability. If the expert is of the opinion that a particular act is prejudicial to the creditors, negotiations,
or prospects for recovery, he/she shall notify the business owner and the company’s supervisory body
in writing. If, despite the expert’s report, the entrepreneur performs the act in question, the entrepreneur
immediately notifies the expert, who may file his/her dissent for registration in the commercial register.
At the request of the entrepreneur, one or more creditors or the expert, the court that granted the
protective measures and/or interim measures may, at any time, withdraw such measures or reduce their
duration when they do not fulfil the objective of guaranteeing the successful outcome of the negotiations
or appear disproportionate in relation to the prejudice caused to the creditors. If the protective measures
are withdrawn, the rule concerning the prevention of obtaining pre-emption rights from pre-existing
creditors shall expire on the date the protective measure is withdrawn.

At the request of the entrepreneur and to the extent compatible with the continuity of the business and
the maximisation of the creditors’ recovery, the court may authorise: (i) the entrepreneur or one or more
companies belonging to the same group to incur new super-senior (prededucibile) indebtedness
pursuant to Article 6 of the Insolvency Code; (ii) the entrepreneur to contract a new super-senior
(prededucibile) debt by virtue of a shareholder loan pursuant to Article 6 of the Insolvency Code; and
(iii) the entrepreneur to transfer its business, or some branches thereof, without the effects provided for
in Article 2560(2) of the Italian Civil Code, without prejudice to Article 2112 of the Italian Civil Code,


-----

identifying appropriate measures to protect all the interests involved, also taking into account the
requests of the parties concerned. The court shall also verify the respect of the principle of
competitiveness (principio di competitività) in the selection of the purchaser.

According to Article 23 of the Insolvency Code, if a suitable solution has been found to resolve the
entrepreneur’s problems, the business crisis negotiated settlement procedure (composizione negoziata
_per la crisi di impresa) may end with_

(i) the execution of an agreement between the entrepreneur and one or more creditors, which

constitutes grounds for the application of the bonus measures provided for in Article 25-bis (1) of
the Insolvency Code if, according to the final report of the expert, such agreement ensures the
continuity of the business for at least 2 years;

(ii) the conclusion of a moratorium agreement (convenzione di moratoria) pursuant to Article 62 of

the Insolvency Code;

(iii) the conclusion of an agreement signed by the entrepreneur, the creditors and the expert, with the

effects provided for in articles 166 (3) (d) and 324 of the Insolvency Code. In this agreement, the
expert notes that the restructuring plan (piano di risanamento) appears to be consistent with the
resolution of the entrepreneur’s insolvency and crisis.

If, at the end of the negotiations, none of the above solutions have been chosen, the entrepreneur may,
alternative

(i) draw up a certified reorganisation plan (piano attestato di risanamento) pursuant to Article 56 of

the Insolvency Code;

(ii) file an application for approval of a debt restructuring agreement with creditors (accordo di

_ristrutturazione dei debiti) pursuant to Articles 57, 60 and 61 of the Insolvency Code. The_
percentage referred to in Article 61 (2) (c) of the Insolvency Code is reduced to 60 per cent. if the
achievement of the agreement is reflected in the final report of the expert;

(iii) filing an application for a simplified composition agreement for the liquidation of assets

(concordato semplificato per la liquidazione del patrimonio) (see “Simplified Composition
_Agreement for the Liquidation of Assets” below)_

(iv) accessing one of the proceedings/instruments provided for by the Insolvency Code or Decree No.

270 or Decree No. 347.

In addition, pursuant to Article 24 of the Insolvency Code:

(i) the acts authorized by the court pursuant to Article 22 of the Insolvency Code shall retain their

effects in the event of the subsequent occurrence of an approved debt restructuring agreement
(accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti omologato), an approved arrangement procedure, an
approved restructuring plan pursuant to Article 64-bis of the Insolvency Code (piano di
_ristrutturazione omologato), the opening of judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale),_
compulsory administrative liquidation (liquidazione coatta amministrativa), extraordinary
administration (amministrazione straordinaria) or simplified arrangement for the liquidation of
assets (concordato semplificato per la liquidazione del patrimonio);

(ii) transactions, payments and granting of collateral made by the entrepreneur after the expert’s

acceptance of the assignment are exempt from recovery actions pursuant to Section 166(2) of the
Insolvency Code, if they are consistent with the course and state of negotiations and the prospects
of recovery existing at the time the transaction/payment/grant of collateral was made;

(iii) extraordinary operations and payments made after the expert’s acceptation of the engagement are

in any event subject to actions for claw-back pursuant to Articles 165 and 166 of the Insolvency


-----

Code if the expert has registered his/her dissent in the commercial register pursuant to Article
21(4) of the Insolvency Code or if the competent court has denied its authorization pursuant to
Section 22 of the Insolvency Code.

Moreover, payments and settlements made after the expert’s appointment acceptance, which the expert
considers consistent with the development of the negotiations and the prospects for the company’s
recovery, or which have been authorised by the court pursuant to Article 22 of the Insolvency Code,
benefit from exemptions from the potential application of certain criminal sanctions.

Pursuant to Article 25 of the Insolvency Code, the negotiated settlement procedure for corporate crisis
(composizione negoziata per la crisi d’impresa) can also be applied to groups of companies, which can
all start a single procedure together. At the end of the negotiations, the companies belonging to the same
group may enter into one of the agreements provided for in Article 23(1) of the Insolvency Code. 1 of
the Insolvency Code as a group, or access one of the instruments provided for in Article 23 of the
Insolvency Code, either separately or as a whole group.

**_Simplified composition with creditors proceeding for the liquidation of assets (concordato_**
**_semplificato per la liquidazione del patrimonio) under the Insolvency Code_**

The simplified arrangement for the liquidation of assets (concordato semplificato per la liquidazione
_del patrimonio) is a special type of arrangement procedure (concordato preventivo) available only to_
those companies that (i) have first entered into the arrangement procedure (composizione negoziata per
_la crisi d’impresa); and (ii) as certified by the expert within the framework of the arrangement procedure_
(composizione negoziata per la crisi d’impresa), despite the fact that negotiations in good faith with the
creditors could not reach a positive outcome.

The simplified composition agreement for the liquidation of assets (concordato semplificato per la
_liquidazione del patrimonio) - which has a purely liquidation purpose - was originally introduced into_
Italian law by Decree 118/2021 and was subsequently incorporated into the Insolvency Code.

If, in his final relation, the expert asserts that the negotiations were unsuccessful, but were conducted
fairly and in good faith, and that the options provided for in Article 23(1) and (2)(b) of the Insolvency
Code are not practicable, within 60 days of the notification of the final report, the businessperson may
file, with the relevant court of the place where the company has its registered office, an application for
admission to the simplified composition procedure for the liquidation of assets (concordato semplificato
_per la liquidazione del patrimonio), a proposal for composition with creditors envisaging the liquidation_
of the assets together with the liquidation plan and the documents provided for in Article 39 of the
Insolvency Code. The proposal may provide for the division of creditors into different classes.

The application for a simplified arrangement to liquidate the assets (concordato semplificato per la
_liquidazione del patrimonio) shall be communicated to the public prosecutor and published in the_
commercial register no later than the day following the date of filing with the court. From the date of
such publication, the effects provided for in Articles 6, 46, 94 and 96 of the Insolvency Code shall take
effect.

Upon the time the petition is filed, the court (i) appoints a so-called 'auxiliary’ (ausiliario) to, inter alia,
express an advice on the entrepreneur’s proposal; (ii) orders that the proposal, together with the
auxiliary’s advice and the expert’s final statement, be delivered by the debtor to the creditors appearing
on the list filed by the debtor; and (iii) sets the date of the probate hearing. Creditors and third parties
having an interest have the right to object to the approval within ten days prior to the date set for the
hearing.

The court approves the simplified composition agreement for the liquidation of the assets (concordato
_semplificato per la liquidazione del patrimonio) when it ascertains (i) the regularity of the adversarial_
process between the parties (contraddittorio) and of the proceedings; (ii) the observance of pre-emption


-----

rights (cause di prelazione); (iii) the practicability of the liquidation plan, and finds that the proposal
does not cause any prejudice to the creditors with respect to what they would receive in the event of the
judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale) of the entrepreneur, and in any event ensures a certain
recovery for each creditor. In the approval decree, the court also appoints a liquidator.

The parties may appeal against the homologation decree within 30 days of its notification.

Pursuant to Article 25-septies of the Insolvency Code, the liquidation planning may also provide for the
offer of a third party previously identified to transfer the company or one or more branches of the
company or specific assets to such third party, even before the homologation: in this case, the judicial
liquidator, after verifying the absence of better solutions on the market, may execute the offer.

**_Certified restructuring plans (piani attestati di risanamento) under article 56 of the Insolvency Code_**

The certified restructuring plans _(piani attestati di risanamento) referred to in Article 56 of the_
Insolvency Code are out-of-court instruments that consist of a restructuring plan addressed to creditors
and prepared by debtors in a state of insolvency or crisis, in order to allow the restructuring of
indebtedness and support the rebalancing of the debtor’s financial condition, which must be certified
by an independent third-party expert directly appointed by the debtor and registered with the register of
auditors and accounting experts (Registro dei Revisori Contabili). The independent expert - who must
verify the feasibility of the restructuring plan and the truthfulness of the company data provided by the
company - must possess certain specific requirements and professional qualifications and meet the
requirements of Article 2399 of the Italian Civil Code and may be subject to liability in the event of
false declarations or attestations.

Attested restructuring plans (piani attestati di risanamento) are usually implemented through one or
more agreements entered into by the company with the creditors/parties concerned. Such agreements
are merely private agreements and do not affect the right of creditors who are not party to the agreement
to enforce their claims, guarantees or securities. As such, there is no ‘automatic stay’ by law.

Attested restructuring plans (piani attestati di risanamento) and related debt restructuring agreements
are not subject to any form of judicial review or approval and, therefore, no application to the court or
supervisory authority is required. Furthermore, the approval or consent of a specific majority of all
outstanding claims is not required.

The terms and conditions of these plans are liberally negotiable, provided that they are aimed at
restructuring the debtor’s indebtedness and rebalancing its asset structure. According to Article 56 of
the Insolvency Code, the ‘minimum content’ of the plan must include, inter alia, an indication of nonsubscribing creditors, the financial resources required to pay their claims on the relevant due dates, and
the causes of the crisis. Moreover, it must be supported by adequate documentation representing the
debtor’s financial and commercial situation.

As explicitly set forth in Article 166(3)(d) of the Insolvency Code, in the event of the bankruptcy of
such plans and the declaration of the debtor’s insolvency, the payments and/or acts performed, and/or
security rights granted over the debtor’s assets for the implementation of the restructuring plan, subject
to certain conditions, are not subject to any claw-back action (azione revocatoria), including the
ordinary claw-back action (azione revocatoria) provided for in Article 2901 of the Italian Civil Code.
In addition, they are also exempted from the possible application of certain criminal sanctions. Court
approval is not provided for publication in the commercial register of the plan, the independent expert’s
report and the agreement(s) is not mandatory, but is possible at the debtor’s request and allows for
certain tax benefits.

The Insolvency Law provides specific rules on protection against claw-back actions and potential civil
and criminal liabilities in relation to transactions, payments and guarantees granted on the debtor’s


-----

assets made in the context of the implementation of certified reorganization plans (piani attestati di
_risanamento) pursuant to Article 56 of the Insolvency Code._

**_Debt-restructuring agreements (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti) under article 57 of the_**
**_Insolvency Code._**

The insolvent debtor or debtor in a state of crisis may enter into a debt restructuring agreement (accordo
_di ristrutturazione dei debiti) with creditors holding at least 60 % of the outstanding indebtedness,_
pursuant to Article 57 et seq. of the Insolvency Code, which must be certified by an independent expert
appointed by the debtor based on an assessment of the veracity of the business and accounting data
provided by the company and the declaration of feasibility and application for approval by the
competent court.

In particular, the independent expert must certify that the plan and the debt restructuring agreement
_(accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) ensure that the indebtedness towards non-participating creditors_
can be fully satisfied within the following 120 days from (i) the date of the court’s approval of the debt
restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti), in the case of debts that are due and
payable to non-parties creditors on the date of approval; and (ii) the due date of the relevant debts, in
the case of debts that are not yet due and payable to non-parties creditors on the date of the court’s
approval of the debt restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti).

The debt restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) is published in the commercial
register and becomes effective on the day of its publication. Creditors and other interested parties may
challenge the debt restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) within 30 days of its
publication in the commercial register. After deciding on any opposition filed, the court approves the
debt restructuring agreement by a decree, which may be appealed within 30 days of its publication
pursuant to Article 51 of the Insolvency Code.

The Insolvency Code does not expressly set out any guidelines on the content of the debt restructuring
agreement _(accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti). Thus, the plan may provide for, inter alia, the_
operation of the business by the debtor or a third party, or the sale of the business, and may contain
agreements on refinancing, moratoria, write-offs and/or deferral of claims. The debt restructuring
agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) may also contain a proposal for a tax settlement for
the partial or deferred payment of certain taxes.

Pursuant to Article 58(1) of the Insolvency Code, in the event of substantive changes to the plan prior
to approval, the expert’s report and the creditors’ consent to the debt restructuring agreement (accordo
_di ristrutturazione dei debiti)_ must be renewed. The report must also be updated in the case of
substantial amendments. In the event of material changes after the approval, the debtor shall make such
changes as are appropriate to guarantee the performance of the agreements by applying for an update
of the sworn report issued by the expert meeting the requirements set forth in Article 57(4) of the
Insolvency Code. In such case, the updated appraisal report, together with the amended restructuring
plan, shall be published in the commercial register and creditors shall be notified accordingly by
registered letter or by certified mail. The parties may file an objection (opposizione) to the
aforementioned decree within 30 days of its notification.

With the application for approval of the debt restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei
_debiti) by the relevant court (or at any time during the proceedings), the debtor may apply for the grant_
of any precautionary measures (aimed at providing for the suspension of actions or the provision by
creditors of collateral security, unless agreed in the debt restructuring agreement in relation to preexisting debts, etc.). Such remedies may also be requested (i) pursuant to Section 54(3) of the Insolvency
Code, to the court by the debtor pending negotiations with the creditors (i.e. prior to the filing of the
petition for approval of the debt restructuring agreement _(accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti)),_
subject to certain conditions, or (ii) pursuant to Article 44 of the Insolvency Code, together with a
‘simplified application’ for access to one of the restructuring instruments provided for in the Insolvency


-----

Code. Pursuant to Article 54(2) of the Insolvency Code, as long as the petition for approval of the debt
restructuring agreement _(accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) contains the related request for_
measures, from the date of publication of the petition in the commercial register it is prohibited to
commence or continue enforcement and conservatory actions (or, in any event, to undertake initiatives
prohibited by the related measures).

This is a court-supervised procedure that does not provide for the divestment of the debtor; nevertheless,
the court may appoint a judicial commissioner to supervise the procedure and must do so if applications
for the opening of judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale) are pending, when it is necessary for the
protection of the parties that have filed such applications. Creditors who join the debt restructuring
agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) are not required to be treated in the same way (i.e.
they are free to reject the proposal and protect their interests in other ways) and no cram-down applies
to third party creditors who do not participate, who will be reimbursed in full within the abovementioned time limits.

The court, after verifying the completeness of the documents filed by the debtor, sets the date of the
hearing, which will be held no earlier than 15 days from the notification of the filing. While awaiting
that time limit, creditors and other interested parties may file an objection to the approval. At that
hearing, the court shall rule on any such opposition and assess whether the conditions for approval are
met.

Notwithstanding the above, Articles 60, 61 and 62 of the Insolvency Code set forth the following
additional forms of debt restructuring agreements (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti).

Therefore, Article 60 of the Insolvency Code provides for the so-called facilitated debt restructuring
agreement (accordi di ristrutturazione agevolati). This is a special type of debt restructuring agreement
that may be entered into with creditors representing as little as 30% of the total indebtedness (instead
of the 60% generally required by Article 57(1) of the Insolvency Code) provided that the debtor: (i)
does not propose to suspend the payment of non-participating creditors; and (ii) has not previously
requested (and waives requesting) the court to grant precautionary measures on its assets.

Pursuant to Article 61 of the Insolvency Code, debtors have the option to enter into a debt restructuring
agreement by obtaining the approval of creditors representing at least 75 per cent. of the claims
belonging to the same category (in relation to the homogeneity of their status and economic interests)
and may request the court to declare such agreement binding on non-participating creditors belonging
to the same category (so-called “cram down”).

More specifically, the debt restructuring agreements with extended effects (accordi di ristrutturazione
_ad efficacia estesa) referred to in Article 61 of the Insolvency Code - which were previously only_
permitted in relation to debts owed to banks and financial intermediaries when such debts represented
at least 50 per cent. of the total indebtedness - may now be applied to any category of creditors, provided
that, inter alia: (i) all creditors belonging to the same category have been informed of the
commencement of negotiations, have been able to participate in good faith and have received complete
and up-to-date information on the debtor’s assets, economic and financial situation, as well as the
restructuring agreement and its effects; (ii) the agreement provides for the continuation of business
activities directly or indirectly within the meaning of Article 84 of the Insolvency Code (iii) the claims
of consenting creditors belonging to the same category represent at least 75% of all claims belonging
to the same category (iv) non-member creditors belonging to the same category to which the effects of
the agreement are extended may be satisfied under the agreement in an amount not less than the amount
they would receive in a court-supervised liquidation, it being understood that a creditor may have claims
in more than one category; and (v) the debtor has notified the agreement, the court’s request for approval
and the documents attached thereto to the creditors to be set aside. The 75 per cent. figure drops to 60
per cent. if the debt restructuring agreement is referred to in the final report issued by the expert at the
end of the negotiations of the negotiated settlement procedure (composizione negoziata per la soluzione
_della crisi d’impresa)._


-----

In addition, paragraph 5 of Article 61 of the Insolvency Code provides for the negotiated settlement
procedure to resolve company’s crisis. In such case, if the debtor has financial indebtedness amounting
to at least 50% of its total indebtedness, the debt restructuring agreement may identify one or more
categories of creditors that are banks and financial intermediaries that have a homogenous legal position
and economic interests and extend the effects of the agreement to non-member creditors that are part of
the same category. In this case, the agreement is valid even if it does not provide for the direct or indirect
continuation of the business activity. However, the rights of creditors that are not banks or financial
intermediaries remain valid.

Pursuant to Article 62 of the Insolvency Code, a moratorium agreement (convenzione di moratoria)
entered into between a debtor and its creditors representing 75 per cent. of the same class is also binding
on non-participating creditors, provided that (i) certain conditions are met, such as, inter alia, (a) all
creditors belonging to the relevant class have been duly notified of the commencement of negotiations,
have been enabled to participate and have received complete and up-to-date information on the debtor’s
assets, economic and financial situation and the agreement and its effects (b) the claims of the
participating creditors of the same class represent 75 per cent. of all creditors of the same class and (c)
there is a real prospect that non-subscribing creditors of the same class, to whom the effects of the
agreement are extended, can be satisfied on the outcome of the agreement to an extent not less than the
judicial liquidation; and (ii) an independent expert certifies (i) the veracity of the business data; (ii) the
ability of the standstill agreement to temporarily settle the effects of the crisis; and (iii) the fulfilment
of the condition in (i)(c) above (i.e., the fact that the reserved treatment was granted to non-participating
creditors of the same class, to whom the effects of the agreement are extended). (i.e. the fact that the
treatment accorded to the non-parties is at least equal to that which they could obtain in the context of
a judicial liquidation).

Non-affiliating creditors may challenge the standstill agreement within 30 days of its notification.

Under no circumstances may the debt restructuring agreements provided for in Article 61 of the
Insolvency Code and the standstill agreements provided for in Article 62 of the Insolvency Code require
non-parties to, inter alia, fulfil new obligations, grant new credit exposures, maintain the possibility of
utilising existing credit exposures or utilise new credit exposures.

Pursuant to Article 59 of the Insolvency Code, Article 1239 of the Italian Civil Code applies to creditors
who have adhered to debt restructuring agreements. Creditors who have not adhered to the agreements
retain their claims against (i) those who are jointly and severally liable with the debtor, (ii) the debtor’s
guarantors, and (iii) the debtors in recourse (regresso). Unless otherwise agreed, debt restructuring
agreements are effective vis-à-vis those shareholders who are jointly and severally liable with the nonlimited liability company, it being understood that, if such shareholders have granted guarantees, they
will remain liable as guarantors.

For an analysis of the rules set forth in Article 99 of the Insolvency Code – which applies to both debt
restructuring agreements (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti) and composition proceedings
(concordati preventivi) – governing supersenior loans authorised prior to the approval of a debt
restructuring agreements (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti) and composition proceedings
(concordati preventivi), please refer to the specific section under “New Financial Resources.”

**_Restructuring plans subject to homologation (piani di ristrutturazione soggetti ad omologazione)_**
**_under article 64-bis of the Insolvency Code_**

Restructuring plans subject to homologation (piani di ristrutturazione soggetti ad omologazione) under
Articles 64-bis and 64-ter of the Insolvency Code constitute a new addition to the legal framework of
crisis and insolvency. By virtue of this new instrument, available to insolvent debtors or debtors in a
state of crisis, it is possible to depart from the distribution rules of ordinary insolvency proceedings,
provided that certain strict requirements are met.


-----

More specifically, under this instrument, according to which creditors must be divided into classes
according to homogeneous legal positions and economic interests, the debtor may allocate to creditors
the value generated by the plan even in derogation of the provisions regulating the legal rank/order of
claims (principle of 'par condicio creditorum’), provided that the proposal is approved with the classes’
unanimous consent.

Restructuring plans subject to approval (piani di ristrutturazione soggetti ad omologazione) must
provide for the payment in full, in cash, of the claims secured by the privilege pursuant to Article 2751bis no. 1 of the Italian Civil Code (i.e., wages) within 30 days of the approval and must be certified, as
to the authenticity of the company data and the feasibility of the plan, by an independent professional
satisfying the requirements of the Insolvency Code.

The debtor must file restructuring plans subject to homologation (piani di ristrutturazione soggetti ad
_omologazione) with the court, together with all documentation required by the Insolvency Code. The_
court assesses the regularity of the filing and the correctness of the class formation criteria: in this case,
the court appoints the judicial commissioner, the delegated judge and sets the deadlines for the creditors’
vote. The next stage must follow the steps of the common framework applicable to all restructuring
instruments and frameworks (i.e. composition with creditors proceeding (concordato preventivo), debt
restructuring agreement (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti) and judicial liquidation (liquidazione
_giudiziale))._

From the date of filing of the petition until the approval, the debtor maintains the ordinary and
extraordinary management of the company in the best interests of the creditors under the supervision of
the court-appointed administrator.

There is no “automatic stay”: however, the debtor may file a specific request for the application of the
stay of action, in order to block creditors’ enforcement and/or precautionary actions on his assets until
the approval of the agreement (and such request may also be filed pending the negotiations for the debt
restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti)). The final decision on such application
(which is provisionally effective) will be made by the competent courts and the duration of such stay of
action period is a maximum of 4 months (subject to extensions in certain circumstances, in any event
not exceeding a total period of 12 months). During the pendency of the action, judicial liquidation
(liquidazione giudiziale) may not be opened by the courts.

In each branch, the proposal is approved if a majority of the claims admitted to vote is reached or, in
the absence thereof, if two-thirds of the claims of the voting creditors have voted in favour, on condition
that creditors holding at least half of the total claims in the same branch have voted. Secured creditors
are not eligible to vote if they are repaid in full (in cash) within 180 days (reduced to 30 days for
employees) after approval without any waiver of their security interests.

If the restructuring plan (piano di ristrutturazione) is not approved by all classes, the debtor may, inter
alia, amend the application by submitting a proposal for composition with creditors (concordato
_preventivo)._

The court will approve the restructuring plan (piano di ristrutturazione) if it is approved by all classes.
If a dissenting creditor opposes the proposal, the court approves and homologates the restructuring plan
if the proposal meets the claim to an extent not less than that arising from a court-supervised liquidation.
A creditor that has not challenged the lack of convenience in its observations may not file such an
objection unless it proves that the lack of opposition is due to a cause not imputable to it.

Against the decision of the court ruling on the approval of the restructuring plan subject to approval
(piano di ristrutturazione soggetto ad omologazione), the parties may file an appeal with the competent
court of appeal within a period of 30 days from the notification of the relevant court ruling.


-----

The acts, payments and warranties/interest on the debtor’s assets performed in the implementation of
the restructuring plans subject to homologation (piani di ristrutturazione soggetti ad omologazione) and
referred to therein shall not be subject to an action for claw-back pursuant to Article 166 of the
Insolvency Code.

**_Extraordinary administration for large insolvent companies (amministrazione straordinaria delle_**
**_grandi imprese insolventi) under the Decree 270_**

Decree No. 270 introduced a specific extraordinary administration procedure, also known as “Prodi_bis” (the “Prodi-bis Procedure”), applicable to the insolvency of large companies (the_
“Amministrazione Straordinaria”).

The objective of the Prodi-bis procedure is to guarantee the continuation of the business run by the
debtor, enabling it to recover the capacity to meet its obligations under ordinary management by the
end of the procedure, or by transferring the business (on a going-concern basis) to a third party.

To be eligible for the Prodi-bis procedure, the company must be insolvent even if it can demonstrate
serious prospects of recovery and must

(i) employ at least 200 employees in the year preceding the opening of the procedure; and

(ii) debts equal to at least two-thirds of the value of its assets, as shown in its balance sheet, and two
thirds of its revenues from sales and services in the last financial year.

Insolvent companies belonging to the group of a company that qualifies for the Prodi-bis Procedure
may be subject to the Prodi-bis Procedure, if certain conditions are met, even if they do not themselves
qualify for the Prodi-bis Procedure.

The Prodi-bis Procedure consists of two main phases:

(i) judicial phase: following an application (which may be filed by one or more creditors, the debtor

or the public prosecutor), the court determines if the company fulfils the admission requirements
and, in particular, if it is insolvent. If the company is insolvent, the court issues a decision to that
effect and appoints one or three judicial receivers to evaluate whether the company has significant
prospects for its recovery (by selling assets or reorganisation of the business) and to submit a report
to the court within 30 days. Once the court receiver’s report is obtained, the court has another 30
days to decide whether to allow the company to be admitted to the extraordinary administration
procedure or to place it in bankruptcy;

(ii) administrative phase: upon approval of the Extraordinary Administration procedure, the

extraordinary commissioner(s) appointed by the Minister of Economic Development must prepare
a restructuring plan. The plan may envisage the sale of the company as a going concern within one
year (unless extended by the Ministry of Economic Development) (the “Disposal Plan”) or a
restructuring plan leading to the economic and financial recovery of the company within two years
(unless extended by the Ministry of Economic Development) (the “Recovery Plan”). The
procedure is administered by the extraordinary commissioner(s) acting under the supervision of
the Minister of Economic Development.

Once the extraordinary administration procedure is approved, the main effects are as follows:

(i) the company continues to conduct its business and debts contracted during the Extraordinary

Administration are handled as priority claims that precede the claims of creditors whose rights
accrued prior to the beginning of the Extraordinary Administration procedure and can be paid
when due;


-----

(ii) the Extraordinary Commissioner(s) has/have the right to terminate ongoing contracts to which the

company is a party.

Moreover, under the Prodi-bis Procedure a debt restructuring plan is approved exclusively by the
Minister of Economic Development but is not subject to any vote by the creditors.

**_Extraordinary administration for the industrial restructuring of large insolvent companies_**
**_(amministrazione straordinaria per la ristrutturazione industriale delle grandi imprese insolventi)_**
**_under the Decree 347_**

Decree 347 introduced a specific extraordinary discipline for companies meeting certain size
requirements, also known as the 'Marzano Procedure’. Decree 347 is complementary to the Prodi-bis
Procedure and, unless otherwise provided for in Decree 347, the provisions of the Prodi-bis Procedure
apply. The Marzano Procedure applies only to insolvent companies that, on a consolidated basis, have
at least 500 employees in the year preceding the start of the procedure and at least 300 million euros in
outstanding debts.

Pursuant to Decree 347, the decision whether or not to open the procedure lies with the Minister of
Economic Development who, at the request of the debtor (who must at the same time file with the
competent court a petition for the declaration of its insolvency), assesses the existence of the relevant
requirements and, if so, appoints the extraordinary commissioner(s). The extraordinary commissioner
immediately becomes responsible for the management of the company. The court decides on the
company’s insolvency.

Within 180 days of the appointment (or 270 days if agreed with the Minister of Economic Development)
the extraordinary commissioner must submit to the Minister of Economic Development, for approval,
a plan for the rescue of the company through liquidation or asset restructuring, and at the same time
must file with the competent court a report on the state of the company.

A restructuring plan proposed under a procedure subject to Decree 347 may include a plan of
arrangement, with the possibility of dividing creditors into classes, with different treatments applicable
to creditors belonging to different classes, and with proposals for the cancellation of any obligations
owed by the debtor and/or the conversion of debt securities into shares in the debtor company or any of
its group companies. Decree 347 provides that an arrangement plan must be approved by creditors
according to the same majority voting rules that apply in the context of the arrangement procedure, as
described above. If the restructuring plan is not approved by the Minister of Economic Development,
the extraordinary commissioner(s) may propose an asset disposal plan. If the asset disposal plan is not
approved, the company must be put into liquidation.

When Decree 134 applies to an extraordinary administration, its purpose is generally to extend the
powers of sale. To this end, the insolvency administrator is given the power to identify and compose
branches of business or partial branches of business, even if not pre-existing, that may be subject to
sale. As a general consideration, it should be noted that under the claw-back rules applicable to the
extraordinary administration (i) the hardening period would be calculated by reference to the date of
the declaration of insolvency; and (ii) with respect to intercompany transactions only, longer hardening
periods would apply (i.e., 5 years or 3 years, depending on the type of transactions).

**_Compulsory administrative winding-up (liquidazione coatta amministrativa)_**

Administrative compulsory liquidation (liquidazione coatta amministrativa), as provided for in Article
293 et seq. of the Insolvency Code, is only available to public interest entities such as state-controlled
companies, insurance companies, credit institutions and other financial institutions, none of which may
be liquidated under judicial winding-up proceedings, unless otherwise provided for by Italian law. It is
irrelevant whether these companies belong to the public or private sector.


-----

Administrative compulsory liquidation (liquidazione coatta amministrativa) is a special insolvency
procedure in that the entity is liquidated not by the court but by the competent administrative authority
that oversees the sector in which the entity operates. The procedure may be triggered not only by the
insolvency of the entity concerned, but also by other grounds expressly provided for by the relevant
legal provisions (e.g., as regards Italian banks, serious irregularities in the management of the bank or
serious violations of the applicable legal, administrative or statutory provisions).

The effect of this procedure is that the entity loses control over its assets and a liquidator (commissario
_liquidatore) is appointed to liquidate the company by the competent governmental authority (e.g., the_
Bank of Italy or the Ministry of Economic Development, which are competent to file a petition for a
declaration of insolvency with the consequent opening of compulsory administrative liquidation
proceedings). The work of the liquidator is monitored by a supervisory committee (comitato di
_sorveglianza)._

The powers attributed to the delegated judge and the court in the context of other insolvency
proceedings are assumed by the competent administrative authority in these proceedings.

The effects of administrative compulsory liquidation (liquidazione coatta amministrativa) on creditors
are largely the same as in insolvency proceedings and include, for example, the prohibition of
enforcement measures. The same rules established for insolvency proceedings with respect to existing
contracts and creditors’ claims apply to a large extent to administrative compulsory liquidation
(liquidazione coatta amministrativa).

**_Adequate organizational, administrative and accounting corporate structures_**

The Insolvency Code introduced the definition of the organizational, administrative and accounting
structures (assetto organizzativo, amministrativo e contabile) of a company considered adequate
(adeguata) pursuant to Article 2086 of the Italian Civil Code, which are required by the applicable
legislation for the purpose of the timely detection of a state of crisis and the taking of appropriate actions
by the debtor.

More precisely, Article 3 of the Insolvency Code requires the entrepreneur to adopt an adequate
organizational structure pursuant to Article 2086 of the Italian Civil Code, for the purpose of the timely
detection of the state of crisis of the enterprise as well as the timely undertaking of suitable initiatives
to overcome the crisis and recover business continuity.

Pursuant to Article 3 of the Insolvency Code:

(i) for the purposes of the timely detection of the enterprise’s state of crisis, the measures and

structures deemed appropriate must enable:

(a) detect any imbalances of an asset or economic-financial nature, related to the specific
characteristics of the enterprise as well as to the activity carried out by the debtor

(b) verify the unsustainability of the debts and the absence of any prospect of business
continuity for the next twelve months, as well as the warning signs identified in Article 3(4)
of the Insolvency Code; and

(c) obtain the information necessary to follow the detailed checklist and conduct the practical
test for the reasonable pursuit of the debtor’s financial recovery.

(ii) Warning signs are identified as, inter alia, the following:

(a) the existence of payroll debts that are at least 30 days past due and equal to more than half
of the total amount of the monthly payroll;


-----

(b) the existence of accounts receivable from suppliers that are at least 90 days past due in an
amount greater than the amount of the outstanding accounts receivable;

(c) the existence of exposures to banks and other financial intermediaries that are past due by
more than 60 days or that have exceeded the limit on credit facilities obtained in any form
for at least 60 days, provided that they collectively represent at least 5% of the total
exposures; and

(d) the existence of one or more exposures to certain public institutions listed in Article 25novies of the Insolvency Code.

**_New financial resources_**

The following is a brief summary of the main features of the provisions relating to the various loans
available under the Insolvency Code.

Interim financings – article 99, paragraphs from 1 to 4 of the Insolvency Code

According to Article 99 (1) and (2) of the Insolvency Code, in the framework of restructuring
transactions as a going concern (continuazione dell’attività aziendale), even in cases where business
continuity is exclusively preserved with a view to liquidation, upon the debtor’s request, the court, until
the approval of the debt restructuring agreements (accordi di ristrutturazione dei debiti) (pursuant to
Article 57 or Article 60 or 61 of the Insolvency Code) may grant interim financing or a petition pursuant
to Article 87 of the Insolvency Code in connection with composition proceedings (concordato
_preventivo), including in the case of a “simplified petition” pursuant to Article 44 of the Insolvency_
Code, may allow the debtor to obtain new super-senior financing (finanziamenti prededucibili) and to
secure such indebtedness, upon authorisation by the court, with in rem securities (garanzie reali) or
with the assignment of claims, provided that the petition specifies:

(i) the purpose of the financing;

(ii) that the debtor is unable to obtain the necessary funds otherwise; and

(iii) that the absence of such financing will result in impending and irretrievable harm to the company’s

ability to continue as a going concern or to the proceedings;

The petition must be accompanied by the report of the expert appointed by the debtor in which the
expert, after verifying the overall financial needs of the company until the approval, states that the new
financing is functional to the continuity of the company’s business until the approval of the relevant
bankruptcy proceedings or the opening of the proceedings or their continuation and, in any event, is
intended to provide a better satisfaction of creditors’ rights. The expert’s report is not necessary if the
court recognizes the urgency of avoiding imminent and irreparable harm to the company’s continuity.
In the event of the debtor’s subsequent admission to judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale), such
financing does not benefit from super-senior priority (prededucibilità) if the petition or the expert’s
report contained false data or omitted important information or if the debtor has performed acts to the
in fraud of creditors (atti in frode ai creditori) and the liquidator demonstrates that those who made
such financing available to the debtor were aware of such facts at the date of the payment.

Bridge financings – article 99, para. 5 of the Insolvency Code

According to Article 99(5) of the Insolvency Code, financing (together with the related claims) granted,
in any form, with a view to the filing of a petition for approval of a debt restructuring agreement
(accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) or an arrangement procedure (concordato preventive) (finanza
_ponte), may be super-senior (prededucibili) provided that (i) they meet the requirements of Article 99(1)_
and (2) (as indicated above), and (ii) they are provided as part of the relevant plan and on condition that
the super-seniority (prededucibilità) is expressly set forth in the decree by which the court grants the


-----

application for admission to the composition agreement (concordato preventivo) or approves the
restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione).

The debts arising from such financing may be secured, subject to the court’s approval, by _in rem_
securities (garanzie reali) or the assignment of receivables.

Implementation financing – article 101 of the Insolvency Code

Pursuant to Article 101 of the Insolvency Code, in the context of restructuring transactions as a goingconcern (continuazione dell’attività aziendale), financing granted to the debtor in execution of an
approved composition agreement (concordato preventivo) or a debt restructuring agreement (accordo
_di ristrutturazione dei debiti) ranks super-senior (prededucibile) to the extent that it is expressly_
provided for in the relevant business continuation plan.

In the event of the debtor’s subsequent admission to judicial liquidation (liquidazione giudiziale), such
loans do not benefit from super-senior priority (prededucibilità) if the plan of arrangement (concordato
_preventivo) or debt restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti) has been approved,_
on the basis of an assessment to be made at the time of its filing, are founded on false data or the failure
to provide relevant information, or where the debtor has committed acts in fraud of creditors (atti in
_frode ai creditori) and the liquidator demonstrates that those who made such financing available to the_
debtor were well aware of such events at the date of the disbursement.

The shareholders’ financing – article 102 of the Insolvency Code

According to Section 102(1) of the Insolvency Code, super-seniority (prededucibilità) is also granted
for claims up to 80% of the value of shareholder loans that have been granted to the company in any
form (including any guarantee or grant of counter-indemnity) in execution or in anticipation of an
homologated composition procedure (concordato preventivo) or debt restructuring agreement (accordo
_di ristrutturazione dei debiti). Restructuring agreement (also as an exception to the subordination_
regime provided for by the Italian Civil Code for loans granted to corporations by shareholders or
persons exercising management and coordination activities).

Pursuant to Article 102(2) of the Insolvency Code, if the lender becomes a shareholder only upon
execution of the composition agreement (concordato preventivo) or debt restructuring agreement
(accordo di ristrutturazione dei debiti), the senior ranking will apply to the entire amount of the loan.

Super senior ranking – article 99 para. 6 and article 101 para. 2 of the Insolvency Code

According to Article 6(1) of the Insolvency Code, providing the relevant conditions are met, claims
arising from bridge financing, interim financing and implementation financing are super-senior
(prededucibile) by virtue of the law. Pursuant to Article 6(2) of the Insolvency Code, predeductibility
remains in any subsequent insolvency or enforcement proceedings.

In specific circumstances, such loans may not have super-senior status (prededucibilità) in the event of
judicial liquidation if, inter alia, the liquidator proves that the debtor has committed acts of fraud.

In particular, for interim or bridge financing, false data or omission of relevant information are relevant
if found by the court in the request for the incurrence of the financing or in the independent expert’s
attestation, whereas for implementation financing, such elements are relevant if included in the plan
underlying the composition agreement or debt restructuring agreement.

Article 99(6) of the Insolvency Code provides that interim and bridge financing shall be treated as a
financing transaction, so that in the event of the opening of a judicial liquidation (liquidazione
giudiziale), such financing (even if authorised by the court in the context of composition proceedings
(concordato preventivo) or the debt restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione)) does not


-----

benefit from super senior status when it is proven (jointly) that: (i) the application or the independent
expert’s report contains false data or omits relevant information, or when the debtor has committed acts
to defraud creditors in order to obtain the authorisation; and (ii) the liquidator proves that the lender, at
the date the loan was granted, was aware of the above-mentioned circumstances.

With respect to implementation loans, Article 101(2) of the Insolvency Code provides that such loans
do not benefit from super-seniority (prededucibilità), in the event of the opening of a judicial liquidation
(liquidazione giudiziale) (alternatively) (i) when, on the basis of an assessment to be made at the time
of the filing of the application for the opening of the proceedings, the plan underlying the composition
agreement (concordato preventivo) or the debt restructuring agreement (accordo di ristrutturazione dei
debiti) turns out to be based on false data or the omission of relevant information; or (ii) when the debtor
has committed acts of fraud against its creditors and the liquidator proves that the lenders who provided
the loans were aware of such circumstances at the time the loans were granted.

**United States**

Under U.S. federal bankruptcy laws or comparable provisions of state fraudulent transfer laws, under
certain circumstances:
